TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our opposition to specific changes proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and associated subordinate legislation in the 1993-94 Federal Budget introduced by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on Tuesday 17 August 1993.
Specifically, we the undersigned oppose:
(i)proposed measures whereby students taking more than an extra semester to complete their first undergraduate degree accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 1.5;
(ii)proposed measures whereby students enrolling in second undergraduate degrees accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 2; and
(iii)proposed measures whereby the rates of prepayment increase from 2, 3 and 4 per cent of taxable income up to 3, 4 and 5 per cent for the three thresholds respectively.
We strongly urge the Senate to reject these measures.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the majority of people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:
(a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

(c)Its closure will place at risk the immediate future in Tasmania of 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active Reservists and 40 inactive Reservists and in addition will deprive the Naval Reserve Cadets of their Tasmanian Divisional Headquarters; and, the fact that only a miserable $250,000 will be allegedly saved out of the National Defence budget of over $9 billion,

and therefore call upon the Keating Government to immediately reverse the decision to close HMAS Huon and to give a commitment that it will continue to be the Headquarters of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 28 February 1994, on the following matters:

TAB.TAB: (a)the origin and basis of decisions in 1991 and 1993 to increase the permissible percentage of foreign ownership of newspapers, and, in particular:
(i)whether those decisions were influenced by considerations relating to the content of newspapers including any requirement for `balanced' coverage,
(ii)whether the contents of newspapers were influenced by those decisions or the prospect of those decisions,
(iii)the procedures followed by the Foreign Investment Review Board and the extent to which any of its deliberations or recommendations were taken into account in the making of those decisions, and
(iv)whether the Prime Minister influenced or sought to influence those decisions, and, if so, the basis on which and the extent to which he did so; and
(b)the significance and effectiveness of the guidelines of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

PARA.TAB: (2)That the committee consist of nine senators, as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)four nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)four nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: (3)That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition;
(b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair shall be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy chair of the committee be appointed by the chair from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;
(d)that the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and
(e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

PARA.TAB: (5)That the quorum of the committee be five members.

(6)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(7)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.
(8)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media; and
(b)written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard, including oral evidence from the authors of the most important submissions.

PARA.TAB: (9)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(10)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(11)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

I refer to the Radiocommunications Regulations, Statutory Rules 1993 No. 177, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 2 September 1993.

SUBJECT:ENQUIRY FROM THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES ABOUT THE APPLICATION FEES SET BY THE SUPERANNUATION FEES REGULATIONS (CSS AND PSS)
Purpose:To explain the basis upon which the level of fee was proposed to you
Background:

Division 5 of Part IVA of the Superannuation Act 1976 and Part 11 of the Superannuation Act 1990 provide for the reconsideration of decisions made by the CSS and PSS Boards of Trustees respectively. These provisions also allow for the payment of a fee when a person applies for reconsideration of a Board decision.

2. When the CSS and PSS review mechanisms were considered by Cabinet it was proposed that a fee should be set to limit vexatious applications and that the level of the fee should be based on the average cost of hearing appeals (a fee of $250 was mooted). It was also proposed that if an adverse decision was reversed by the Trustees, the fee should be refunded.

3. At their meetings held on 8 August 1991 the CSS and PSS Boards of Trustees considered whether fees should be prescribed in the circumstances outlined above. The Boards were advised that it would not be practicable to set a fee on a cost recovery basis as the cost of reconsidering an average invalidity retirement case would be at least $1500 and would prove prohibitive.

4. Both Boards decided, by a majority, that it would be appropriate to set a fee and that the appropriate level would be $150 (this was at that time the same as a reconsideration fee set under legislation administered by the then Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and half the fee set by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal). The Boards considered it would be appropriate to index the fee for inflation and that the level of fee should be reviewed in 12 months. In addition, the Boards considered that the Regulations should provide for the fee to be refunded where it is decided not to proceed with a reconsideration decision or where the outcome of the reconsideration is to the applicant's advantage.

5. The Superannuation Fees Regulations (CSS and PSS) applied to persons requesting reconsideration of a decision on or after the date of gazettal of the Regulations (20 July 1993). To date the fees have not been reviewed.

Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letter dated 30 September 1993 concerning the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1993 No. 206.

Of the regulations you have identified, rr. 20B, 21(1B) and 21(1C) provide the power to either revoke or suspend a permission in the specified circumstances. I am assured that these matters are covered under the review process outlined in subregulation 22 which includes provisions relating to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Regulation 20A in addition to allowing the Authority to suspend permissions also allows it to vary or impose additional conditions. The variation or imposition of new conditions is not presently covered by regulation 22. This appears to have been an oversight with this form of words being in the regulations since Statutory Rules 247 of 1987.

Regulation 21(1) provides a new power to vary a permission in circumstances where the permission holder has failed to comply with a condition of the permit. This is not presently a reviewable decision.

Regulation 19E introduces a capacity to transfer permits. This was requested by tourist operators. Previously permits were not transferable. The exercise of the discretion under r. 19E is not reviewable under regulation 22.
I intend to have r. 20A, r. 21(1) and r. 19E amended so that they will be reviewable under regulation 22.

Regulation 51B does not give the Authority any discretion, since the amount of the charge payable in any quarter is determined by the regulations. Therefore any overpayment is simply the excess of what has been paid after subtracting the amount of liability. I am advised this is therefore not a matter which should be reviewable under regulation 22. A later amendment to this regulation (Statutory Rules 266 of 1993) allows the Authority to refund the amount of the overpayment directly to the permit holder.

In conclusion some of the discretionary powers which the Committee has identified are not reviewable under the provisions of regulation 22 and I agree that they should be. Where appropriate I intend to amend the regulations so that those discretions identified are properly reviewable.
Yours sincerely
ROS KELLY

CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 30 September 1993 concerning the Guidelines under section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (the Act). I apologise for the delay in responding to you.
Relevant sections of the Act

Section 18(2) of the Act provides that I may specify a sporting or cultural event held, or to be held, in Australia if, and only if, I am satisfied, having regard to the guidelines in force under subsection 18(5) of the Act that:

PARA.TAB: the event is of international significance; and
failure to specify the event would be likely to result in the event not being held in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Purpose of the Guidelines
The purpose of the Guidelines is, therefore, to ensure that I take into account factors relevant to determining whether an event qualifies for an exemption under section 18(2) of the Act.
Current Guidelines

Under the current Guidelines, there are six factors which I consider in determining `international significance' (under clause 2) and a further three factors in determining `lost to Australia' (under clause 3).
You have queried the appropriateness of the inclusion of the final factor in clauses 2 and 3 of the Guidelines, which is, "any other information that the Minister believes is relevant".
The Act explores new areas of prohibition, that is, the prohibition of most remaining forms of tobacco sponsorship of sporting and cultural events.

During the development of this new legislation, a great deal of consideration was given to the types of events to which this part of the Act was intended to apply. I was most concerned to ensure that the Guidelines were as clear and unambiguous as possible. In particular I wished to ensure that applicants fully appreciated the key factors against which my decision would be made.
I was concerned that, despite this consideration, it would not be possible to foresee:
the variety of events for which specification would be sought under Section 18(2); and
therefore, all of the factors that should legitimately be considered as relevant in determining applications under this section.

The clauses you have questioned were, therefore, included to enable me to consider relevant factors which could not be addressed against any of the other criteria. The clauses have, to-date, proved appropriate. Following are some specific examples of factors which I considered to be directly relevant and which had not come to my attention during the development of the guidelines;

In relation to the Fosters Australian Formula One Grand Prix the applicant advised that FISA (the international organising body) cancelled the French Grand Prix when the French Government refused to allow teams, sponsored by tobacco companies, to display tobacco adverting. This was directly relevant to determining whether the event was likely to be lost to Australia without a specification.

In relation to the Australian Motor Cycle Grand Prix the applicant advised that it was a term of the promoter's contract that the organising body had the right to terminate the contract if any legislation prejudiced the event. The applicant further advised that failure to specify the event would result in triggering this right. This was directly relevant to determining whether the event would be lost to Australia.
Inclusion of the clause "any other information that the Minister believes is relevant", therefore, gives applicants the opportunity to submit:
information specific to an event, which is relevant in assisting me to understand the nature of that particular event.

The examples I have included are not an exhaustive list of relevant factors which are not specifically reflected in the current Guidelines. This is because the legislation has been operative for less than 6 months and I am continuing to receive applications and hence learn about the cross-section of international events of significance to which this Section has application.

Whilst the clause "any other information that the Minister believes is relevant" is useful at this time, I believe that it may be possible, with experience, to produce Guidelines which specifically detail all factors relevant to my decision making process.

I undertake to review the Guidelines particularly the general provisions at Clause 2(f) and 3(c), in a little over 7 months. At that time, the Guidelines will have been operational for 12 months and the majority of events for which an exemption is necessary, will have been considered.
I will also ensure that future instruments of this type include a citation or number by which the instrument can be identified. I apologise that this was not included for the current Guidelines.

Finally, should your Committee secretariat require additional information or clarification of points raised in this letter, Mr Tony Kingdon, Assistant Secretary, Drugs of Dependence Branch, of my Department would be pleased to assist you. Mr Kingdon can be contacted on telephone 289 7025.
Yours sincerely,
GRAHAM RICHARDSON
30 September 1993

Dear Mal

Thank you for your letter of 30 September 1993, addressed to Senator the Hon Graham Richardson, concerning the formulation of Principles under the National Health Act 1953 (NHA). Your letter was referred to me as the matters raised are within my portfolio responsibility.

Principles were not numbered in this case as it was felt that reference to the Section or Sub-section of the NHA was sufficient. However, your suggestion of numbering the Principles to reduce confusion for users is noted and future Principles will be numbered.

You also raised the concern of the use of the term ". . . .. or such larger amount as determined by the Minister from time to time". The phrase was inserted to provide the Minister responsible for the provision of additional recurrent funding for upgrading of nursing homes the power to determine rates of subsidy consistent with movements in costs and is used only for that purpose. However, given the concerns you raise, I am prepared to amend the Principles to remove the possibility of sub-delegation.

Finally, I should point out that the whole of the Commonwealth legislation on aged care is currently being reviewed by the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Commission will be specifically looking at the role played by subordinate legislation, the issue of sub-delegation and the issue of appeal provisions on funding decisions where resources are limited.
Yours Sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the report on its inquiry into the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate a brief tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I have pleasure in presenting the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on aspects of the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1993.
This report addresses some key themes of the Government's proposed reforms as provided for in that Bill.

In the short time available for its inquiry into aspects of the Bill, the Committee has considered a substantial volume of both written and oral evidence from a representative range of interested parties. The report is not a close analysis of the technical detail of the Bill, but rather an assessment of the main features of the proposed reforms.

It is clear to the Committee that the need for industrial relations reform is a pressing one. It is equally clear that the system of enterprise bargaining which the Government wishes to encourage with this Bill is one which provides both optimal flexibility and adequate protection.

I am confident that the reforms proposed in this Bill will serve Australia well as the basis for an industrial relations system that is open to all. The legislation also serves to ensure that the standards operating in Australian workplaces are commensurate with those required of Australia by international treaty.

Time did not permit us to make a comprehensive response to the Bill, but the report indicates the Committee's support for the broad thrust of the legislative reforms. There are some particular aspects of the Bill which the Committee has chosen to draw to the attention of the Government. These are matters which emerged during the course of the inquiry, and the Committee hopes that they will prove a useful contribution to the general debate. The report contains a dissent from Senators Crane and Chapman.

The Committee wishes to thank all those who gave evidence to the Committee, and in particular, the Department of Industrial Relations whose cooperation and frequent appearances at public hearings were of substantial assistance to the Committee. We also thank the Secretariat for their magnificent efforts which enabled this report to be tabled today, before the introduction of the Bill.
Chair, Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion to take note of the report of the inquiry of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into the Industrial Relations Bill 1993 in view of the fact that Senator Chapman and I, the Liberal members of the committee, have put in a dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: We say in that dissenting report that, looking at the evidence given to the committee, the lack of consultation on and understanding of this bill, the rigidity and complexity of it—and for a whole range of other reasons which I will deal with in a moment—the minister should withdraw the bill, consult properly with everybody involved in industrial relations, and come back with legislation which reflects the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Institute of Directors on 21 April 1993. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me describe the model of industrial relations we are working towards . . . It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases would be there only as a safety net . . . Over time the safety net would inevitably become simpler. We would have fewer awards, with fewer clauses.

An examination of this bill shows that the exact opposite has happened. That process of destruction started the very next day when, on ABC Daybreak, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) said:

Well, of course, what the Prime Minister said, yesterday, was that the next four months are going to be exclusively devoted to widespread consultation with the union movement. And John (Halfpenny) and all of his colleagues will have ample opportunity, over the coming weeks and months, to make all of the points that they wish to in developing the Government's policy package. I would hope to go to the Cabinet by August of this year, with a full range of the views of the trade union movement . . .

The only thing about that statement that is not accurate is that we are dealing with the matter now and I understand that we will get the bill this afternoon or tomorrow morning. So the minister is just a couple of months late. He has carried out all those promises and we have legislation which will not enhance flexibility or get rid of the rigidity in our current industrial relations system; in fact, it will enhance it.

PARA.TAB: Employers' anger, disappointment and frustration at this bill are best summed up in the key points made by the Australian Wool Selling Brokers. Those key points are that the commitments made to the Australian business community by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations earlier this year are not reflected in the context of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993; and the processes through which this bill was developed do not reflect the International Labour Organisation's principles on general consultation with the parties affected. The result is a bill which is seen to be unbalanced and which ignores the needs of the Australian business community.

The convoluted, complex nature of the bill will do little to assist the implementation of more flexible appropriate labour arrangements in the Australian workplace. The proposed reforms in the non-union sector are such that they will not be utilised and, therefore, will deny 70 per cent of persons employed in the private sector access to determining their working conditions. The bill encourages industrial action by unions and their members by condoning its use as a tool to obtain wage improvements. The removal of protections from boycotts will not assist in the creation of business confidence so as to ensure Australia's economic future.

Witness after witness, and submission after submission—with the exception of the ACTU, although even the ACTU was not totally satisfied—consistently criticised the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. They consistently criticised the government for its approach to consultation. In fact, it would appear that the major part of the consultation—probably more aptly described as an audience—took place after the government and the ACTU had set down the principles of the bill. Witnesses were frustrated at the complexity of this bill; the additional power given to the union movement; and the fact that the award system is being made more rigid, and that the number of tests with regard to the establishment of certified agreements has been significantly increased. They highlighted that the no disadvantage test was a real impediment to the development of genuine flexibility in the workplace.

They said that enterprise flexibility agreements would not happen because of the necessity for unions either to be involved in the negotiating process, if there are unions in the workplace, or to have the power to vet agreements before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission when they are not present in the workplace. Witnesses could not understand the need for an industrial court because they believed that the industrial division of the Federal Court had the necessary expertise and was independent. Last, but certainly not least, they were angry at the decimation of the boycott provisions of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

I want to bring out a couple of points. The first is the minimum wage provisions as they pertain to the bill and the necessity that they be set by an independent arbitrator or by an arbitration commission. We have the potentially ridiculous situation where the Commonwealth sets its minimum wage at $300, plus various other conditions; Western Australia sets its at $250, plus various other conditions; and Queensland sets its at $200—$50 less than Western Australia. Because Western Australia's minimum wage is set by the minister on a recommendation from the Industrial Relations Commission, it would not be void under this bill, but Queensland's would be. If anyone on the other side of the chamber can explain the commonsense of that, I would be very interested to hear it.

The other aspect is that this is not conclusive, even though we were given evidence from the department that the Western Australian position will not stand. The message that we got from this inquiry is that, in terms of industrial relations, the states should be allowed to get on and govern and carry out their mandates. This is what is happening in Western Australia. We have seen the selective use of the external affairs powers, ILO conventions and international conventions. One rule is being applied in some areas but other rules are not being applied as far as freedom of association is concerned.

We were told about the lack of consultation and the lack of understanding in respect of this legislation. We were also informed that confusion exists in so many people's minds because of the complexity of this matter. Mr Robert Bastian, a representative of COSBOA, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I say over and over again that we do not understand the full ramifications of this bill. Nobody does. That is point one. I stress again that the smaller end of things is where employment is really occurring and where this bill seems, in my view, to land most harshly. Quite frankly, the government is not much further advanced than I am in terms of approaching the back of a TV set with a screwdriver. I just do not think we know what we are playing with here. My strongest counsel would be to say not to ram this thing through in the next couple of weeks, let the debate run for as long as it takes to get a clearer picture.

Mr Bastian spelt out quite clearly the degree of confusion which exists in the community in relation to this legislation. He highlighted, as others have, how unsatisfactory the consultative process has been. These people highlighted very succinctly their views about moving towards enterprise flexibility agreements.

PARA.TAB: The processes that have been put in place with regard to enterprise flexibility agreements will ensure that not many, if any, agreements will get off the ground. One of the concerns raised in relation to enterprise flexibility agreements is that changes have not been made to the no disadvantage test. Evidence was consistently given to us on how the no disadvantage test would interfere with the development of certified agreements. It was put to us, `Why would we bother going through that process when we know full well that any agreement reached with our employees would be overridden when we get to the commission?'. The government must ask itself why it wants to go past just having minimum standards which protect the position of the people involved in the enterprise flexibility agreements. It should also ask itself why it wants to continue to indulge in this no disadvantage test.

Representatives of small businesses such as COSBOA—70 per cent of the people they employ are outside the union system—asked why they should bother going through a process in which a union had to be involved in the total negotiations if one or more employees were unionists, or the union had to be notified if employees did not belong to a union. It was consistently put to us that if an employer and its employees reached an agreement approved by a secret ballot—some suggested a 65 per cent agreement and some suggested a 51 per cent agreement—then that agreement ought to be able to be registered. That to me seems to be a commonsense approach.

But this government will not do that. Earlier in my speech I quoted what had been said by the minister, Mr Brereton. He made it quite clear who would be running the agenda. Evidence was given to us that the 10 additional tests that have been put in this legislation will make it almost impossible for enterprise flexibility agreements to get off the ground and certified agreements to be expanded. Some of these tests are not very onerous but others are extremely onerous, and they will stand in the way of people moving towards a more flexible wage fixing system.

I will briefly comment on the removal of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. We have already had one report on this matter. This proposal highlights the extent to which this government is prepared to allow Australia's exports to be put in jeopardy. The removal of sections 45D and 45E would severely curtail legal action in regard to boycotts of a political nature involving the movement over the wharfs of our live sheep, coal, wheat, wool and meat, and other export products.

The proposition was put to the committee that the common law could be used. But we were told by departmental officers that if ships were tied up in one, two, three or four ports around the Commonwealth, one would have to take action under common law in each Supreme Court. Practitioners—the people working on the ground—explained to the committee that even though there were a lot of complaints about the expense of 45D and 45E actions, common law actions would be of the order of 40 per cent more expensive than the 45D and 45E actions.

I should make a point about the industrial relations court. The opposition will certainly be moving to amend this part of the legislation. These responsibilities should be left with the industrial division of the Federal Court. The best reasons for the appropriateness of this arrangement were given to us by the Law Council.

It is also worth looking at what Lionel Bowen said in 1978 when the Industrial Court was taken away and the industrial division of the Federal Court was put in place. It is also interesting to note the reasons that Mr Ralph Willis gave in 1988 for the federal government not moving to bring in an industrial court. The reasons Ralph Willis gave at that time are just as valid today as they were then.

I conclude my remarks on this report by repeating that it is disappointing that this government has brought down legislation which in fact gives more power to the unions. This legislation will not `do the trick' in terms of taking the rigidity out of the labour market. It will not bring about the flexibility that this country desperately needs. I have outlined the hostility to this legislation. Honourable senators would have had to be at the committee hearings to see the real frustration, anger and disappointment at the fact that, although the Prime Minister promised so much on 21 April, he and Mr Brereton have delivered so little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry in relation to the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 that has been conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training shows very clearly that never has a government promised so much but delivered so little. The speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) following the March election which he delivered to the Institute of Directors on 21 April 1993 heralded a new world, a new era, of industrial relations for Australia. In this new world that was promised by the Prime Minister, awards were to become only a safety net and eventually would fade away. However, as the close examination which has been directed towards this bill by the committee shows, the legislation that was before the committee and which will be shortly before this house does not meet the criteria set down by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: That was certainly the overwhelming view of the witnesses before this committee in the evidence that they presented to the committee. I refer to the dissenting report, which has been tabled today as part of the committee report, written by my colleague Senator Crane, who has just addressed the chamber, and myself. The transcript of evidence shows that I asked Mr Bryan Noakes from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry the following question about this legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you believe that this legislation delivers what the Prime Minister promised to deliver in industrial relations in his speech of 21 April?
Mr Noakes replied:
No, it does not, not in the least.
Then I further queried:
It is another broken promise.
Of course, we all know that Mr Noakes is the epitome of courtesy and respect; therefore, Mr Noakes replied:
I would not put it in that way, but certainly expectations were created by the speech of 21 April.

Certainly, the Prime Minister created expectations of a new era in industrial relations which this bill simply does not deliver. When one considers the balance of the evidence that has been presented to this committee over three very exhausting and detailed days of hearings the only conclusion that one can reach is that that is the correct view—the legislation does not deliver what the Prime Minister promised and it will not deliver the needed reforms in industrial and employee relations in Australia. We will not get better productivity in our firms. We will not get more competitive firms to build our export markets and thereby overcome the enormous foreign debt under which Australia continues to languish as a result of this particular legislation. That is why, regrettably, Senator Crane and I have found it absolutely necessary to prepare and present a dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: For a few minutes I will direct attention to some of the conclusions which were reached by the majority of the committee—the Labor members of that committee and the Australian Democrat who agreed with their conclusions and general statements. In doing so, I have to say that, while the report presented by the majority members of the committee certainly presents a range of evidence relating to the bill, Senator Crane and I believe that it fails to assess that evidence in a balanced way. The majority report gives undue credence to the submissions and evidence from the ACTU and the Department of Industrial Relations and gives inadequate weighting to the submissions and evidence presented from a wide range of business representatives.

We certainly cannot support the view of the majority members of the committee that the evidence sustains the conclusions which they have reached. Our objections to those conclusions begin with paragraph 3 of their foreword to the report. The majority members of the committee claim:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the system of enterprise bargaining which the government wishes to encourage with this Bill is one which provides both optimal flexibility and adequate protection.

The Committee is confident that the reforms proposed in this Bill will serve Australia well as the basis for an industrial relations system that is open to all. The legislation also serves to ensure that the standards operating in Australian workplaces are commensurate with those required of Australia by international treaty.
Paragraph 5 of the foreword also indicates the committee's support for the broad thrust of the legislative reforms.

PARA.TAB: As I said, if one considers the evidence in a balanced way, there is absolutely no way in which that conclusion can be validly reached. We believe that the legislation itself does not provide the opportunity for optimal flexibility and will not begin a system and a structure of industrial relations that will serve Australia well. But it is not only the specifics of the legislation and what it lacks which are important; it is also the perception about the legislation. Time and time again, the employer and business witnesses that came before this committee stated their view that this legislation would not provide the desperately needed flexibility that Australian industrial relations requires, providing the opportunity for the development of enterprise agreements based on enterprise bargaining.

Quite simply, if that is the belief of those witnesses—those major parties to industrial agreements and employee relations—then they will not achieve the opening up of the system that Australia desperately needs, irrespective of whether in detailed argument it might be asserted by the majority members of the committee that the legislation does allow that. The simple fact is that the employers do not believe that it does. There are some 16 tests now required, for example, to achieve certified agreements—16 hurdles that have to be jumped before those certified agreements can be achieved. They believe that that is simply too difficult to achieve within their enterprises.

Of course, that will mean that small businesses in particular will seek to remain outside the industrial relations structure and perhaps not observe the law as is required of them, as we know happens on many occasions already. That is not a healthy situation that ought to be provided by new legislation.

The employers were particularly concerned that under this legislation enterprise agreements would continue to be nothing more than over-award payments. Again, the majority of the committee rejected this view of the employers, but all of the evidence that has been presented to us and the perceptions of the employers suggest that this is the case. Again, it would appear that in reality that is the way the system will operate—that enterprise flexibility agreements and certified agreements will simply become another name for over-award arrangements.

There was also great concern on the part of employers about the legislation requiring the obligatory participation of trade unions in the development of certified agreements and enterprise flexibility agreements. Nevertheless, the majority of the committee accepted that obligatory participation. Senator Crane and I cannot accept that obligatory participation.

Concern was also expressed by a number of witnesses, including employers and state government representatives, about the capacity of this legislation to override state legislation and the likelihood that it would do so. Again, the majority report, in effect, approves this overriding circumstance. The committee debated this. The federal government was recently re-elected to government in March. Therefore, it might like to claim a mandate for this legislation. However, an examination of the last election campaign shows that absolutely no forewarning was given by the present government of the type of legislation that it proposed with respect to industrial relations reform. As I have already said, immediately after the election the Prime Minister made certain promises which have not been fulfilled in this legislation.

The only reference to industrial relations in the last federal election campaign was the lies and the misrepresentation that we continually heard from the federal Labor government about the proposals in the coalition's industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobsack.

—Jobsback—and if we were putting Jobsback into place now, as this legislation ought to be doing, the future for industrial relations, the future for productivity and the future for Australian competitiveness would be much brighter than it will be under this legislation. But the only thing we heard about industrial relations in the last election campaign was lies and misrepresentation of what the coalition planned to do as far as industrial relations reform was concerned.

PARA.TAB: In contrast to that, recently we have had several state governments elected which have laid out in detail what they intend to do—most recently the Western Australian Liberal government—as far as industrial relations reform is concerned. They have introduced legislation to give effect to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They spelt it out clearly before the election.

—As Senator Crane says, the Western Australian Liberals spelt it out clearly before the election. The South Australian Liberal Party, which is in the middle of an election campaign right now, has spelt out very clearly what it intends to do with regard to industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: So those parties, one in government and one about to be in government, have a very specific and direct mandate as far as the state jurisdiction of industrial relations is concerned. Yet this federal legislation, for which there is no mandate, will, effectively, override that. That is a matter for concern—a matter for concern which the majority of the committee ignored, but a matter for concern which Senator Crane and I certainly do not ignore.

The majority of the committee also dismissed offhandedly concerns expressed by a number of witnesses that this legislation opened up the potential for forum shopping under the legislation—in other words, unions seeking the best deal they could get from either a state or a federal jurisdiction. That is a very real concern that needs to be addressed which is not addressed in this legislation.

Apart from the concern that I have already expressed about the federal government intruding into state jurisdictions contrary to a mandate which a recently elected state government might have, there is also great concern about the intrusion which the federal government is achieving by using the foreign affairs power and, therefore, by implementing through this legislation ILO conventions and recommendations. Again we do not accept the majority's view that this is an appropriate way to ensure adequate and minimum standards for employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the committee's report?
—Indeed I am talking about the committee's report. I will refer specifically to what the majority says on page 27 of the majority committee report.
—No, the committee's report.

—The majority of the committee—not Senator Crane and me—rejected the fears regarding the intrusion into state jurisdiction as a result of applying those ILO conventions and recommendations. They are just some of the objections that we have to the report agreed by the majority of the committee. That is why Senator Crane and I have produced, in a very detailed way, a substantial minority report. Among the conclusions of that minority report we highlight the anger, disappointment and frustration which a number of witnesses have expressed about this bill and to which my colleague Senator Crane referred in his earlier remarks.

PARA.TAB: We have a number of specific recommendations in relation to the legislation which we believe are based on a balanced consideration of the evidence presented to the committee in its hearings. Of course, our major overarching recommendation is that this bill ought to be withdrawn and the government ought to enter into fair dinkum consultation with all of the parties to industrial and employee relations—employers, in the form of small and large businesses, as well as the ACTU and others who have an interest in this field—to achieve legislation and a system of industrial relations which will provide for the productivity gains that this country desperately needs to reduce the excessive levels of unemployment and the massive foreign debt that we have.

The only way we will achieve a reduction in foreign debt and an increase in the number of jobs is by increasing our export earnings and, of course, as a consequence of that, being more successful at import replacement. This legislation will do absolutely nothing for productivity and competitiveness on the part of Australian business to ensure that that occurs. So that is the overarching conclusion that has to be drawn from a balanced assessment of the evidence that was presented to our committee.

We also want to see clause 6 of the bill deleted to ensure that sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act remain there. Despite what the government claims, a number of witnesses provided specific evidence that under the proposed changes whereby sections 45D and 45E will be incorporated in the industrial relations legislation rather than the Trade Practices Act, as is currently the case, they will not have access to that legislation to prevent secondary boycotts, which of course have the potential to do so much damage to businesses in an unjustified way. That clause ought to be repealed.

We also recommend that all provisions for discrimination on the basis of membership or non-membership of a trade union be removed from both the existing act and this bill. This legislation provides for a ban on a number of areas of discrimination. We cannot discriminate on the basis of age, on the basis of sex or on the basis of a whole range of other criteria, but we can still discriminate on the basis of membership or otherwise of an industrial organisation—a trade union. Of course, that is entirely unreasonable and it ought to be removed from the legislation.

We express our opposition to the use of the external affairs power, which I have already mentioned in dealing with the recommendations of the majority report. We also recommend that the procedures for striking enterprise flexibility agreements should be modified, firstly, to remove any requirement that a dispute exists. Of course, this is a complete nonsense. Under the legislation, employers cannot get together with their employees and say, `Let's reach a deal that is suitable for our business. Let's reach an enterprise agreement between me, the employer, and you, the employees. Let's do this all voluntarily'. No, they have to prove that there is an industrial dispute—whether that is a real dispute or a manufactured paper dispute—between the employer and the employee before they can even get to that stage. The government claims that this legislation will introduce greater flexibility, yet all it does is tie us back to the old, outmoded 19th century structure of industrial relations where before we can get any new arrangements in place we have to have an industrial dispute.

With regard to enterprise flexibility agreements—and I referred to this when dealing with the majority report—we also reject the automatic right of a trade union to participate in that approval process whether the employees of the enterprise want the union involved or not. It ought to be the right of those employees to decide whether they want a trade union to represent them in negotiations, or whether they believe they can undertake the negotiations themselves, or whether they want to hire someone else to undertake the negotiations on their behalf. That is a significant shortcoming in the legislation which ought to be amended.

We also recommend that part 7 and part 9 of the legislation be removed. Part 7 deals with the establishment of an industrial relations court. We believe that is entirely unnecessary. The existing industrial division of the Federal Court is quite capable of dealing with legal matters in relation to industrial relations.

We are also concerned with regard to the effect of the legislation on the National Labour Consultative Council, and in particular the reduction of the representation of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry from six representatives on the existing National Labour Consultative Council to but one representative on the restructured council under this legislation. It is obviously a payback to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry for the support that it gave for the coalition's industrial relations policies at the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —They backed a loser, didn't they?

—Senator Burns interjects, `They backed a loser'. What that means is that this government is sectional. This government governs for only one section of the community, not the whole community—as is the responsibility of a good and sound government.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, because the Chamber of Commerce and Industry saw some merit in the industrial relations proposals of the coalition at the last election and because the coalition lost the election, the government is going to wreak vengeance on the Chamber of Commerce and Industry by not giving it the representation to which it is entitled on the National Labour Consultative Council.

DEBATE.TITLE: AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act 1988 to enable duty on aviation kerosene, avtur, to be appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority. At present, the act enables the assessment only of aviation gasoline, avgas, with duty. The appropriation of duties paid on avtur, along with the increase in duty paid on avgas to the CAA, is part of the government's aviation cost recovery agenda for safety regulation.

PARA.TAB: The question of who should fund the cost of safety regulation, the government or the industry, has been quite a controversial one. The argument for government funding of air safety regulation rests on the belief that it is the government's responsibility to provide safety for the public from an industry which operates in public airspace. The argument in favour of industry funding rests on the belief that, if it were not for the existence of the industry, there would not be any need for safety regulations and that, therefore, these regulations should be the industry's responsibility.

There is certainly a case for considerable general revenue funding of aviation safety. The need for prevention of accidents which might occur in the airspace—in which debris might fall on people's houses or property or on people themselves, and these people may have no connection at all with the aviation industry—certainly makes it a matter for general funding rather than industry specific funding. I guess it is a question of degree.

Of course, search and rescue operations, which have cost an enormous amount of money and which are paid for out of the general purse, need to be taken into account. Any accidents we can prevent, of course, would prevent spending of general funds on those search and rescue operations. I highlight the information that I was given at the estimates committee that the search and rescue operations arising out of the recent tragedy of the aircraft which was lost in the Blue Mountains last month entailed a cost of $599,000 for the hire of the search aircraft alone.

Since the establishment of the CAA, the government's position on aviation safety funding has reflected the controversy about who should pay, shifting back and forth between government funding and industry funding, to the most recent position of 50 per cent joint funding. At the time the CAA was established, the government agreed to fully fund aviation safety. This position changed in the 1991 budget when it was announced that there would be full cost recovery from the aviation industry for aviation safety regulation, to be phased in.

In the 1992-93 budget, however, after intense lobbying by the industry, the government changed its position again when it agreed to meet 50 per cent of safety costs to a limit of $22.8 million. This arrangement is to be phased in over a two-year period starting on 1 July. Discussions thus far with regard to this newest government safety regulation agenda have consisted primarily of the CAA proposal for some sort of licensing fee system. This proposal, when announced, failed to gain the support of the industry and the matter has therefore been placed under yet another review to determine what should be done.

While this review continues, the government has gone ahead with three interim measures which are consistent with the 1992-93 proposal to phase in cost recovery from the industry. The first of these measures is a fee to be imposed upon the international operations of Australian aircraft. This fee is to be collected directly by the CAA and the fee is being imposed because fuel used by Australian airlines on international services is exempt from the duty.

The second measure has been to increase the duty paid on avgas by 0.264c per litre. This increase in duty will raise about $250,000 for the year 1993-94 and is to be collected by the Commonwealth and appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority. Prior to this increase, the government collected 22.735c per litre from avgas users which was appropriated to the CAA. It is estimated that for 1993-94, $21.8 million will be gained. This duty is not for safety regulation alone, but is for the normal services provided to avgas users by the CAA. Although the duty on avgas has increased to 22.999c per litre, only 0.264c per litre of this will be used for safety regulation.

The final measure has been to restart the collection of a duty on avtur of 0.264c per litre. This duty is expected to raise $3.35 million for the year and will also be collected by the Commonwealth and appropriated to the CAA. The collection of this duty on avtur was stopped in July 1988. Unlike the other two measures, this measure is not provided for by existing legislation, hence the need for this bill. The purpose of this bill is to allow for the appropriation of avtur duty.

The government has stated that the three measures together will reduce the government's outlays by around $4.5 million. There is some suggestion that this estimate is an incorrect guess and an overstatement for a couple of reasons, one of which is that there is really no correct estimate of the amount which will be raised from the avtur duty because the charge has not been in existence since it was last abolished in 1988.

The financial consequences of this bill represent a definite move towards recovering some of the cost of aviation safety regulation from the aviation industry. The importance of this bill is that it represents a move towards yet another government position for funding aviation safety regulations. My concern is that, in the process, aviation safety will be compromised. I urge caution on just how much funding should be recovered from the industry.

I am worried that the government's constantly changing position on aviation safety funding will result in a reduction in safety funding, closely followed by a reduction in safety standards. Too often we see this Labor government skip from one unresearched policy to another without studying the effects of these policies.

Because general aviation in Australia has had such a difficult last few years—with 14 per cent and 16 per cent per annum declines respectively in activity—it is necessary for the government to be very careful when implementing policies which affect the industry's pocket. The government must remember that safety and economic stability go hand in hand in the aviation industry and any policy which has the potential to jeopardise the balance between these two must be watched very closely.

Since I raised in the Senate estimates committees the recent crash of the Piper aircraft of Monarch Airlines at Young on 11 June this year, I have had many approaches from people in the industry who have told me that that particular aircraft never should have been flying. The airline was known to be struggling financially and losing money. Many reports have suggested that the airline was cutting corners in maintenance and safety simply to stay afloat. I have been told that airworthiness inspectors had been trying to get the air operators certificate for Monarch Airlines cancelled because of grave concerns they had about lack of maintenance on Monarch.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. My point of order is very simple and has been alluded to in the Senate before. TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to get back to the bill, Senator Macdonald? This has nothing to do with this bill.

—This matter is symptomatic of this government and this minister's inability to do things about the CAA and air safety regulation, which is directly employed in this bill because this bill pays for air safety regulation.

PARA.TAB: My concerns in relation to the CAA's administration of air safety were heightened when I learned that last Wednesday week an Eastern Airlines aircraft operating out of Tamworth was told—at about 6,000 feet out of Tamworth—to reduce speed. The air crew retarded the power levers to reduce speed. When the power levers were retarded, the ground spoilers activated. These are lift up devices on the top of wings that destroy the ability of the wings to produce lift. They are designed to operate only with aircraft on the ground to provide assistance to the brakes. The aircraft then suffered considerable loss of altitude at a rapid rate and the air speed decreased by 100 knots. Fortunately, recovery was achieved by the air crew. But had this malfunction occurred during a landing approach phase, the outcome could have been quite disastrous, as could have been the case had the aircraft been in a holding pattern over Sydney at the time when, with that sudden drop, it could have fallen on other aircraft in the holding pattern.

I understand that the incident occurred as a result of faulty maintenance due to replacement of torque links on the main undercarriage assemblies at the Tamworth maintenance facility of Eastern Airlines. How could such a potentially serious incident occur? I believe this to be yet further evidence of a growing picture of declining standards of air safety in Australia. The root cause in this particular case was the lack of maintenance control.

Since I have become involved in this matter through many approaches prior to the estimates committee, the number of people who approach me with real concerns about air safety in Australia are growing.
