SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found the speech of Senator Ian Macdonald quite interesting but he really cannot be taken seriously. The essence of what he is saying is that a system which is driven and guided by profit will cut corners with respect to safety. I just wish that he would carry that general principle over into so much of his other thinking, because in so many other respects he believes that the free market should reign and the profit system should be dominant, and that questions of safety, health, social justice and everything else should be totally ignored.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Ian Macdonald to come in here and protest in a very hollow way that somehow safety will be compromised by a profit-driven system is simply quite inconsistent with what he says in so many other respects at other times. While I would have to agree philosophically with the substance of what Senator Macdonald has said, I simply cannot accept it because he does not consistently take that same line.

The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1993 will be supported by the Australian Democrats. In essence, this legislation concerns the use of market forces. In our opinion, it is an appropriate use of market forces in that the revenue from aviation fuel will be given to CAA as part of the payment for the safety services which CAA provides. It seems to us entirely appropriate that those who use the aviation services with respect to safety and other matters should pay. Clearly, a levy on fuel is a reasonable measure of the intensity of the use of those services. Therefore, this measure essentially lines up with the user pays principle.

We are concerned that the government is not carrying over this principle into other areas. I would remind the Senate that last year, in our Getting to Work document, we made a recommendation in relation to road transport—which is exactly comparable to air transport. We recommended that the fixed costs of car ownership—registration and third party insurance—should also be shifted as a tax on fuel. Nobody is providing a service to those people who buy a vehicle and leave it in the garage. People are, however, providing a service in relation to the use of the roads with respect to safety, policing and health costs in relation to both air pollution and accidents and so on.

The general principle which the government has adopted here—the principle which we accept—should be extended more widely. We would certainly accept the view that the market system, the internalisation of what economists call externalities, is not a complete answer to the problems of covering all aspects of safety, health or anything else. But it is at least a move in the right direction and that is

SPEECH.PARA: fundamentally the reason why we are supporting this legislation. But, in doing so, we would enjoin the government to take that principle and apply it more widely.

PARA.TAB: Last night we saw the rejection of that principle when we were considering the privatisation of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. In numerous other instances the government has not accepted the application of the principle which lies fundamentally at the basis of this legislation. We simply say to the government that it should more widely accept the principle in this area and get on with the job. In doing so, it should recognise that, as I think Senator Ian Macdonald said, while it is a necessary condition, it is not a sufficient condition to take into account all aspects of safety, health and everything else which a complex society needs to take into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest of respect, I thought Senator Coulter would have taken some time to enlarge on those themes. I would like to deal very briefly with the argument that Senator Coulter put up. Apparently, Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats cannot recognise a public interest component in any part of the government's operation. I do not have any difficulty in seeing that governments have a place in looking after a broad section of interests of the community which are best defined as public interest.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of things that only governments can do and that cannot be put out to private industry. To argue, as Senator Coulter did, that it was a matter of this being either black or white, that it was one thing or the other, that people should pay for everything while governments pay for nothing and, therefore, it was quite wrong for Senator Ian Macdonald to talk about a public interest in relation to aviation safety, is to take a rather extreme and totally illogical position.

I wonder whether Senator Coulter would like to pass some legislation in this parliament to provide for people to pay for the protection they get from the police forces. Does he really want every Australian citizen to pay a special levy for the defence forces? If his imagination or intellect cannot cope with that, I would ask him to deny that there is not a public interest in things like public health. Surely there is such an interest in the control of disease by general health and hygiene standards and in the provision of clean drinking water so that we do not have cholera here. Where would we be with inoculation programs if they were dependent on the individual to pay for them? Are Senator Coulter and the Democrats saying that the government has no obligation to provide education for the children of our poor and needy? Senator Coulter surely is not saying that.

The only interpretation and conclusion that can be put on Senator Coulter's line of argument is that, if we are going to the user pays doctrine—which he is embracing so enthusiastically this morning—good, let us get rid of personal income tax. One of the objections I have to the hybrid system is that we are taxed so heavily to provide for services, and that this government slips off the hook and gets into user-pays doctrines but still maintains the previous taxation levels. But enough of that nonsense; it is hardly worth spending my time on it.

The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill, which is before us this morning, increases the rate of duty on avgas, imposes a rate of duty on avtur and passes the money from these measures to the Civil Aviation Authority with respect to its regulatory safety functions. Liquid fuel has been a great milch cow for governments of all persuasions, but the Nobel Prize winner for milking the public purse with respect to fuels has to be the Hawke-Keating junta. Its record is without parallel in Australia's history.

Let us look at where we were when the Liberal Party was in government in 1983. At that time, excise on motor fuel and diesel was 5.15c per litre plus a short-term 2c per litre bicentenary levy. Today, out there on the footpaths of Canberra and in every other outlet in Australia, it is 29.7c per litre. There has been a lift in 10 years from 7.155c per litre to 29.7c per litre. Pretty well everything we do in Australia has a transport component in it; every transport action reflects that staggering and rapacious level of taxation on an essential commodity—a commodity as essential as food—namely, motor fuel.

When this government came to power, aviation fuel was only 6.55c per litre; it is now 22.735c per litre; and we are being asked to impose a levy of 0.264c per litre on it, which will take it to 22.999c, effectively 23c, per litre for aviation gasoline. Admittedly, that is less than the 29.7c, effectively 30c, for motor spirit. But the point we have to remember about aviation gasoline is that its price is always very much higher than motor fuel.

I think fuel in Canberra today is about 71.5c per litre. As recently as two weekends ago, I was paying 95c to 96c per litre for avgas in country areas of New South Wales. The best price I know of is 81.7c at Archerfield in Brisbane. But even at that level, I think the Brisbane price of motor fuel today, without having a state tax on it, is about 58c a litre. So the retail price for avgas is always considerably higher than it is for motor spirit.

This levy will be paid so that the Civil Aviation Authority can discharge its regulatory function. This is in direct contrast to the findings of the Bosch inquiry, which was set up by this government to look at the whole matter of funding the Civil Aviation Authority. It is well known to every member of the Senate chamber that the Bosch inquiry reported that the government should move to 100 per cent cost recovery in aviation over 10 years; the government, in its wisdom, moved to do it in about three years.

Also, on this matter of the supervisory or safety functions of the authority, Bosch argued that there was an unequivocal case for that to be classed as the public interest and that it should be funded out of consolidated revenue. The government agreed with that; there was no ambiguity about it. It said, `Yes, we accept the findings of the Bosch committee'. A couple of years later, when the financial irresponsibility and deficits were mounting, the government said, `We are going to walk away from that'. The proposition we have at the moment is that there will be a recovery of 50 per cent of the regulatory costs this financial year and 100 per cent in the next financial year, 1994-95.

The next point is that there is a great deal of rubberiness about what it actually costs the Civil Aviation Authority to provide this function. That is not surprising, given the managerial skills within the CAA. But the figure that comes up is around $50 million. I do not know whether that figure of $50 million is true or not; it seems very high to me. But we have no way of determining that so, for the moment, it has to rest.

What I want to talk about is where this money will go and relate it to the practical matters of one of the safety functions of the department. The particular matter I want to talk about this morning is the matter of flight plans. A flight plan is really a prospective guide to where an aeroplane is going to fly. It lists the track and certain reporting points to make along that track. It analyses the time intervals, the winds, the fuel loads; it should have listed on it the safety and navigational equipment and the number of people on board. It therefore provides a guide that enables air traffic to be managed and coordinated, and it also has a very important safety function in so far as it is a record of what the aircraft was meant to do. It is a rather detailed record.

The reason I speak on this is that on Monday, 15 November a Senate estimates committee meeting was held and several contentious points were raised in evidence. The particular point I am concerned about is evidence by Mr Brooksbank, who is described as the General Manager, Air Traffic Services; he is responsible basically for air traffic control procedures and the systems that apply.

The evidence that Mr Brooksbank gave on page E574 of the Senate Hansard of 15 November is literally quite misleading. He was asked a question by Senator Ian Macdonald in relation to an aircraft which crashed in the Blue Mountains. The gist of Senator Macdonald's question was whether or not, if the aircraft had had a flight plan filed in respect of its activities, the two survivors would have been found in time. I was not at the inquiry, unfortunately, but I came into my office when this was being held and saw Mr Brooksbank on the internal TV.

Mr Brooksbank, with quite a degree of emotion, dealt with this question—and it may have been his emotion that carried him away and confused his judgment. But it is not for me to reflect on his motives; all I can do is reflect on the facts as stated by him. I will make a statement about his evidence because it was really quite misleading to the parliament and to the Australian public. Mr Brooksbank in his reply said:

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are very simple. Firstly, they did in fact give us radio notification as they taxied at Bankstown so we knew the track and that was taped. Secondly, the parents were advised and the parents are a `responsible person'.

He then went on and finished up with a great thespian flourish of flinging his glasses down on the table and denying that anything more could have been done to save the lives of these two unfortunate people. Mr Brooksbank is quite wrong when he says, `We did know where the aircraft was going'.

PARA.TAB: I will take honourable senators through what happens at airports when an aircraft departs. It is a matter of fact that when one enters an aircraft, the first thing one does is switch on to the frequency for the ATIS, the automatic terminal information service. This gives us the active runways, the weather reports and a few other relevant points. The next call is made to ground control, and in this case the call would have been, `Bankstown ground, this is Alpha-Bravo-Charlie', and whatever the aircraft type was; `Received Delta', or whatever the call sign was for the ATIS that was current, `Taxiing for Parkes'.

The facts of life are that you cannot move off an airfield without saying what you are going to do—either going into the circuit for take-offs and landings, the training area or somewhere else. That is mandatory. The fact that this pilot called up and said he was taxiing for Parkes does not allow Mr Brooksbank to make the claim, as he emphatically did, that therefore they could draw a straight line between whatever the departure point was nominated from Bankstown and Parkes and pursue that with confidence, with a search party, as the aircraft's path. They could have flown anywhere. If I call up at Canberra this morning and say that I am taxiing for Mudgee, they do not know whether I am going out west to some place, or through Wagga, or whether I am going to track east; I could be on any path at all to get there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure it was Parkes?

—Whatever—it really does not matter. The point was that Brooksbank was quite wrong in telling that to the Senate at the time. It is a hopelessly inefficient position to be in. It is a hopelessly inefficient position for the Civil Aviation Authority to support. It is also quite wrong to say that we can get over the requirements of filing a flight plan by lodging a note with a responsible person who will then advise that if the aircraft does not arrive we have to go and look for it. That is not the way to save lives.

PARA.TAB: Time is crucial in this. If you know the track of the aircraft, the probabilities are that you will find the survivors, if there are any, more quickly. We know very well from our military experience in Korea and in Vietnam that the quicker you Medivac people out the better. In this case we had plenty of helicopters. Had they been able to find the people, the possibility of survival as a general proposition depends very much on the rapidity with which you find them and the rapidity with which you find them turns on having an accurate flight plan. That principle is an absolutely solid one in aviation.

There is another aspect to this tragic accident in the Blue Mountains which I will not develop this morning, and that is the fact that almost certainly they were flying under conditions which did not permit visual flight under the visual flight rules. That leads to another large area which I do not want to argue about this morning—the all or nothing rule of the CAA that you have to have a first-class instrument rating to cope with non-VFR conditions. But that is a separate argument.

I want to come back to this information of Brooksbank that departure notification is, in effect, a flight plan. If a pilot puts a plan in, it puts discipline on that pilot to look at what he is going to do, to work out his fuel loads and his wind and to find out whether he can actually fly the operation. It certainly helps the search and rescue enormously. We had later on in the same hearing the staggering admission that $599,000 was expended just in aircraft hire alone, without personnel, for this search.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we will never spare that effort. If people are lost we will look for them, no matter what it costs—whether they are lost at sea or in the air, just like the Rockin' Robin. Those searches are expensive.
—I am pleased to hear that. I would also ask the minister, if he had a sense of responsibility at all—
—Those searches are expensive—
—Would you shut up? For the last time, will you shut up?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I would ask for that to be withdrawn. The order in this chamber is provided by you, Mr Acting Deputy President, not by Senator MacGibbon.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Collins has incessantly interjected throughout this debate. I know that you like to allow latitude, but when this incessant interjection goes on by Senator Collins I ask that you call him to order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask for that to be withdrawn. The order is provided in here, rightly or wrongly, by the chair, not by Senator MacGibbon.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: are you going to rule? I do not believe that `shut up' is offensive. I would like you to rule on whether it is going to be a precedent or not.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. This seems to me to be a reflection on the chair and its incapacity to keep order in the chamber.
—Senator MacGibbon, Senator Collins has taken offence at your remark to him. I would ask you to withdraw. Senator Collins might help the situation by not being so provocative with his interjections.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like you to apply the standing order for persistent unruly behaviour because Senator Collins has behaved deplorably throughout this debate all morning. If it is sauce for the goose, it is sauce for the gander. I will not be talked down by unruly ministers or any unruly senator in this place.
—Senator MacGibbon, I have asked Senator Collins to be more careful with his interjections.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. You have asked Senator MacGibbon to withdraw and he has not done so.
—I was just going to refer to that. Senator Vanstone, do you wish to speak to the point of order?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to a point of order that was raised in this chamber last week, when Senator McMullan made some remarks at which Senator Patterson distinctly said she took offence. The original view of the President, who was in the chair at the time—this was during question time—was that it was just a debating point. Senator Patterson stood up and said, `It may be a debating point but I personally take offence at it'. I understand that in the past the rulings have occasionally been that if a senator on the other side or whoever it is takes offence at a remark, the appropriate thing is for it to be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: I would personally like, therefore, to support your ruling. I just ask you to consider, and perhaps give some indication of, whether the President was right last week in saying that it is bad luck if someone has taken offence; that does not apply. Senator McMullan was not made to withdraw that remark. I support the position that if a senator is offended, even if he or she is a bit thin-skinned, the polite and courteous thing to do is to withdraw it. I invite you to comment on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it depends on the circumstances at the time. I have asked Senator MacGibbon to withdraw on the basis of the offence that Senator Collins has expressed. Senator MacGibbon may not like to fall to the standards that you have highlighted that someone else fell to on a previous occasion.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, could you explain why you are prepared to apply one standing order here, yet you would not apply the standing order that interjections are unruly against the offending minister?
—I have asked Senator Collins to abstain from unruly interjections and he has agreed that he will do that.

—On that basis and on the basis that that applies in the future on all occasions when I am speaking, I will withdraw. I want to get back to this business of the $599,000 that was spent on the search. Arguably, had there been an accurate flight plan and had the department known the track of the aircraft, it would not have been necessary to spend anywhere near that amount of money, which comes from the taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: A few weeks ago I made a very good speech in this place on flight plans. It was very well received by the aviation community. I had people ringing me up from all around Australia, thanking me for saying it. I do not resile from anything I said at the time. I want to expand on that slightly. It was the subject of a rather bitter and ill-informed attack by the minister, but I will let that pass. It is important that people plan a flight. I do not want to see a situation where flight plans are made mandatory; it should be left to the discretion of the pilot in command. But there are a number of circumstances where it is very good policy to plan. We have to get away from the business of the department not encouraging people to plan, of telling them that it costs $150 to put a plan in at the time.

We have a system which works, but it is an awkward system. Two weekends ago I flew 17 1/2 hours, mainly around western New South Wales. I used the facilities. I say that I had no difficulty with them in any way at all, but I do recognise that it is an awkward system. Essentially, the only way you can get weather information and the only way one can file a plan is to use a fax or to use a phone and dial a 008 number. I said in my previous speech that sometimes one cannot get through. A commercial pilot of great experience phoned me up after I made that last speech and said, `I have been held on occasions for an hour and a half trying to get through'. There are only two outlets, one in Brisbane and one in Melbourne, that answer these calls. But that is a minor deficiency. I am happy with the present system but it needs supplementation.

We get to the business of getting weather briefings. We have a system known as Dectalk, where there is a synthesised voice from a computer that makes the answers. That voice is in an American accent and it is a slurred, drunken voice at times. At times it is quite indistinct. For Australians who have not lived in the United States and who are not familiar with the American intonations and inflection, it can be misleading.

I have lived in America for quite a bit of my life. Last weekend I was going to go to Rockhampton. I did not go in the end, but I made a number of calls getting weather reports on this Dectalk system. The announcer, in this slurred diction, was saying what sounded like `north of a line from Gympie to Tiaro'. It was only after I replayed it for the third or fourth time that I realised he was saying `Tara'. Tara is west of Gympie, and that is in zone 4D. I do not see why Dectalk cannot be the same as the ATIS. Why cannot the staff of the CAA do the automatic recording every time a fresh forecast comes in, because there are not that many regions in Australia?

The difficulty is that a pilot really needs to have a fax if the system is going to be accessed properly. It is all very well for Senator Collins to say that a second-hand fax costs only $300, but a lot of pilots do not have them. His comparison of $300 against $50,000 for an aircraft is quite meaningless because, for every pilot who owns an aircraft, probably 50 or 100 pilots do not own aeroplanes; the majority of pilots do not own them. I cannot lug around a fax if I am touring western New South Wales in my little aeroplane; it is just not practical.

There is another element to this matter. One of the most experienced instructors in Australia, who does a lot of long distance flying with his students and who holds all licences as an ATO—a testing officer—et cetera, phoned me after my speech and said, `I often go to Coolangatta. With students, I want the hard copy of weather reports and NOTAMs. I want to be able to lodge a plan. I cannot do that at Coolangatta because there is no public terminal facility there'. We need to put in a supplementary system. We need something like the automatic tellers in the banking system. We need a system where a dollar can be put in and a NOTAM or a weather report dispensed or a plan filed. That could exist at the larger airports around Australia.

The other huge deficiency in the present system is the absence of any position reporting system. (Extension of time granted) The essential thing about the flight plans at the moment is that position reporting cannot be done. The old system of full radio has been abandoned. In bygone times, there were two ways of filing a flight plan: either full radio or position reporting. Full radio was similar to what the airlines used. There were designated reporting points and a pilot had to call up within a minute or two minutes of reaching a point. For a private pilot without the sophisticated navaids of the airlines, that involved a fair bit of strain; it is fair enough for the airlines, but it imposed difficulties for others. I have no difficulty with the abolition of full radio reporting for private VFR traffic. I have done a fair bit of it in the past, but I do not regret its passing. The present system whereby a pilot does not have to report—a SAR time is nominated—is really quite meaningless. I cannot understand how any experienced airman in the Civil Aviation Authority agreed to its implementation.

I return to my experiences of two weekends ago. I flew from Archerfield to the western part of the Victorian-New South Wales border. I put a lot of time into planning it beforehand, with charts and ERSA. I spent quite a bit of time preparing the aircraft and making sure that everything was quite right. When I had done all that, I spent over an hour going to a very good flying instructor, paying money and going meticulously through all my air traffic control procedures. The whole weekend went without a moment's hesitation, difficulty or embarrassment anywhere along the line. The system worked. It reflected the work that was put in beforehand. But that is just normal airmanship; one should do things like that.

The track I flew followed Archerfield, Armidale, Dubbo, Griffith to the Victorian border. I came back from the Victorian border through Canberra, Mudgee, Armidale and Archerfield. If I had gone missing and not reported on SAR time, I could have been anywhere on that leg between Archerfield and the Victorian border. There is now no provision to make a position report in flight. To state it as baldly as that demonstrates the stupidity of the system we have. It really is quite inexcusable.

A subterfuge has to be used. There are different radio frequencies for different areas. I called over Gibraltar, which is a navaid in the northern part of the New England tablelands area. I reported to Sydney: `Sydney, this is Alpha Kilo Whiskey'. The air traffic controller said, `Alpha Kilo Whisky, go ahead. This is Sydney'. I said, `Sydney, this is Alpha Kilo Whisky overhead Gibraltar this time, tracking Armidale. Request area QNH'. That goes on the tape. There is no acknowledgment of it as a position report. The controllers are obliged to give me the area QNH, which is the altimeter setting for that region. It is by using subterfuges like that that pilots now record their position around Australia.

If I do not report in at SAR time, they will go back and listen to all the tapes for the regions through which I was flying. They will find these entries sequentially along the track and be able to derive from them where I got to. But that is wrong. It may not be necessary to designate a staff member to plot every individual flight in Australia, but surely it should be possible for us to say, `This is Alpha Bravo Charlie overhead Gunnedah this time, estimating Coonabarabran 26, operations normal', or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is stopping you?

—The air traffic controllers simply do not like it. It might not be a matter of policy, but they will tell to you to stop the chatter. I have never tried it myself. I have relied on a large number of instructors who have told me that. Let us fix up the system. Finally, the minister said in his speech that he had accessed the AVFAX system.
—I have. I have the print-out.
—That is pretty good. Does he have an AVFAX account number and pin number? Unless he has both a registered account number and a pin number, he cannot get in. If he has one, good luck to him.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to making the system work. It is not working well at the moment. Most of the changes I have proposed will cost very little if they are efficiently administered. We should have flight plans and encourage people to make them. We should not make it mandatory. We have to expand the present system by providing automatic tellers—

TALK.START.PARA: —And sober Australian voices.

—Yes. Let us have some Australian voices who speak the way we speak around here. For goodness' sake, let us have some position reporting for the huge amount of money we are now putting into the Civil Aviation Authority through our levies. I have not totalled up the bill for the trip of 17 1/2 hours, but it probably cost somewhere around $500 or $600 in fuel. I am spending a lot of money to support this system. I do not mind doing that if the dammed thing works.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. I indicate to Senator MacGibbon that, although the Senate extended him the courtesy of an extension of time, it was not on the basis of lost time during the points of order, because the clock was suspended when those points of order were being considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that Senator Ian Macdonald could get so extraordinarily irritated at what he alleges are the personal anecdotes I tell, yet he can sit in total silence for 20 minutes of personal anecdotes from Senator MacGibbon.
—His are informed.

—We will address that now. Despite the false assertions of Senator Macdonald, I have before drawn attention to the fact that I am not a professional pilot or engineer. I have described myself—Senator Macdonald knows this—as a professional passenger. I do respect the fact that Senator MacGibbon is not only a pilot but an experienced pilot of many years standing. On every occasion that someone in the industry—Senator MacGibbon is in the industry; that is acknowledged by people in it—be it Dick Smith, Senator MacGibbon or anyone else, has raised a concern about air safety, I have followed it up with the relevant authorities, which is usually both the CAA and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

PARA.TAB: The reason I make that point is that Senator Macdonald again made a number of totally unsubstantiated assertions in his address this morning and provided absolutely no detail whatsoever. It was a dreadful exercise in unspecific scaremongering. As I have advised the Senate estimates committee before, as a member of parliament, not as a minister, I have never failed to go to the authorities when any individuals—passengers, pilots or anyone else—have brought a matter to me. As Senator Macdonald knows, the CAIR system has been established for that very purpose by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. It guarantees the anonymity of an informant. In fact, officers from BASI gave Senator Macdonald direct evidence on it.

I told that committee, and I will tell this Senate, of one occasion concerning an operator in the Northern Territory which involved multiple engine failure that turned out to be through crankshafts being incorrectly ground at an uncertified works. I have received complaints from passengers on board flights where there has been an engine failure. On three occasions I have been on aircraft that have had engine failures. It is disconcerting for the passengers. The officer who had followed it up was at the table at that estimates committee.

On each occasion, I can attest that the CAA has scrupulously investigated every claim to the point—this is what annoys me about these things; I gave evidence to the committee on this basis—that complaints are then made against the CAA about harassment when it follows up these complaints. In the case of this operator in the Northern Territory that is precisely what happened, to the point where I got a letter from a Northern Territory government minister making representations to me about the unfair harassment by the CAA of this operator who had had two engine failures in aircraft in his fleet, both caused by crankshaft failure. The CAA is hiding nothing in this area. It is accused of failure to provide sufficient scrutiny. When it provides that scrutiny—in my experience, from the complaints I have taken to it, it always has provided it—it is hounded for harassing people.

In my portfolio I take safety more seriously than any other matter, whether maritime safety, road safety or air safety. I have personally followed up with the authorities every complaint I have ever got about poor maintenance or about incidents in the air, as is the case with what recently happened near Groote Eylandt in the Northern Territory. I am going to take the trouble today to contact the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and to check whether Senator Macdonald has taken any of the concerns—as non-specific as they were—to the CARE service, which he knows exist. I was present in the room when he was told about it weeks ago. I will not be at all surprised to find that he has not been near BASI or the CAA with any of these complaints. That is why I consider his behaviour to be irresponsible.

I turn to a matter which Senator Coulter might be interested in hearing about. I was fascinated to hear both Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator MacGibbon on the question of why the government should pay rather than the industry. I thought I must have been campaigning in a different election. I refer to the coalition's policy on aviation which Senator Macdonald and Senator MacGibbon took to the people at the last election. To the best of my knowledge—I am sure that I am not wrong—it is the coalition's current, published policy, still in print and unchanged, with respect to the Civil Aviation Authority. I ask honourable senators to compare what Senator Macdonald and Senator MacGibbon have said during this debate with this policy:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition in government will move to privatise or contract out those functions—
of the CAA—
that can be best undertaken by the industry itself or by private enterprise.

On the question of cost recovery, I refer to the astonishing contributions made this morning by both of those honourable senators and to the policy they both supported and took to the last election—it is only a short time ago—which is contained in the Fightback document. As well as the coalition not agreeing with the staged process of gradual cost recovery that we envisaged over a number of years, Fightback states:
The Government announced in the 1990-91 Budget its intention to phase in full cost recovery for air safety activity from 1 November 1992. In the 1991-92 Budget this decision was reversed—
which it was—
so that cost recovery would only start to phase in from 1 November 1992.
Since then we have progressed it a bit further and clawed 50 per cent of it back, of which the industry is extremely appreciative. The Fightback document goes on to state:
The Coalition will implement full recovery for air safety activities forthwith, saving $20 million.

The coalition parties went to the last election wanting to privatise the CAA and fully cost recover—with no staging—the total cost of safety regulation. The coalition came in here this morning and said what a terrible thing it is that the government is going to get 50 per cent of it back and that we should be paying the whole lot. That kind of credibility gap has to be exposed.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the appalling statements that were made about the accident involving the tragic loss of life of two young men. The careless and inaccurate statements that Senator MacGibbon made in relation to this matter really do need to be addressed. Senator MacGibbon implied that the CAA was responsible for the loss of the two lives in this accident because of the lack of flight plans. He has just reasserted—and I agree with him—that it should not be compulsory to lodge flight plans. That compulsion was removed in 1978. That is how long the existing arrangements have been in place. As Senator MacGibbon knows, the industry wanted that arrangement. This is what Senator MacGibbon said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is a reasonable proposition that . . . they might well have been alive today if they had been found promptly.

Senator MacGibbon then linked this comment with a question as to why there was no flight plan. I said at the time, and I say again, that it was a disgraceful implication by Senator MacGibbon which cannot be allowed to stand.

PARA.TAB: The CAA search was based on the information which the pilot left which indicated the track on which the aircraft would be flying. Senator MacGibbon knows that. The extensive search involved over 50 helicopters and fixed wing aircraft—and that will always be laid on, regardless of cost. As Senator MacGibbon also knows, as a result of flying on each side of that track, search aircraft actually went directly above the aircraft, but because it crashed through a dense canopy—it was a light aircraft, a small aircraft—it could not be seen from the air. It was found in a ground search for that reason. Senator MacGibbon knows that too. So in respect of this particular accident, it is outrageous to say that if a flight plan had been lodged, these two lives could have been saved.

Further to that, Senator MacGibbon also knows that the plane was carrying an emergency beacon which, unfortunately, was destroyed on impact. That even happens, I am afraid to say, with a percentage of the highly engineered black boxes in big jet aircraft. Some years ago the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation spent several hours briefing me on the engineering of those boxes. I examined them and saw some damage to the foil strips inside those boxes. It was explained to me that it is almost impossible to engineer them to the stage where they can survive every impact. That is even more the case with what needs to be a reasonably small and reasonably light beacon and, I might add, an affordable beacon, in a light aircraft. Unfortunately, although the aircraft involved in this accident was carrying one, it was destroyed on impact. Senator MacGibbon knows all of that too.

Senator MacGibbon would do well to stop making these allegations without having some regard to the facts and without awaiting the results of the investigation of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. Unfortunately, these assertions were made again recently at a Senate estimates committee hearing. They were rightly corrected by the officers present. I do not blame Mr Brooksbank, who was involved in that search, for getting a bit emotional about these totally irresponsible statements.

I turn to the matter of flight plans. I agree with most of what Senator MacGibbon says most of the time—and I certainly agree with his final statement this morning about flight plans. I think people can distil, from the comments he made to me about air traffic controllers telling people to stop the chatter, that he has confirmed what the CAA has said. His original assertion that a pilot has to rely on subterfuge to lodge a position report is not correct. I am advised by the CAA that it is not correct. Dick Smith told me—and he is right, because I checked it, not being a pilot—that Senator MacGibbon's assertion in here a few weeks ago that one has to use a fax to lodge a flight plan is complete nonsense. I notice that Senator MacGibbon has withdrawn from that today, but look at the Hansard. A 008 number can be used, and one can also radio in a flight plan at any time—to quote Dick Smith—by pushing a button in the aircraft.

I respect Dick Smith's experience in the air equally with Senator MacGibbon's. Dick Smith said to me that it was a shame that, on that particular occasion, when they were faced with that decision, the pilots did not make a flight plan. I do not think Senator MacGibbon would disagree with me when I say that, from my experience as a professional passenger sitting in that right-hand seat, you cannot depend on the air traffic controllers or the CAA on the ground 500 kilometres behind in Darwin when you are running into storm conditions across Arnhem Land. You have to depend on the professional judgment of that person sitting in the left-hand seat. It is that person's judgment as to whether to continue in weather conditions that you should not be flying in or whether to turn back, which has happened on many occasions, and I am always happy to leave that decision in the hands of the pilot; or, and Dick Smith made this point to me, if a flight plan has not been lodged, one can be lodged immediately as a precautionary measure.

If pilots decide to fly on into bad weather and they think they might get into a bit of trouble, Dick said to me, `They can turn back'—which is what they should do—`or they can fly on if they wish. But if they fly on, they can pick up the radio and lodge a flight plan at that point in flight'. In other words, they can record their position with the CAA. They can do that.

I am advised by the CAA—and that is why I accessed the system myself—that it is easier now by a country mile to lodge flight plans and get flight information than it ever was in the past. Senator MacGibbon talked about tracking around in the back blocks of New South Wales as if there was, under previous arrangements, a briefing office at every airport around Australia. Of course there was not. As has just been pointed out to me by my adviser, if one was wondering around in the back blocks of New South Wales 20 years ago, one would had to have lodged a flight plan by telephone, as is the case now; or, as is usually the case, and I would like Senator MacGibbon to tell me that I am wrong, at least with the pilots I fly with in those isolated areas, they lodge their flight plans from the aircraft over the radio. I have sat next to them and listened to them enough to know that that is the case.

So the information Senator MacGibbon provided to the Senate with this air of authority, as is often the case, was flatly wrong again. The Hansard will show that Senator MacGibbon protested when I corrected him and said I had checked the facts. He told us that there were only two operators operating this system and that there were huge delays. I said that I had checked the situation and had found that there were 16 operators, not two. Senator MacGibbon then said, `Oh, I didn't say two operators; I said two centres.' I tabled the extract from the Hansard immediately after that debate.

The Hansard showed correctly that Senator MacGibbon had said two operators, not two centres. That is the problem with the information Senator MacGibbon gives the Senate time and again with this air of authority. When one checks out the facts, his facts turn out to be wrong. The facts are that all pilots, including private pilots, are able to file a flight plan, it is easy to do so, and the CAA regulations encourage them to do so. Senator MacGibbon knows that.

There was one point Senator MacGibbon made this morning that deserves to be highlighted and emphasised. Senator MacGibbon said that pilots should plan their flights. So they should. Any responsible pilot should do that. It would assist air safety enormously. The problem is that there are too many occasions when young, particularly inexperienced, pilots treat the aircraft like a Holden ute and jump in and go. They do not sit down and plan their flights. I agree with Senator MacGibbon in that regard. I agree with him that we should not go back to making it mandatory to lodge flight plans because that would clog the system to death and take us back to where we were prior to 1978. The industry does not want that, as Senator MacGibbon said correctly. But, at the same time, pilots should plan their flights. A lot of these problems would be alleviated if they did.

These services are operated by 16 operators rather than two, as suggested by Senator MacGibbon. I tried the service out myself. Senator MacGibbon asserted that two people had to cover the whole of Australia and that people had to wait for hours. I accessed the system in five seconds and in under five minutes I had a complete hard copy print-out of all the information I needed to plan my flight. When I accessed the 008 number, I was told by the operator that pilots love the system. This operator, who has been with the CAA for 20 years, told me that under the old system, even when the CAA had briefing centres, 80 per cent of pilots got their flight information over the phone. I am sure Senator MacGibbon knows that is correct. This operator said that what the CAA does now with this automatic system is provide a hard copy of the information whenever the pilots want it. It can be provided hours before the flight if they want it and this is without going near a briefing office. He said, `They love the new system.'

The operator said that he personally had only one regret about the new system. I asked him what that was and he said, `I am operating a system'—in other words looking after a computer bank—`that formerly 200 people were employed to operate under the previous system.' Again, as Senator MacGibbon knows, because of these chiefly technologically driven changes the CAA—this incompetent management referred to by Senator MacGibbon—in the current restructuring passed on to the aviation industry in Australia, because of cost reductions in the last two years, which is a very rare event these days, some $200 million.

In respect of flight plans, the pilot has a number of options to comply with the regulations. As Senator MacGibbon knows, those regulations require all pilots to obtain all necessary meteorological and operational information and to plan the flight prior to making the flight. That is what the regulations impose on pilots. The pilot can submit full flight details. The CAA's aeronautical information publication provides clear guidance that `pilots not formally required to submit flight notification are nevertheless encouraged to leave a flight note.'

Senator MacGibbon bemoaned the loss of the briefing services previously provided at airfields. What he failed to mention was that the majority of the briefing services—and I have been advised by the people who provide them—were still provided by telephone without the benefit of being able to follow the information through to the pilot with a hard copy, as can now be provided by fax. The pilot has the information in front of him without having to write it down over the phone. The CAA has two central briefing offices. Each has a number of staff to provide briefings by telephone and to accept flight details. The pilot can choose to put it over the radio from his aircraft if he wants to. I would like honourable senators to compare those facts with the alleged facts put to the Senate by Senator MacGibbon. The Hansard will show those facts.

Senator MacGibbon also complained about the CAA getting rid of the visual flight guides. What he forgot to tell the Senate was that it was the aviation industry that asked the CAA to do that. That was a reasonable piece of information that Senator MacGibbon could have provided.

The last thing I would like to address is Senator MacGibbon's assertion that `the CAA will take people to court at the drop of a hat.' I would like to provide Senator MacGibbon with the information that was available over the last 12 months, because I chased it up. There are 36,000 active pilots in Australia. In the 12 months ending September 1993, there were 28 prosecutions. That is hardly evidence of an organisation that will take people to court at the drop of a hat.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 191, I refuse to let the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) misquote or deliberately misunderstand my speech. Under standing order 191, I want to be heard to explain a material part of my speech. The Minister again, as is his wont, misrepresented or misquoted—and I will not say deliberately because it may be offensive—either unwittingly or wilfully, my speech. He is calling upon me to go to BASI with these problems I have about air safety. The matters I mentioned in my speech are past incidents. One related to Monarch Airlines.
—That is irrelevant. The incidents I reported are past incidents. If they are not past incidents how do you report them? How do you report them before they happen?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Minister, can we have some order, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We had a very unpleasant incident here about half an hour ago where we had very unruly behaviour from the Minister which was not checked by the Chair. I hope we are not going through that procedure again. We had an undertaking from Senator Collins that he would behave.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Not only did the Acting Deputy President, on encouragement from Senator MacGibbon and myself, order Senator Collins to be quiet and not interject, but Senator Collins gave an undertaking to the Senate that during the course of this debate he would not interject. He has now broken that promise on several occasions. I ask you to bring him to order.
—Order! There is no point of order. However, I would appreciate it if both sides would cease injecting. Senator Macdonald, if you have a personal explanation to make, please proceed.

—I mentioned three incidents in my speech all relating to past incidents. The first matter that I mentioned related to Monarch Airlines, which is now out of business. I am not quite sure what I can report to BASI about that. I simply said that airworthiness investigators wanted to remove Monarch's air operator certificates some months ago. If that is news to BASI, I can report it. I do not know what it can do about it because the company is now out of business.

PARA.TAB: The second matter that I mentioned also happened many months ago when I mentioned a commuter airline at Wagga Wagga. Again, the airworthiness inspectors wanted to remove its certificate. They reported it to the CAA administration but nothing was done. Since that time, that particular airline has also gone into liquidation and is no longer operating. If BASI does not know about that, I will certainly report it. But I am not sure what BASI can do about it when that airline has gone out of business.

The third matter that I mentioned was an Eastern Airlines commuter aircraft—a Dash 8—that was travelling out of the New England tablelands area of New South Wales last week when it had a serious problem. BASI would be aware of that. If it is not, heaven help our system. But if BASI is not aware of that, I will certainly pass on the details of that incident that I have. But I am informed that these matters have been reported. I suspect, only I will not say specifically in the last instance, that they have also been reported to Senator Collins. If Senator Collins wants me, as he misrepresented in his speech, to say that those sorts of things are things that BASI can do something about, I am quite happy to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have not done it.
—Madam Deputy President, if BASI is not aware of those things, I will certainly report it or perhaps Senator Collins or his large staff, who follow these sorts of areas, can pass that on.

PARA.TAB: The other matter that I should correct is that my staff pointed out to me that I incorrectly said that Senator Collins was a failure as the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales. Of course, he was a failure as the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ian Macdonald, it is inappropriate to reflect upon people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the same standing order, I wish to make a brief personal explanation as I claim to have been grossly misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is a reasonable proposition that, since they survived the crash, they might well have been alive today if they had been found promptly. I stress that I do not know their condition after the crash—how badly injured they were—and it may well have been so bad that, even if they had been picked up by a helicopter immediately afterwards, they would not have survived.

Today I was trying to argue the obvious case that the sooner one is found the higher one's chances of survival. If I inadvertently created the impression in the Senate, through all the uproar of interjections, that I was attributing a direct cause and effect to the Blue Mountain incident, I apologise for that and I unreservedly withdraw it. But I do not resile from the general proposition that the sooner we find survivors the better their chance of survival.

PARA.TAB: We also had a great diatribe about briefing officers. I have had a look at my speech of 28 October where I referred to briefing officers. In both the briefing officer case and the VFG, I did not say that I wanted those re-established. I was establishing the situation out there in the real world where these services have been withdrawn and there is no compensatory service put in place.

I think it is deplorable that there is no reference document that is meaningful for the average pilot. I never knew that it was the industry's request that the VFG be withdrawn. I am disappointed at that but then in regard to the GA sector—the broad group of pilots who form the majority of pilots in Australia—it has no effective voice at all in negotiating with government. Its representation is presumably through AOPA and diluted through the membership of much wider committees, so I am not surprised that these things happen.

I am not arguing for the return of briefing officers. I am arguing for the return of VFGs because there simply is no other way of a pilot's knowing. The two documents that we have at present—the AIP and the RACOPS books—are very inadequate and very incomplete. The reality is that the average pilot finds them quite incomprehensible.

The final point that I want to make is about filing plans. We have the very difficult situation now where the CAA is believed by the industry to be at war with it. As for all this business that the great majority of plans were always put in by telephone to briefing officers, I do not know about that. All I know is that in my home field of Archerfield there are between 11 and 14 briefing officers in the briefing office at the weekends—which I always thought was excessive, but they were certainly going flat out. I would have often rung up and got a weather forecast before I went to the field so that I could do my flight planning in the comfort of my own desk at home and save time at the airport. I would be interested in the statistics. If he has hard copy statistics of those who phone in, that is fine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are ranging fairly widely. I would appreciate if you could state where you have been misrepresented and correct that, please.
