TALK.START.PARA: —The Childcare Rebate Bill seeks to provide for the payment of rebate for expenses incurred for work-related child care. Over the last 10 years the provision of suitable child care has become an increasingly important issue for Australians. To a large extent, this growing importance can be attributed to the growth in female employment and particularly to the growth in employment amongst married women.

PARA.TAB: A recently released report on women's employment stated that between June 1983 and June 1993 the total number of employed females increased by over 925,000, or by around 40 per cent. It also confirms that, until recently, the participation rate for married females was lower than the rate for unmarried females. However, with the significant growth in the number of married women in the labour force in the last decade, the participation rate for married females began to exceed the rate for not married females for the first time in 1990.

Currently the federal government subsidises around 208,000 child-care places in Australia and has promised to meet all demand for work-related child care by the year 2001. Given the ALP's track record in relation to child care, I have grave doubts that this promise will be delivered. In the last ABS child-care survey, completed in 1990, unmet demand for formal child care in Australia had grown by over 112 per cent in just over three years.

Over the years I have seen many of this Labor government's promises either dumped after the heat of an election or simply never realised. In the 1988 election campaign Labor promised to create 30,000 child-care places by mid-1992. The target was not met. I can recall that in 1990 the Labor government, in a last minute vote grabbing promise, stated that it would create 50,000 new child-care places by mid-1995. Three years after the promise was made not one of those places has been created. Almost every Australian will remember the now famous, or infamous, promise that Bob Hawke made in 1987 that `no child would live in poverty by 1990'. I suppose it is no wonder that I am sceptical about the promises that this government makes.

At the last election the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that the ALP would be spending $626.7 million over four years on a package of child-care measures. One of the key measures of this package announced by the Prime Minister was the introduction of a child-care cash rebate. As one journalist noted at the time of its announcement back in February of this year, the measure was carefully designed to ferret out 145,000 upper middle class women who received no government assistance or tax relief for child care.

It was a blatant and obvious measure designed to buy votes. It had nothing to do with equity or genuine concern by the Labor government to extend child-care places and services to those most in need. It was simply another slick election promise, presumably penned by Dr Anne Summers, brought out at great expense to the Australian public, and mouthed by Mr Paul Keating for the purposes of the election.

The Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 is evidence of the wooing of the women's vote. The government bought women's votes like it bought the pensioner vote. It claimed pensioners would be taken out of the tax system and then, after the election, they were dumped. It was just another way of fooling the Australian public about what it was going to do, and it did not do it with pensioners. This is another attempt to woo the women's vote.

Under the bill the child-care cash rebate will be available from July 1994 for parents using child-care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work. It will be paid fortnightly through Medicare offices in person or by mail and, unfortunately, as far as we are concerned, it will not be means tested. The child-care cash rebate will allow families to claim up to 30 per cent of child-care costs after the first $16, up to a ceiling of $110 per week for one child in care or $220 per week for two or more children in care. The maximum rebate will be $28.20 per week for one child and $61.20 per week for two or more children. Availability for the rebate will extend to both formal and informal care and it will be paid for child-care expenses for children up to 12 years of age.

In the past the federal government has opposed tax rebates for child-care expenses for working families, claiming that they benefit those on higher incomes more than lower paid workers or those looking for work. Ironically, under this bill, those families currently receiving little or no child-care assistance will benefit from the system. In particular, two income families enjoying relatively high incomes will benefit the most. Accordingly, the coalition has very real concerns about the fairness of the new rebate. In our current economic climate, it is simply irresponsible for this Labor government to assist high income earners at the expense of those who are not so well off. While the coalition recognises that child care is a legitimate work related expense, for reasons of equity and fairness we would like to see a capped rebate.

Under our child-care policy at the last election we proposed that, for families with combined incomes of $50,000 or $60,000, our child-care cash rebate would be progressively withdrawn so that no rebate would be payable to families with incomes exceeding $60,000 per annum. In this way we would have directed limited government resources to those in most need instead of pursuing this ridiculous child care for millionaires scheme. In view of this we are proposing an amendment to the bill to cap the payment of the rebate to the level provided for in our election policy.

It is interesting to note that our concern about the equity of the scheme was not lost on all members of the Labor government. Prior to the budget, it was reported that the federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) wanted to ditch the cash rebate to higher income earners. However, the issue of equity is not the only concern the coalition has regarding the introduction of the child-care cash rebate. We have also expressed grave reservations about the privacy implications of the rebate scheme.

Honourable senators will recall that the coalition expressed its concerns about the privacy implications when the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993 was debated in this place in May of this year. The coalition was concerned that, while providing the machinery to enable payments of the cash rebate through direct payments from Medicare offices, the bill left it open as to what administrative system the HIC would develop for the scheme.

We were particularly concerned that tax file numbers could be required by the HIC and passed on to the Australian Taxation Office for checking purposes. This would have meant that, for the first time, a government agency would hold both Medicare and tax information.

We were reminded of another promise by Paul Keating that was broken when he introduced the tax file number. He said it would never be used or extended for any other purpose. We then saw the slippery slope where it was extended for the use of checking for overpayments in the social security system. It is yet another promise that the government chose to break: people did not like the Australia Card, so the government brought in a tax file number and just extended it a bit further; it slimily introduced something that it told the public it was not going to introduce.That is typical of this government. Australians should have learnt by now that what the Labor Party says before an election is not really what it means.

Despite the assurances before and after the election that tax file numbers would not be linked to the child-care cash rebate scheme, in May the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) would not categorically rule out the prospect that they would be used in the new scheme. She was asked this over and over again. Instead, she said that the coalition's views would be taken into consideration and that various options for the implementation of the scheme were being explored by the government.

Both Senator Newman and I were concerned by this statement. It is significant that we were not alone in our concerns. Both the Privacy Commissioner and the Australian Privacy Foundation expressed concerns about the possibility of tax file numbers being used in the administration of the system. Again I remind honourable senators and other people that, when Paul Keating was Treasurer, he said that the tax file number would not be extended for any purpose other than that of the Australian Taxation Office. We know that that is not true because it was extended to social security.

I am pleased to see that in designing the new child-care cash rebate scheme, the minister and the government have actually listened to the concerns of the coalition, the Privacy Commissioner and the privacy lobby. The Childcare Rebate Bill requires neither child-care providers nor child-care users to supply their tax file numbers to the Health Insurance Commission. The bill requires child-care providers to register with the Health Insurance Commission as registered carers and to state that they have a tax file number. In turn, the Health Insurance Commission will provide a carer with a child-care provider number, which will appear on child-care receipts. Under the scheme, the Health Insurance Commission may ask the Commissioner of Taxation whether a carer has a tax file number. However, it is not allowed to know what the number is, nor may it provide the child-care provider number to the Commissioner of Taxation.

While the coalition's concerns have been largely addressed, we note that the Office of the Privacy Commissioner has expressed some reservations about the further extension of the use of the tax file number and about the fact that the bill moves away from the voluntary disclosure of tax file numbers. As I say, we note these concerns and we will be monitoring the operation of the scheme very closely in this regard.

Although the government's child-care accreditation scheme will be debated in this place at a later date, I would also like to raise it in the context of debate on this bill. I am extremely concerned that the introduction of the government's accreditation system will increase the price of child care in long-day care centres. This will drive some low income families into the informal sector where they will lose their child-care assistance. At the same time, as a result of the introduction of the child-care cash rebate, high income families will be able to claim a child-care cash rebate in the same way as the low income family which has been pushed out of the formal sector.

Apart from being inequitable, this raises an obvious inconsistency. While the government is promoting the ideal of high quality child care through its accreditation scheme, it is forcing more families into the informal sector. It is also significant that peak organisations representing around 60 per cent of the long-day care sector have voted to boycott the government's accreditation system. If this happens, and they refuse to join the system, it will cause chaos in the child-care industry.

Another concern of the coalition is the possibility of double dipping under the scheme proposed in the bill. A loophole appears to exist whereby it might be possible, in the situation where a child is a dependant of more than one family, for two families to split child-care expenses, resulting in a total benefit for one child in excess of the maximum rebate. While it is not envisaged that this will occur to any great extent, it is possible under the provisions of the bill.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills further raised concerns with the provisions in the bill dealing with false or misleading statements used in connection with a claim for a rebate. It was alarmed that there had been an inappropriate onus of proof standard used in the bill. The government has now addressed those concerns in the amendment the minister will be moving to clause 60 of the bill.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to an article by Paddy McGuinness in the Australian of 23 April last, when he said, very presciently, in the wake of the government delivering on its promise to Conrad Black:

QUESTION.PARA: Keating and the NSW Labor right give nothing for nothing. What the price was we will only discover gradually. For a start it would be advisable to inspect carefully every senior editorial and managerial appointment to the Fairfax group from now on, and inquire regarding each one just how close he or she is to the Keating camp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the bloke who writes for the opposition?

—This is the bloke Keating called the cane toad—the bloke who can make balanced judgments. Was the appointment, announced the very next day, of Dr Anne Summers, formerly the Prime Minister's women's adviser, to edit the Sydney Morning Herald Good Weekend magazine part of the quid pro quo that Paddy McGuinness was talking about? Why was Kerry Stokes wrong when he said this morning that the Prime Minister had no right to say what is balanced political coverage and that he should be censured?

—The imputation against Anne Summers on her appointment to the editorship of the SMH's Good Weekend magazine is a slur on the professional integrity of Ms Summers which Senator Alston ought to be comprehensively ashamed of himself for making, because it is absolutely absurd to suggest that someone like Ms Summers is an inappropriate appointee for a position of that kind. On any conceivable criterion of editorial experience or standing in the journalistic and professional community, and general experience of a wide range of relevant occupations, she was obviously an ideal appointee who would meet any objective criteria.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is yet another example of Senator Alston employing his famous—notorious, I should say, rather than famous—trawling technique of juxtaposing events which have no relationship with one another, drawing imputations which have no justification, and generally behaving like a snivelling, sleazy slimebag. He ought to be ashamed of himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The words are unparliamentary. I ask that they be withdrawn.
—I withdraw.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. It is hard to take offence any more from someone who does not really know the difference between right and wrong. Nonetheless, putting aside that little distractionary diatribe, I ask: why is Kerry Strokes wrong when he says that the Prime Minister has no right at all to be in the business of making judgments about balanced coverage, and why should the Prime Minister not be censured?

—He is wrong because he is proceeding on the wrong premise—as is Senator Alston—namely, that decisions about the extent of the ownership were contingent upon prime ministerial judgments of that kind, and nothing else. The point, as has been amply explained over and again, is that the decision about foreign ownership was made, essentially, on the basis of the judgment about commercial, managerial, financial and economic needs.

PARA.TAB: Of course Mr Keating took the opportunity of that conversation to make a point in favour of balanced, responsible, professional journalistic coverage. That point was one which was well made and about which no explanation or apology is needed, particularly since exactly the same kind of conversation was, on all the available evidence we have at the moment, conducted between Dr Hewson himself and Mr Black immediately before the conversation with the Prime Minister took place.

The only evidence those opposite have of the conversation that took place between Mr Black and Mr Keating, as to the text of it, as to the substance of it, as to the shape, direction and the motive of it, is that from Mr Black himself. Mr Black has made it abundantly clear that there was nothing in what was said that was in any way different from what Dr Hewson himself said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to reports of action apparently taken in the United States which has served to interrupt Australian aid to Vietnam. I ask: what is the government doing to reverse the recent reported action by the US Department of Treasury to freeze money belonging to the Fred Hollows Foundation? What is the minister's view of such regrettable intervention?

—As honourable senators would have seen, there was a story in the Canberra Times this morning that the US Department of Treasury has frozen $US18,000, or $A27,300, from the Fred Hollows Foundation because it says the company from which the foundation bought intra-ocular lenses broke the US trade embargo with Vietnam. This is a fairly extraordinary state of affairs. We are urgently looking into it through our embassy in Washington in the hope of quickly being able to correct this situation in the event that the story is accurate. We would of course be extremely concerned if the enormously valuable work of the Hollows Foundation were being undermined in this way. I am certainly happy to report back to the Senate as soon as possible on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I make the further point that it is particularly incongruous that the Vietnam embargo should be applied in this way, if indeed it was, not only because of the obvious humanitarian context in which we are talking in this instance, but also because of course that embargo itself is manifestly on the way out, as it should have been some time ago, in the context of the very changed environment that exists in Vietnam. It is ironic indeed that, at a time when the United States itself is winding back the previous barriers that it has placed on its relationship with Vietnam, one of the remaining barriers should apparently be capable of application in this way. It is just another demonstration of the extent to which barriers of this kind in this day and age simply have no place and I hope the United States will make a policy judgment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The minister will be aware that Estimates Committee A, on the vote of Labor senators, decided not to reopen the hearings into the staffing arrangements at the Lodge. I ask the minister—
—Getting on to the big issues?

—I would have thought Labor people would be worried about two people who have been sacked like this. Will the government reconsider its decision and call an independent inquiry into this sad affair as requested by the housekeepers at the Lodge? If not, why is the government refusing to face up to its parliamentary responsibilities or respond to the fair requests of its own former employees?

—There are some occasions in this place when the degree of hypocrisy to which we are exposed reaches such massive, gothic proportions that one is simply left almost breathless in reply. We have these crocodile tears being shed on behalf of two employees by a member of an opposition, who, for as long as I can remember, certainly almost daily in recent times, has been actively opposing the implementation of ILO convention 158 relating to the termination of employment. He has campaigned against it, written against it, spoken against it, whipped up his state counterparts against it, and he has made absolutely clear where he stands on appropriate procedures for termination. Again, we are talking about a member of an opposition who is campaigning actively against the industrial relations bill and the use of the power to implement it.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. On the issue of relevance, I think the question I asked related to the attitude of the government to this matter and I ask you to direct Senator Evans to face up to that question or sit down.
—Order! The question dealt with industrial relations and I think that is what Senator Evans was answering.

—I am indebted to you, Mr President, for allowing me to continue to expose the hypocrisy of the opposition and Senator Kemp, in particular, who has campaigned against, written against and spoken against the industrial relations legislation, whipped up his state counterparts against it and encouraged various state troglodytes to take High Court action against it. These are the people who are now shedding tears over staff who have been the subject of perfectly proper procedures.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Is the minister going to be asked to answer the question, which was about an independent inquiry into this matter, not about industrial relations, as you just ruled?
—I have been listening carefully to Senator Evans and I thought that was what he was just beginning to do.

—The reason why the government has resisted this matter being taken forward in this place in the way that was proposed is simply that there is no logical or rational substance to the call for an inquiry; it is a political trawling expedition of the kind we have seen so often. Personal staff are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act—this is the case for the Lodge as well—one of the underlying principles of which is that people should have flexibility in regard to the employment of staff.

PARA.TAB: The particular circumstances that were involved in this case were clearly spelt out in the full estimates committee hearing. The two housekeepers' contracts were terminated on 5 October. Changes were made because the household was not running properly, staff were not working well together and the housekeepers concerned had been refusing to take directions from the department.

Only one of the housekeepers had an official credit card. She had failed on a number of occasions to follow departmental directions to advise the department in advance of major spending. The department's concern had, I am advised, been drawn to her attention a number of times. The other housekeeper had also failed to follow non-financial departmental directions and had been advised, I am advised, of the department's concerns.

Also of concern was the fact that the household staff were not working together as a team. At meetings with staff on at least four occasions staff were asked to improve their working relationships with each other. When the situation had not improved, the department recommended that the contracts be terminated in order to ensure that the household operated properly.

That is the beginning and end of this matter. It is unfortunate for the individuals concerned. It is obviously a matter of extreme disappointment to them. They handled themselves with a great deal of dignity in relation to efforts that have been made to get them to talk about the way in which the Lodge operated, their relations with the Keatings and so on. It is an unfortunate staffing dispute with the background that I have described which has led to a termination of employment, a situation that occurs every day in this country in hundreds of different circumstances. Of course it is proper that appropriate processes and procedures be followed. We are absolutely committed to doing that. I wish Senator Kemp could persuade anybody that he had any kind of commitment to fair and decent industrial relations employment practices.

As I began by saying, there is no commitment whatsoever on the part of opposition, or Senator Fudd in particular, to pursue that particular course. There is no commitment to doing that and everything that the opposition has done over the last few weeks and months has absolutely demonstrated the extent and the scale of that hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask that proper names be used in the Senate chamber.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Biggles has already shown in the past his great capacities—
—Order! That ruling goes both ways.

—I point out to the minister that the Lodge is funded by the taxpayer. It is not an emperor's palace, although Mr Keating might prefer to treat it as an emperor's palace. The minister speaks of justice and fairness. I put it to him that he has further attacked the good names of these two housekeepers. I agree that they appeared last night on television and acted in a most restrained and sensitive manner.
—Order! Senator Kemp, ask the supplementary question.

—I put it to the minister that they should have a chance to put their case. He has attacked them once again in this parliament, as he attacked them in the estimates committee. They should have a chance to put their case. I urge the government to reconsider its decision and call for an independent inquiry into this matter.
—That wasn't a question.
—Order! There was a question in there.

—It is just because these positions are funded by the taxpayer that it is proper and appropriate that I and officials of the Prime Minister's department give a full and adequate explanation as to why these particular appointments were terminated. If these were not taxpayer supported positions, this would be entirely a private contractual employment arrangement which would be no business of anybody's. Because public funds are involved, it is appropriate that the explanation be given of the circumstances for the sacking, but that is as far as it goes.

PARA.TAB: There is no intention on my part, either in the estimates committee hearing or today, to in any way further make life difficult for the two employees in question. They have chosen to bring the matter into the public domain in the way they have. Under those circumstances, they must expect an explanation to be given in the proper forum—namely, the original estimates committee hearing and now in this parliament—as to what happened. That explanation having been given fully, appropriately and adequately, there is no more to be said about this matter, particularly given the motivation which obviously inspires it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of media reports suggesting that, in the event of a change in government in South Australia, there would be changes to current voting arrangements in that state? PARA.TAB: What we have here is self-interest dressed up as principle. The conservative motivation in this matter is absolutely clear. Conservatives have, on the same information that I have—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is, what are you going to do about it?

—I am about to tell Senator Macdonald, to his embarrassment, why we are not going to do it, even though he would like to claim—as raised in that Leichhardt chicanery of his—that there was a misleading attempt—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The questioner tagged a federal aspect to the end of his question. However, that is not being answered by the minister. Rather, he is talking about the South Australian voting system and the prospects for that, which is none of his business.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, I listened carefully to Senator Foreman's question. He did refer to the situation in South Australia and he did ask whether the Commonwealth was going to adopt such a proposal. I would ask the minister to answer that part of the question.
—Absolutely, Mr President; that is exactly what I was doing.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Are you going to allow the custom of your addressing remarks to people while they stay standing and ignore what you are doing?

—No, Senator Vanstone. I would ask that when points of order are taken ministers resume their seats. I would like to point out that at the time I was making that ruling there were three members of the opposition standing.

—Mr President, I understand why people do not want me to get the chance to put this point, but I intend to do so anyway. The reason why the Commonwealth will not take this course of action is very clear. The research shows that as soon as compulsory voting is removed, the socioeconomic characteristics of the people who do not vote become apparent. It is the poor, the less educated, the homeless and the disadvantaged who are less prone to vote. All the evidence is clear.

PARA.TAB: What they are trying to do will lead to a situation where the necessary priority of the government—and the campaigns, the promises and the commitments—become focused on those who do vote. The whole emphasis of government will be skewed away from those in most need to those who have the most political clout. That is the whole history of the emphasis of campaigning in countries which have voluntary voting. The research conducted by Ian McAllister in 1986 indicated that turnout rates are lower amongst young lower socioeconomic groups, Aborigines and certain categories of migrants—absolutely.

There is a stack of research. There has been research done for years; it shows the same result. That is the basis of their policy. Those opposite know that the research exists; they know that the people who are less likely to vote are those in the socioeconomic groups that are less disposed to support their policies—and this tends to skew the whole electoral process away from those most needy. This has been done in other countries and it should not be done here. It is very important, if we are going to sustain our democracy, that the electoral process—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This answer has nothing whatsoever to do with Commonwealth administration. Nearly every country in the world has a voluntary system of voting, and it is accepted quite reasonably. That is an interesting debate that we can have at another time. But Senator McMullan's answer has nothing to do with the administration of his portfolio. His time is just about up, but otherwise he ought to be sat down.

—It absolutely has. I have said, right from the first sentence of my direct response to Senator Foreman's question, from Senator Macdonald's helpful interjection, that this is why the Commonwealth has absolutely no intention of taking such action. We will not because it is unfair and undemocratic, and we will not have a bar of it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the government's post-APEC and post-NAFTA euphoria, and ask: is the minister aware of the concessions that President Clinton is reported to have made to get support for NAFTA from congressmen with farming electorates? Will these concessions oblige the United States President to continue subsidy schemes which are now sending Australian farmers to the wall? What action is the government taking to ensure that we do not sacrifice Australian farmers, in addition to the labour intensive manufacturing industries, which are doomed by the rush into free trade areas with low wage countries?

—We have closely monitored the lobbying that has gone on to negotiate the passage of the NAFTA legislation in the US Congress. Of course, one cannot be sure that one knows the details of all of the lobbying arrangements which have been made to ensure passage of that bill. That is the very nature of politics. One is never quite sure, for example, what some of the minor parties and the opposition decide between themselves in this chamber by way of deal making.

PARA.TAB: But we know that some of the reports that have come out of the United States as to the nature of those deals have been exaggerated. Some of them have been quite lurid in their content and, indeed, many of them are untrue. That does not mean to say there is not a worry here; it means that we should not be stampeded at the first sign of a newspaper headline. We should be careful and examine the situation. I do know that in at least one case an undertaking that was given was in the words, `We'll use our best endeavours'; and that did not accord with what the newspapers said on this subject, which sort of suggested an open-ended commitment. So one has to be careful about those things when one looks at what might have happened.

Our view on all of this is that, of course, the draft final act, the framework that we are negotiating the Uruguay Round within and, indeed, the Blair House accord, which affects the interests of our rural producers as well, constrain the United States in the sense that it is not possible, given the commitments it has made, to do deals which break that framework. That framework is the formula for how trade and agricultural products will be regulated; and that framework has often been characterised as the recipe for how that trade in agricultural products will be regulated.

But it is a reasonable concern that Senator Spindler has raised, and we are keeping our eye on it. It must be said that the US reaffirmed its positions on both Blair House and the draft final act at the APEC conference itself. The resolution of the conference was quite strong on that point. President Clinton, Mickey Kantor, the US Trade Representative, Commerce and Industry Secretary Brown, and the Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, all committed themselves in support of that as well. They made it very clear that they are determined to put pressure on the European Community about this as well.

In addition, we are continuing to monitor the developments coming out of the NAFTA debate. We will make sure that trade deals are examined in their implementation if they have been made with adverse effects to our people, which at this stage we do not believe has been the case. If necessary, within the multilateral rules of the GATT we will deal with it.

I thought the last part of Senator Spindler's question was a cheap shot. This country is transforming itself into a very efficient producer of high quality manufactured goods which pay high wages. One of the reasons why we are performing so well on our export account in manufactured goods is that we have access to the very markets which the last part of the honourable senator's question condemns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the last remark of Senator Cook's, and ask him: despite the admittedly creditable performance of some export industries, why are merchandise imports still rising at a rate 25 per cent higher than merchandise exports? This means that we have not turned around. What is the government going to do about it? If we are going to rush into free trade areas, what is the government doing to look after those workers who inevitably will lose their jobs?
—Our growth in the export of manufactured goods is rising at a very high level—
—Not as fast as imports.

—It has been rising at a level of about 15 per cent over the last several years. That is because, under our approach to managing tariff reductions and industry policy reform, we now have a number of infant industries which are exporting for the first time. The trend line will be to turn around those account figures. The honourable senator knows that as well as I do. There is no party, perhaps other than the Democrats, in the whole parliament that is not committed to the concept of fair trade. Fair trade means people giving access to our markets while we enjoy access to theirs.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. My question relates to the recent decision of Justice Keely of the Federal Court to set aside the rejection of a refugee claim by Ms Mok Gek Bouy and remit it to the minister for reconsideration. Could the minister advise whether he intends to appeal against this judgment in the full Federal Court.

—I have received advice from the Commonwealth's legal counsel in the Mok case. That advice strongly recommends that an appeal be lodged to the Federal Court. In light of this advice I have determined that the decision of Justice Keely will be appealed. Counsel has accordingly been instructed to prepare the notice of appeal.

PARA.TAB: Senators may be aware that Mr Justice Keely found for the applicant, Ms Mok Gek Bouy, in her challenge against the decision taken by a delegate of the then minister for immigration refusing her refugee application. His Honour set aside that decision and remitted Miss Mok's application to me as the relevant minister for reconsideration. Under the terms of the Migration Act, as amended, any such review decision would be made by the Refugee Review Tribunal.

His Honour's decision was based on a number of grounds which are at odds with the contemporary decision of Mr Justice Wilcox, also in the Federal Court, in what is known as the Lek case, which takes its name from the principal applicant, Dr Lek Kim Sroun. In that case, Justice Wilcox upheld 45 out of 48 departmental decisions, also refusing refugee status. The refused applicants in that case have already lodged an appeal which has, following an application for expedition made on my behalf, been listed for the first sitting period of the Full Court in the new year. I am advised that the Federal Court has indicated a preference for the same bench of the Full Court to hear both the Lek and Mok appeals.

It is worth bearing in mind that a decision in these cases is not likely to be received before the second quarter of next year and, were the Full Court to find for the asylum seekers, they will receive a new hearing only before the Refugee Review Tribunal.

The finalisation of other associated cases which have yet to be heard in the Federal Court is unlikely before June next year. I point this out not because I believe the court will uphold the appeal of the Cambodians, as my advice is that the Commonwealth's case is strong, but to make the point that the Cambodian boat people have another option available to them. If they choose to return to Cambodia before next June, they will be eligible to apply for the special assistance category I announced last month. However, they and their advisers should not believe that they can necessarily pursue both options.

There will be no extension to the life of the SAC in so far as it applies to those currently detained beyond the next SAC program year. This effectively means that they must return, at the latest, before the end of this program year to qualify for the 12 months residency in Cambodia. Some supporters of the group have recently suggested that the alternative to returning and taking up the SAC is, or should be, the granting of permanent residence on humanitarian grounds. I have made both my and the government's position on this proposal clear in the past. It is not an option that the government will agree to. Nothing has occurred to change that view. Moreover, a more realistic appraisal of the options available to the asylum seekers should not be forgotten. If, at the conclusion of the legal process, they remain screened out of the refugee process, the Migration Act requires their departure from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it both the philosophy and the specific policy of the minister's government that all employees who may be dismissed for their performance should be given a warning by employers?

—I am advised that the practice followed in this case was for it to be drawn to the attention of the employees in question that there were concerns about the employment situation in which they were engaged. I believe it is a good employment practice to do just that if one is going down that path.
—Were these people warned?
—There is a dispute about the evidence. Ms Tinney made it perfectly clear in her estimates committee evidence in this parliament that there was prior advice. I said again today on the basis of—
—She said there was no warning that they would be dismissed. Isn't that right?

—She made it clear that they had been advised a number of times of the department's concerns about the lapses that were occurring in the situation in the Lodge. I am not going to be drawn into a semantic debate with Senator Troeth, Senator Hill or anybody else. The point is that the grounds for a belief by the department that something was unsatisfactory about the employment situation had been conveyed.

PARA.TAB: I have said again today that, as far as the housekeeper with the official credit card was concerned, the department's concerns had been drawn to her attention a number of times. I repeat that now. As to the other housekeeper, who, I am advised, had failed to follow non-financial directions, she too had been advised of the department's concern.

As to the general underlying problem which existed about the household staff not working together as a team, I have said already and I will say it again that there were at least four meetings with the staff in which staff were asked to improve their working relationships with one another. If the message had not been obtained through any of those means, then obviously a very unsatisfactory communication occurred.

It is very difficult to believe that there was not a satisfactory communication of the basic concerns that the department had, on the evidence that Senator Troeth has heard directly from Ms Tinney. The fact that that is contested by the employees in question is just one of those things that happens. One has to make one's own judgment. Ms Tinney was giving her advice under the conditions of a parliamentary inquiry and, in my judgment, it is inconceivable that she would have misled the parliament on this matter, particularly since it is one in which she was personally involved—she was not simply working from files or matters of that kind. I think that is a reasonable judgment to make about this unhappy situation and it is one that the Opposition should cease to continue exploring in this thoroughly tendentious fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister appears to have misunderstood my question. I was not asking about a warning about performance; I was asking about a warning about dismissal. In view of the earlier comments that he made to Senator Kemp about the flexibility of staffing arrangements at the Lodge and fair and decent arrangements for staff employment at the Lodge, does this extend to a warning being given to staff about their imminent dismissal?

—I am advised that the proper processes were followed within the meaning of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. Nothing that occurred in this instance is in any way against the letter or the spirit of that legislation. It is important that people in an employment situation be clear about the attitude of their employer towards them, that they not be caught by surprise, as it were, in a situation and not given an opportunity to lift their game or improve their performance. All of that, I am advised, was followed in this particular case.

PARA.TAB: Once again, I cannot forbear from making the point that if the opposition were really serious about these termination employment issues, if it were really serious about good process and good procedure being followed, it would adopt a very different attitude towards ILO convention 158—which it has consistently opposed in every conceivable form—and it would adopt a very different view about the industrial relations bill which, again, it has so obviously opposed in this place. Those opposite are a mob of hypocrites and they are incapable of lying straight in bed or sitting straight in this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is a clear reflection on all members on this side. Senator Evans well knows it and ought to withdraw.

—A collective reflection is impermissible, I take it, Mr President? It fails to single out any individual. You did not rule me out of order before when I referred to those opposite as hypocrites. That is a legitimate parliamentary expression, I would argue, in this context.
—I was not going to ask you to withdraw it. But I think that comments were made that are not helpful in the running of the chamber. I ask you to withdraw them.
—A lot of comments are made that are not helpful, Mr President. I understand your position.

—May I be clear on your ruling? It is therefore permissible to say `That mob on the other side are liars', but it is not permissible to say that any individual is a liar, is that the effect of your ruling? That is intolerable and illogical. If the Standing Orders of this parliament say that you cannot reflect on an individual, then it cannot possibly be the case that you can avoid that sanction by reflecting on them all. I do not think Senator Evans believes it for a minute. But if that is your ruling, then that mob over there are liars, and we will stick to it.
—Order! Calling the opposition collectively hypocrites is something that I think should be withdrawn. I can think of other instances where the expression has been used.
—It was hypocritical behaviour—may I say that? If you do not like the expression `hypocrites', I withdraw it.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Would you consider asking Senator Ian Macdonald to retrospectively withdraw all the collective references he has made about the Democrats?
—If I think that Senator Ian Macdonald has transgressed, I will ask him to withdraw. I did not hear him during that exchange.

—I wish to speak to Senator Kernot's point of order. What she was raising was the fact that it has consistently been ruled in this place—not only with regard to Senator Ian Macdonald, but including him—that Senator Ian Macdonald's reflections collectively upon the Democrats were not unparliamentary because he was talking about them collectively. As I understand it, that has been the process in this place ever since federation. Senator Evans has withdrawn in this instance; I do not want to pursue this instance at all. But I do ask you to consider that ruling that you made and come back. If we are getting to the circumstance where it is not possible to make those comments collectively, it is of no consequence to me. I think that we are all much too precious about what we say about each other and what can be withdrawn or not. But we do need to be consistent.

—Order! I will look at the issues that have been raised this afternoon. Senator Kernot, I think the Procedure Committee did look specifically at some of the remarks that Senator Ian Macdonald had made about the Democrats in the past. I was of the belief that it was not found to be correct, but I will check that.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to a statement made by Senator Julian McGauran, as reported on evening news programs on channels 7 and 10, with regard to child-care accreditation guidelines. Will the minister tell the Senate whether Senator McGauran's comments with regard to the effect of the guidelines, as presented on those evening news programs, were accurate?

—I think Senator McGauran should hang his head in shame. He is to blame for an irresponsible fear campaign about an issue on which he admits knowing nothing. People have been ringing my office in droves today and some have been in tears as a result of seeing those reports on Channel 7 and Channel 10 last night. Those reports were based on selective reporting of the worst kind and were clearly based on the old adage `never let the truth interfere with a good story'.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it quite clear, Senator McGauran is wrong on every count. There is no move to ban Christmas carols in child-care centres. There is no move to stop boys playing with trucks. Senator McGauran is wrong, wrong, wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is right, right, right.

—I am glad Senator Boswell interjected. I have a question for him later on in my comments. I am pleased to hear Senator Boswell say that Senator McGauran is right. Both meanings of the word apply, but I will come back to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: On radio yesterday I heard Senator McGauran say that it is a long time since he had been in a child-care centre, and it clearly shows. It is a long time. I think it might be 20 years. He says that these guidelines are being imposed on the child-care industry by government. He is wrong. These guidelines were devised by the child-care industry. They were devised by a committee representing all elements of the child-care industry. They have been accepted by the government as the industry's description of what is best practice in child care.

I have a clear responsibility to assure parents and to be able to assure parents that when they leave their children in child care they will be leaving their children in quality care. Secondly, we spend over $600 million on child care and it is proper that we should have good accountability of those dollars.

I want to ask whether Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran are at odds with the opposition. Senator Newman has made it clear in this place that she supports accreditation. Where she differs from the government is in her support for voluntary accreditation. If honourable senators opposite object, then they are even further divided than they know. Senator Newman has said that she supports accreditation. Senator Herron knows that because he is going to have carriage of this legislation tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. On behalf of Senator Newman, I point out that that is completely untrue and I ask that the minister withdraw that statement because it is a misrepresentation of what Senator Newman said.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is not a point of order and Senator Herron knows it. It may well be a matter that Senator Herron or any other senator may care to take up after question time via the mechanism of a personal explanation. Senator Herron and all opposition senators know that it is clearly out of order.
—A similar point of order was taken earlier this morning. It is not the role of the Chair to determine whether a statement is correct or not.

—The opposition has made it quite clear that it supports accreditation. I have made it clear that the point it opposes is linking accreditation with fee relief. It says that it supports a voluntary program of accreditation.

PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran and now Senator Boswell have divided themselves from the opposition on this issue, many of whom are divided amongst themselves. I think it is very important that the opposition gets clear its view of accreditation. It seems to me that it is saying that it has no care for the quality of care that parents can expect when they take their children to child care. If that is the opposition's view then I think it should come out and say so. If it is not its view then it is divided on this issue as it is on many others.

I am very clear. I want to be sure and able to assure parents that when they leave children in child care they are leaving them in quality care. The guidelines come from the industry. The industry supports those guidelines. It knows what constitutes best practice in child care. This government supports the child-care industry's preference for accreditation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Family Services to her $11 million social engineering program aimed at the nation's child-care centres and embodied in the 107-page child care quality improvement and accreditation system manual. Can the minister explain specifically why the manual claims: first, that child-care centres are deemed as acting in an unsatisfactory way if they exclusively celebrate Christmas and promote the playing of Christmas carols; secondly, that the child-care centre staff cannot use routine phrases to girls like, `That's nice' or `I like your pretty dress'; and, thirdly, why child care staff are considered as acting in an unsatisfactory way if they speak more gently to girls than boys?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite will probably take note of this at the end of question time, too. I say again, exactly as I have said before, Senator McGauran is wrong, wrong, wrong. He is deliberately misrepresenting those guidelines and the intention of the child-care industry when it brought these guidelines to government.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber. It is impossible to hear.

—Thank you, Mr President. The answer is to repeat that Senator McGauran is determined to get it wrong. He is determined to make sure that parents in the community are made to be fearful and concerned.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not think the minister has read her own guidelines. They say that occasions such as Christmas are culturally irrelevant for many children and that staff provide stereotype toys such as trains, trucks and bulldozers for boys and dolls for girls.
—Order!
—This is a manifest abuse of question time, Mr President, and I ask that you sit him down right now.
—Order!
—This is a misuse of question time and I ask you to rule accordingly, Mr President.
—Order! There is no point of order at all.
—Mr President, there may have been no point of order by Senator Hill, but I am arguing as a point of order that that was an abuse of question time and it ought to be ruled out on that ground alone.

—Order! This would obviously be one of the worst question times that I have been in the chair for. The next person who consistently interjects or uses comments like I just heard then will be thrown out.
—Since those opposite insist that we read the guidelines, I will draw their attention to another very important part of the guidelines, which says:

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to note that the descriptions accompanying each Principle do not constitute an exhaustive list. Instead, they are provided as examples to guide a centre in the process of self-study.
I have read the guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Panizza, resume your seat.

—Mr President, there is no point in arguing with those opposite. They are determined to misrepresent their own case. If they care to check, they will find that Senator Newman supports accreditation and so do most of the people involved in this process. Senator McGauran's question goes to objecting to the accreditation process. It has come from the industry itself. It is the industry's description of what constitutes best practice. The opposition is deliberately misunderstanding the intention of those guidelines.
—Table the guidelines!

—What does Senator Vanstone mean—table them? They have laid on the table in this place for 15 sitting days. Senator Vanstone simply does not understand what is going on. Those opposite have finally caught up on this campaign. They are whipping themselves into a frenzy. I will not be misled or distracted by it. They are responsible for creating a huge amount of fear and anxiety in the community and they are not concerned to support the child-care industry in its own description of what constitutes best practice. These are not government guidelines; they are guidelines the government accepts from the industry.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crowley is defending her actions; she is not responding to the question that was directed to her by Senator McGauran. She has enough trouble with her own party letting this get out of the bag, but would you direct her attention to answering the question addressed to her by Senator McGauran?
—I believe that Senator Crowley has been in order. I ask her to finish her answer.

—I am coming to a conclusion. This question is a deliberate attempt by Senator McGauran to confuse and create anxiety for parents of Australia. I can only say again that the opposition seems not to understand that these guidelines have come from the industry. They have been accepted by government. They constitute what is called good practice. They actually are a description of ways in which child-care centres can provide a varied and enjoyable experience for children in child care.

PARA.TAB: If members of the opposition had read the guidelines themselves, if they understood this process, and if they had not listened to selective lobbying from a small section of the private industry, they would be entirely in support of the government. I urge them to look at Senator Newman's comments in Hansard where she supports accreditation, going to all the matters that have been raised by Senator McGauran. The opposition is divided and confused, not the government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Family Court Counselling Service, Gold Coast

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I draw the minister's attention to a question asked by Senator Kernot in December 1991 about the closure of the Family Court Counselling Service on the Gold Coast and assurances given by the then Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, that the service should be restored in the 1992-93 budget. Is the minister aware that this service has not been restored? Is the minister concerned that the population of the Gold Coast area is estimated to grow to 380,000 people by the year 2001 and that this is an area of great social instability? Does the minister know that an estimated 100 Gold Coast families are not attending compulsory counselling services in Brisbane? Will the minister take steps to ensure the service on the Gold Coast is restored by the end of 1993?

—I do have some advice from the Attorney-General on this. I must say at the outset that I cannot immediately confirm the claimed assurance of Senator Tate. But I can say that a crisis counselling service has previously operated on the Gold Coast, as has been indicated. The purpose of the service was to provide crisis counselling intervention relating to marriage breakdowns, particularly in the early stages of separation. The decision to withdraw the counselling service on the Gold Coast was made late in 1991 by the Chief Justice of the Family Court in performance of his statutory function of administering the court.

PARA.TAB: The Family Law Court has recently negotiated an extension of its workload formula arrangements with the Department of Finance in the context of the need to provide further counselling services. Further, I am informed that subject to the outcome of these discussions it may be possible that a Family Court registry will be established on the Gold Coast in the next financial year. I am sure it would be the priority of the Attorney-General. I will also pass on Senator Woodley's support for the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the kindy culture social experiment being implemented under the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System Handbook. What cost to the taxpayer will be incurred by members of the department investigating compliance with the principles under the external review process? What will the self-study process cost child-care centres, bearing in mind that the handbook specifies in great detail what is and what is not satisfactory? Will the minister's inspectors be checking the sandpits to determine whether only girls are making cakes? Will they be counting the number of times staff use the words `no' and `naughty'? If they find any stencils or other colouring books emphasising conformity, will they be confiscated?

—I take the serious part of that question to go to the costs. First of all, let me say that Senator Boswell betrays a complete lack of understanding of this process because he is referring to departmental supervision of the program. It will not be supervised by the department; it is to be supervised by the National Child Care Accreditation Council, which I established earlier this year.

PARA.TAB: The first process of accreditation is a self-assessment done by the centres themselves against these guidelines. If they judge that they have reached a satisfactory standard, they will apply for accreditation and they will get it. If they judge that they themselves are below standard and seek assistance to develop a program to bring themselves up to standard, then they will continue to receive fee relief. The prospect of losing fee relief with the accreditation is a very long process. Parents need be assured that child-care assistance will not be cut off from centres, provided they show any enthusiasm or interest in the accreditation process.

I can tell the Senate that the costs at this stage are, first of all, a $100 registration fee per centre per year—a very small cost per child. Private consultants assessed the cost of the review process and their estimate is about 80c per child per week at the most. Centres that reach accreditation early will not have to meet anywhere near that sort of cost.

It is the failure of the opposition to understand this program that is most concerning. The program will not be policed or supervised by departmental people. This will be done by the accreditation council and peers—that is, other providers of child care. It is done and designed that way by the child-care industry to meet its needs and to keep the costs very low. These standards, I can only say again, are not designed by government. They are designed by the child-care industry as its description of best practice in child care.

Much of what the opposition is putting forward is an absolute nonsense. If the opposition had read the guidelines, if it had understood the process which provides for documents and regulations to be in this place for 14 sitting days—the 15th day is tomorrow, which is why the disallowance motion will come on then—instead of believing the absolute furphies that Senator McGauran is running around with, then we would not have this absolute nonsense campaign. I suggest again that those opposite look at what Senator Newman has said about this matter. She is in support of accreditation and that would be a very thoughtful approach for the opposition to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The handbook describes as good quality, under principle 3 relating to lack of sex bias, a situation where staff recognise that this not extend to minor areas such as expecting boys to dress up in female clothes if this conflicts with family expectations. I ask the minister whether she was disappointed at making such a concession to current stereotypes.
—The opposition is showing an absolute failure to understand and a determination to be really stupid about this matter, and I find that extraordinarily disappointing.
—They don't have to try.
—Senator McMullan is right; they do not have to try. The opposition is clearly deeply divided about this matter. It does not know what it is talking about—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes it is—read Senator Newman's acceptance of accreditation. What the guidelines are asking for is that our children have an enjoyable and varied experience in child-care centres. There is no compulsion on any child to do anything. There is an appreciation by child-care providers of what constitutes a good curriculum and a good day in the child-care centres, what constitutes good relations between staff and children and what constitutes safety, hygiene and good nutrition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the Australian government's reaction to the military coup in Nigeria which has put prospects for the return to democracy on indefinite hold? Are Australians in Nigeria at any personal risk?

—I am indebted to Senator Childs for this opportunity to express the Australian government's very serious concern over the military takeover which occurred in Nigeria some days ago on 18 November. The coup, led by General Abacha, is especially untimely, given moves towards democracy and multi-party government in many other African countries. By its actions in removing the interim government and its wholesale dismantling of government and democratic institutions, the Nigerian military really has dealt a very severe blow to any prospects for democracy in that country in the foreseeable future.

PARA.TAB: Of particular concern is the fact that the military has dissolved the Senate, the House of Representatives and national and state assemblies, and has dismissed state governors and civilian administrators. General Abacha has also dissolved the National Electoral Commission, outlawed political parties and revoked democratic rights, including the holding of political gatherings and demonstrations. It will be remembered that the Nigerian people voted freely in presidential elections on 12 June this year; the then military regime later annulled those elections and installed an interim government of its own choosing, further delaying the introduction of democracy. Those interim government arrangements were declared unconstitutional by the Nigerian High Court on 10 November. Along with just about all other members of the international community, we very strongly urge the military leadership to set the process of democratisation back on track.

As to the situation for Australians in Nigeria, I understand that the situation in Lagos—which is not an easy environment at the best of times—and other parts of the country is relatively calm at the moment. But my department is recommending that Australian travellers consider deferring non-essential travel to Nigeria. Australians who desire to travel there should keep themselves informed of developments and are advised to register with the Australian High Commission in Lagos. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During question time Senator Kernot raised a point of order with me. It is disorderly to use offensive words against groups of members of either house, as distinct from individually named members. It was a ruling originally given in 1916. It was a ruling that I gave again on 10 December 1991. The situation that she referred to was dealt with on page 11 of the procedure committee's third report of 1992 relating to unparliamentary language. It is clearly out of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a question asked by Senator Lees on 19 November, I gave an undertaking to provide further information in relation to the administration of the Medicare agreements by the South Australian government. There has been a degree of public concern in South Australia that the South Australian Health Commission proposed to impose financial penalties on country hospitals. These penalties were to be imposed on hospitals which either fell short of public patient bed day targets or exceeded private patient bed day targets. The South Australian Health Commission set the target number of bed days for each hospital.

PARA.TAB: Under the Medicare agreements, part of the Commonwealth funding to states is designed to provide an incentive for the states to maintain and improve their level of public access. The performance measure which is used for these incentives is the ratio of public to private bed days across each state.

The Commonwealth does not prescribe the states' management strategies which are required to be implemented at the individual hospital level. South Australia has chosen to manage its public-private ratio by allocating public and private patient throughput targets for each individual hospital. The South Australian Health Minister, Martyn Evans, recently stated:

ANSWER.PARA: No country hospitals have been penalised for exceeding private bed days and indications are that this will not happen.

He gave an assurance that no penalty will be imposed on country hospitals if the state as a whole does not suffer any penalties from the Commonwealth. Clearly, Minister Evans has indicated that he is not expecting that either the state or any South Australian country hospitals will suffer any reductions in funding. His assessment is consistent with the data provided to my department for the calculation of bed day bonus funding. At this stage—and based on data supplied to my department—it has been estimated that if the current level of public access is maintained, South Australia should receive a bonus in the region of $950,000 in 1993-94.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I answered a question from Senator O'Chee concerning AQIS and Mr Bisset, a consultant to AQIS. I have now received from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy additional information concerning the contractual arrangements relating to Mr Bisset. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has been advised by the Department of Finance that Mr Bisset was selected for the provision of consultancy services for the commercialisation of AQIS on the basis of quotes it had received from five known suppliers. Other companies approached included Price Waterhouse and Aspect Computing.

PARA.TAB: Finance's decision to employ Mr Bisset was based on the quality and price of his quote and the work which he had previously performed for the Department of Finance. The Department of the Arts and Administrative Services Commonwealth government procurement guidelines do not require contracts of this nature to be gazetted for public tender. Gazettal is not required where an authorised person has decided to confine an approach to known suppliers or a particular market sector.

Under finance regulation 43B, gazettal of the details of contracts awarded for amounts over $2,000 is required. This was done in regard to the Bisset contracts. The actual dates of publication of the Bisset contracts in the Gazette were: 23 October 1991, 19 February 1992, 23 September 1992 and 21 October 1992.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday Senator Ferguson asked me a series of related questions regarding air traffic controllers in the Royal Australian Air Force. I will now answer those questions in sequence. Senator Ferguson asked:

ANSWER.PARA: How many air traffic controllers have left the RAAF under the recent redundancy program?
Thirteen controllers were made redundant. He asked:
How many are currently in Somalia?
I indicated on Monday that there were 10 or 11. I can confirm that there are currently 10 controllers serving with UNOSOM. He asked:
Has this left the RAAF with a critical shortage of air traffic controllers?

The answer to that is no. There are minor staffing shortfalls at a number of units because of the UNOSOM commitment, but these are manageable. Unit staffing of all officer categories, including air traffic controllers, varies for a number of reasons including resignations, exercise commitments, the UNOSOM contribution, officers proceeding on maternity leave, training failures and long service leave. He also asked:

In the event of this shortage, have any air traffic controllers who left the air force under the redundancy program joined or been asked to join the RAAF reserve to fill their old positions or other air traffic positions which were declared to be redundant and, therefore, excess to air force requirements?

The answer to that part of Senator Ferguson's question is that there is no critical staffing shortage. One air traffic controller who left the RAAF under a redundancy program applied to transfer from the general reserve to the active reserve. His application for transfer has been approved to fill a vacancy in reserve squadron. One other officer's application is currently being processed. These requests for transfer were initiated by the officers concerned and not by the air force.

PARA.TAB: Officers on the active reserve do not fill permanent air force positions. They are employed for a limited number of days, normally 32 days per year, to enable their skills—in this case as air traffic controllers—to be maintained. Members of RAAF reserve squadron supplement permanent air force staffing in contingency or exercise operations. Senator Ferguson also asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Have any officers taken up this offer?
The RAAF has made no offers. The two officers concerned initiated their applications for transfer. He asked:
Have they been required to repay their redundancy payments?

Should an officer who accepted a redundancy payment apply to rejoin the permanent air force, ministerial approval is necessary and repayment of the redundancy payment may be required. But, an officer who has transferred to the active reserve and is employed on a limited part-time basis has no such obligation. He asked:
If not, is this with your knowledge or with the knowledge of the Chief of the Air Staff?
In that case I would refer the honourable senator to my previous answer. Finally, he asked:
. . . if there is a shortage, whose decision was it to declare these positions redundant and excess to air force requirements?
No air traffic control positions were declared redundant and excess to air force requirements

directly as a result of the redundancy program. Rather, the redundancy program enabled air force to adjust structural distortions in staff profiles arising from both the reduction in establishment due to the force structure review and reduced wastage rates. Air force selected individual officers from volunteers for redundancy according to a number of criteria.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson also asked the following supplementary question:

ANSWER.PARA: When the minister is making those investigations, will he confirm that all air traffic controllers who recently accepted redundancy will not be returning to the RAAF to fill their old positions, or other air traffic positions, which were declared redundant and in excess of air force requirements, and that they will not return as members of the RAAF reserve, working under better conditions and better pay than their permanent, full-time counterparts, including being able to name the hours they are available and being paid somewhere in the vicinity of $100 a day tax free?

The answer to that part of Senator Ferguson's question, as I said previously, is that air traffic controller positions were not declared excess to requirements as a result of the recent redundancy program. Air traffic controllers who are made redundant may be subsequently accepted for employment on the active reserve, but they do not fill permanent air force air traffic controller positions and are employed on a strictly limited number of training days per year to maintain their proficiency. They are paid at an appropriate daily rate according to their rank and experience; and that payment, as for normal reserve pay, is tax free.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, during question time, Senator MacGibbon asked me a question relating to a book by Nigel Cawthorne in which the claim was made that 2,360 Australian and 2,573 New Zealand prisoners of war disappeared into Soviet labour camps at the end of World War II. I indicated to him that I would have inquiries made. These inquiries are continuing but, given the sensational nature of the claims, I thought it important to provide the Senate now with further information.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that, during the 1939-45 war against Germany, a total of 200 servicemen were presumed to have died while prisoners of war, while the remaining 7,919 were recovered and accounted for. I am not yet able to be definitive on the proportion of these 200 who may be unaccounted for. Dr Jeffrey Grey of ADFA is quoted in the Age newspaper of 20 November, as saying that 91 Australians taken prisoner in Europe, mostly in Greece and Crete, are unaccounted for. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: That means, while we don't know what happened to them they are presumed to be dead.

Australian War Memorial research confirms that the vast majority of German prisoner of war camps were in western Europe, and that very few Australians were in eastern camps. It suggests that there is anecdotal evidence, some of it published in memoirs, of the treatment of liberated Australian prisoners by advancing Russian armies; it seems that they were treated as allies and were assisted by the Russians. Indeed, it is hard to think why their captivity would have been continued by the Russians.

PARA.TAB: In the Age article, which I previously referred to, Dr Grey and the National President of the Returned Services League, Major General Digger James, both indicate that the claims should be treated very cautiously and that, if any Australians had been enslaved in Russia, the numbers would be very low.

The statistics and anecdotal evidence lead to the very high improbability of what the writer has suggested. The probability is that no Australians became prisoners of the Russians, but I cannot say that, obviously, with complete certainty. In any case, the figure of 2,360 Australians is totally unsustainable.

While there may be some debate amongst academics, I think that the last words on this might appropriately come from the Ex-prisoners of War Association of Australia. That association was contacted by my department, and the federal president of that association said that his association was, `satisfied that every Australian prisoner of war in German hands had been accounted for', and that his association `would never have rested unless that had been the case'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This matter arises because of a notice of motion by Senator Patterson seeking that certain documents relating to Australian Artists' Creative Fellowships be tabled.

PARA.TAB: I understand the information purpose for which they are being sought, notwithstanding any subsidiary political purposes. In a document I have made available to Senator Patterson I have sought to outline my concern about the nature of the request and how I think I might be able to satisfy her search for information without transgressing some of the privacy and other concerns I have about the nature of her request.

The problem that Senator Patterson had in judging whether my response was reasonable, as I understand it, was that she wanted to see the documents which I proposed to table, some of which she has asked for and some in lieu of those for which she has asked which serve the same purpose. I am content to table those documents which I indicated to her I would table, but I wanted the opportunity to put in context why I am not proceeding directly in response to her request but hope to comply with the legitimate aspects of that request.

In this instance we do not have a circumstance in which the conflict over a return to order, some of which we have had before in other circumstances, relates to a conflict between the executive and the parliament. There are not issues of concern about executive privilege, the nature of documents being disclosed, such as confidential government cabinet documents, or any of those issues that have arisen with regard to some controversy concerning previous returns to order. It is a concern that I have about the balance between the rights of citizens to privacy of documents which they consider they have provided in that context and the integrity and respect of the arm's length peer review process in the assessment of arts funding matters.

There is no doubt, notwithstanding that arm's length peer review process, that the parliament has undoubted rights to ensure that proper processes exist, that they have been followed, that the money has been accounted for, and that those involved have acted in accordance with reasonable expectations of standards of public behaviour.
