I believe that with the explanatory document which I have previously given to Senator Patterson and these documents which I am now about to table, all those issues can adequately be pursued by opposition members. They may come back and be very concerned about what is shown up in the documents; that is a legitimate matter of public debate—although I think they all indicate that the process has been entirely proper. The opportunity for interested senators to pursue the undoubted rights of the parliament is covered in these documents that are being tabled and in the tabling statement that has already been provided to Senator Patterson.

To go beyond it is to move from accountability to a bit of a witch-hunt. A number of people sincerely believe that their reputation has been damaged in this process and that their integrity as members of the committee has been reflected upon. I do not want to start that debate as to whether that is right or not; those people are citizens and can speak for themselves. Some of them have written letters to the newspapers, et cetera about that.

It is important that, while we do acknowledge the undoubted right of the parliament to seek information, we balance that with our responsibility to be concerned about the rights of individuals, and the credibility and independence of the arm's length peer review process, which I regard as very important. I think the balance of public interest is met by the compromise which I have developed and which I think will make all the information available that will enable people to make a considered judgment.

So I table the documents as I indicated I would in my previous response to Senator Patterson. I suppose for the sake of completeness I should table that document as well, although Senator Patterson already has it. I table the statement from me to Senator Patterson headed, `Return to Order' in response to her resolution and the documents to which that statement refers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not with great pleasure that I have embarked on the task of addressing the issue of the awarding of the creative fellowships. I know that it has caused some people concern. But if the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had done the right thing in the beginning and not been so involved in appointing people to the original committee, we most probably would not have reached this point.

PARA.TAB: Some feel that the fact this issue is being raised in this way is in some way casting aspersions on their professional ability and integrity. I regret most sincerely if this has meant that some people feel that their integrity has been questioned. It would never have come to this if Mr Keating had not appointed the advisory panel to be at arm's length from the Australia Council because, as Mr Keating said, the Australia Council was stale. That is why he did it. The arts community is rightfully concerned that that committee was appointed by Mr Keating when he was Treasurer, which is not a normal procedure.

It is very telling that the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) claims that the meeting of the advisory panel at which the first round of fellowships was considered was not formally minuted. Is the minister saying that no minutes were taken at a meeting at which it was decided to grant the recipients $1.4 million of taxpayers' money? If so, that is very disturbing. If they are informal minutes, then in the best interests of accountability they should be tabled in the Senate. That is the sort of thing that the arts community is concerned about, not the integrity of the people who are on the committee.

It is a fact that the committee was appointed by Mr Keating himself. The minister will correct me if there are no minutes of the meeting at which the first scholarships were awarded. The decision should be seen to be clear-cut and one that was made publicly available to especially those of us who are charged with the responsibility of looking at how taxpayers' money is spent. An amount of $1.4 million was being spent in this case.

In relation to the request for the tabling of all the documents pertaining to the appointment of the members of the original advisory panel, the minister has provided a letter from the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, to the then Minister for the Arts, Mr Holding, proposing seven people for appointment to the panel. A letter from Mr Holding to the Prime Minister proposed the appointment of the original panel. So Mr Keating wrote to Mr Holding proposing seven people, and Mr Holding wrote to Mr Hawke proposing those seven people.

Is the minister saying that these are the only documents pertaining to the original appointments? If so, it confirms my concern and the concern of many in the arts community that the panel was hand-picked by Mr Keating, not by the responsible minister or by the arts community, therefore letting it feel that it had a say in this peer assessment of what were to be very prestigious awards. The committee was picked by Mr Keating, not the responsible minister or, as I said, the arts community.

In my amendment to this return to order, I stipulated that the names and addresses of the members of the original panel be made available to senators upon request rather than be tabled. Using this alternative means, this information will not be put in the public domain unless the senator who requests this information makes a decision to reveal it in the public domain. That senator would then be subjected to the force of law. Senator McMullan may like to answer whether he will be making this information available to me.

In regard to my request for Mr Tozer's application, the minister claims that the tabling of this information would be a breach of the information privacy principles. I remind the minister of the resolution of a committee of the whole that was adopted by the Senate on 21 May 1990 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)that the principle, espoused by the Senate in 1971 and 1974, that there are no areas of expenditure of public funds where Statutory Authorities have a discretion to withhold details or explanations from Parliament or its Committees unless the Parliament has expressly provided otherwise, be re-affirmed.

(ii) the affirmation, in accordance with this principle, that the right to privacy of individual counsel accepting a brief on behalf of the Commonwealth for which money is appropriated by Parliament is supervened by such acceptance, subject to the reasons for the information being clearly defined and to the proviso that injudicious or unwarranted invasion of privacy is not the intention of the Parliament or its Committees;

This precedent is directly relevant in this instance. The Senate has the undeniable right to scrutinise the expenditure of public funds, especially given the unusual nature—I think most honourable senators would agree—of the appointment of this committee. The Senate has a duty and a responsibility to ensure the accountability of moneys that it has appropriated.

PARA.TAB: This government has amazing double standards in the area of privacy. We have been called upon to extend the tax file number. At the same time that public servants are matching the most intimate details of millions of welfare recipients—many of whom receive less than $1,000 a year—on the basis of protecting the public purse, is Senator McMullan implying that he will not provide the Senate with the information that it requires to decide whether all due processes have been followed in the allocation of over half a million dollars to a single person? It seems as though there are different rules for different people.

If the minister tables the document in the Senate, he is covered by parliamentary privilege. Of course, any document that is tabled in this place is also in the public domain. Hence, if it contains identifiable personal information and is given to senators on a privacy basis, the publishing of that information would be a breach of the responsibility we have as senators.

I hope that the two objectives of individual privacy and public accountability do not inherently conflict. It would be possible to obtain a ruling on whether the claims made by Senator McMullan in his correspondence to me this morning, which he has tabled, actually do prevent him from tabling the applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said. I said they meant I shouldn't, not that I couldn't.

—I think Senator McMullan is saying that he should not, not that he could not. We are saying here that one of the reasons for giving a second scholarship is on the basis of exceptional circumstances. We need to know whether the aims and objectives that the applicant set out for the first scholarship were actually achieved.
—The documents make all that available. Why don't you read them first and not after?

—It has been said that one of the aims and objectives was to purchase a property at Queanbeyan for a music school which would provide master classes for musicians. I will read in more detail the documents that were tabled. From the information that I received in the letter, it appeared that that information would not be forthcoming. I will be very pleased if it is.
—It is sufficient to determine all that.

—Mr Deputy President, this is very difficult with the minister mumbling on the other side of the chamber. After reading the letter that Senator McMullan sent to me, I anticipated that that information would not be available in those documents. I therefore was anticipating that I would move my motion. The most appropriate thing for me to do would be to look at those tabled documents and to come back to the Senate at a later hour this day, and re-examine what we will do with the notice of motion that is standing in my name.

PARA.TAB: This matter relates to the awarding of one of the most prestigious awards to—we all would admit—one of Australia's gifted artists. It is in the interests of Mr Tozer, the Prime Minister, the minister, and also those who served on that committee, that it is shown and demonstrated to the arts community and to the Australian public that all due processes were followed in the awarding of these two fellowships.

If those processes were followed and if the minister can demonstrate that, nobody should take offence at the fact that we need to look at these things closely. An amazing amount of concern about the process has been expressed to me not from applicants who did not get the scholarship—we would understand when people do not get a scholarship that they may feel aggrieved—but from senior people in the artistic field. I have some disquiet given the very clear revelation that the advisory committee was set up by Mr Keating. One of the documents tabled by Senator McMullan actually talks about it being an independent committee. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: .The grant of a Fellowship is made by the Australia Council on the recommendation of an Advisory Panel to the Australia Council
.The Australia Council enjoys statutory independence from the Government of the day

That is very difficult to justify when the original committee was apparently handpicked by Mr Keating. It seems to me that a double standard or a process is operating that really is not clear-cut and really needs to be examined very closely. I think the arts community needs to know about that.

PARA.TAB: One person in the arts community said to me, `I was staggered; I thought that was an Australia Council committee.' That person was stunned when it was found out that it might be possible that Mr Keating actually recommended the original committee. They are the concerns that need to be made public.

I will look at those documents because obviously the minister, from his interjections, appears to be suggesting that there is more available in those documents than I would have thought from the letter that he sent me. I put on the record that we will be considering what we will do about this notice of motion later today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not expect this debate now. I assumed that Senator Patterson would read the documents and if she was not satisfied and wished to speak about them she would come back. I would have been happy to have the debate then and it would have been a better debate. Nevertheless, that is not a problem because she has the right to raise the matter now.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it clear that I think the wording of the documents I gave to Senator Patterson make the situation clear. They were certainly meant to. I tabled my copy, so I do not have a copy with me. I am sure the documents make it clear.

I am not arguing that the Senate cannot request information that conflicts with the privacy principles of that legislation. I am simply saying that that is a very serious thing to do. If we can meet the reasonable information requests of senators without doing that, we should. I think I can give Senator Patterson that information in an alternative manner without literally conforming to her request.

We often have to balance competing principles. That is what I have sought to do on this occasion. I think it is extraordinary that anybody would be surprised that a minister is involved in the selection of a government committee. How do those opposite think they get there? By osmosis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole committee?
—The whole committee is always appointed by the minister.
—One person?

—They are appointed by cabinet on the recommendation of the minister. The committees are now appointed by cabinet on my recommendation. That is the only way they get there. The people who serve on those committees have taken significant offence at what has been said. I am not going to disclose the content of private correspondence to others because that is not for me to do. Although, if it becomes necessary, I will do so.

PARA.TAB: Mr Bryson, a member of the committee, has in a letter to the Age taken great exception to Senator Patterson's suggestion of a Keating influence over the awarding of the fellowship to Geoffrey Tozer. He says the suggestion that Mr Keating influenced the decision is a furphy and that the award was given on merit. He said some things about Senator Patterson that were very unkind. I will not mention those.

TALK.START.PARA: —About all politicians.
—He gives Senator Patterson a special mention. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The AACF panel does it tough and straight. It toadies to no Keating, no Patterson, no one.

PARA.TAB: The other panellists may make their own replies, but I wonder how long committees like it could carry on under this senator and those with the stomach to work with her . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He is making his point very clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else did he say?
—I will read the whole lot, if Senator Herron likes.
—Order! Senator McMullan, The fact that you are reading a document which reflects upon a senator does not move outside the standing orders which forbid reflections on senators.

—Mr Deputy President, I do not think in this instance that that would breach standing orders, but I thank you for drawing it to my attention. We have to be very careful in this place. A lot of people keep leaping up and taking exception to things being said about them, but they feel free to say things about other people. I think we operate an amazing double standard in this place in terms of demanding withdrawal of things—
—Your own side is worse.
—I think the whole Senate needs to consider its position about how sensitive we are about what is said about ourselves and what we feel free to say about others.
—You know me, Bob. I have thought about it very carefully.

—I am not necessarily referring to Senator Patterson in this instance. It is a statement that I have made before, as honourable senators know. I am not making it just with regard to this matter, and I will not take time diverting to it for long because it is a debate that we have had before. I think things said about ourselves that we seek to have withdrawn are ridiculous when one looks at it in relation to the things we feel free to say about others. That is not directed particularly at Senator Patterson; it is directed at the 76 of us.
—Get back to the issue.
—I happen to think that is an important point, but I will not take a lot of time on it. I repeat it on every occasion. I think we should take it into account.
—I take it, Senator McMullan, that you are not canvassing my ruling.

—Far be it! I accept that it is undoubtedly correct. I was only trying to make a different point. The President's rulings, in all these matters about what should be withdrawn, are consistent with the tradition of rulings in this place. Until the Senate changes its practice, the President has to continue to enforce those precedents; he has no choice. I am not reflecting on his rulings. I acknowledge that they are correctly interpreting the precedents of the Senate. I just think we should change our attitude with regard to it.

PARA.TAB: The debate about the substance of this will come subsequently, either if Senator Patterson is not satisfied with the documents or if she is satisfied with the documents but wants to pursue issues of substance that arise from them. I will be very happy to debate issues of substance because I believe that creative fellowships are regarded overwhelmingly as an important initiative.

There is a lot of concern. People say that these people are paid too much and big figures are thrown about. Let us make it very clear. Nobody on a fellowship receives as much taxpayers' money as any senator in here. Every senator is paid more by the taxpayer than everybody on these fellowships. Let us not be too pious about the amounts of money—

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with it?
—I am simply saying that $325,000 sounds like a lot of money, and it is—
—Bob, could you get on to the topic?
—It is exactly the topic.
—It is absolutely irrelevant.

—It is not. People are entitled to make assessments about whether this is a lot of money. I am simply making a comparison. The people making the allegations about how much money this is get paid more than the people about whom the allegations are made. I think that is relevant. I think the documents will show that the process by which people are appointed was on this occasion absolutely orthodox; it is by ministerial recommendation and cabinet decision. I am happy, as I say, to debate the standards.

PARA.TAB: It is long overdue that we had a scheme like these fellowships that enable Australia to give proper recognition to its outstanding artists. I am very pleased that it was introduced and that proper processes, which the documents indicate, were undertaken on this occasion. Mr Bryson and others—but I refer only to him because he is on the public record—made it absolutely clear that they are offended by the reflection that they did not pursue that proper process.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Boswell and McGauran this day, relating to child-care accreditation guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I make the point that the Senate, and particularly the people of Australia, should be indebted to Senator Julian McGauran for raising this most important issue. Despite the fact that Senator Crowley tried to prove that Senator McGauran was wrong, there is no question that the accreditation guidelines and the points that Senator McGauran made are accurate; they are there in black and white, and they are true.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that people from all over Queensland are now ringing my office and expressing their concern. Senator Crowley, just like her sister in the other place, has embarrassed the government beyond belief. In fact, I think these guidelines to which Senator Crowley has given her imprimatur are even more damaging to the government than Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rio Ros.

—Yes, Minister Rio Ros in the other place. Money can always be recovered in some form or another. Public money is important, but there is nothing more important in this world than our children—and Senator Crowley is treating people's families cavalierly.

PARA.TAB: There are some examples that I think should be brought up in the Senate. For instance, the guidelines say that it is unsatisfactory for staff to make sex biased remarks about appearance. I suppose a remark like `Your hair looks pretty in that ribbon' would be bad if it were directed to a girl, but it would be okay if it were said to a boy. That is the utter stupidity—and I feel pretty wild about this—of this document that the minister has allowed to go out under the government's name and embarrass it.

According to the guidelines, a child-care centre reaches basic standards only when both boys and girls are allowed to make mudpies in the sandpit. They say that a centre is deemed to be of good quality when staff realise that the need for lack of sex bias need not extend to minor areas such as expecting boys to dress up in female clothing if this conflicts with a family's expectation. It is ridiculous that we have to go through this, and it is even more ridiculous that a well-founded fear in the community should be promoted by this government. I know that various ministers have been embarrassed by these guidelines.

According to the guidelines, it is unsatisfactory for staff to use the words `no' and `naughty' often, and it is unsatisfactory for staff to interrupt children's activities and expect them to conform immediately to staff demands. How are the children going to know what is right and what is wrong if people do not tell them? How are they going to conform to the expectations of their parents and of the staff if they are not told what is right and what is wrong?

I wonder what would happen, Mr Deputy President, if you did not have some jurisdiction to tell either side of the Senate what was right or what was wrong. It would be chaos; it would be mayhem; there would be no control in the Senate. There would be no control in our schools, and there would be no control in our child-minding centres, if people could not make the distinction between what is right and what is wrong and kindly pass that information on to children. This shows the utter stupidity of these guidelines that are put before this parliament. They are an embarrassment to the government and an offence to this side of the parliament.

According to the guidelines, it is also unsatisfactory if there is too much competing colour in the child-care environment, or if there is a constant repetition of Christmas songs as background at the end of the year. Who is going to police this? Are inspectors going to go into the rooms and monitor which carols are sung, who is in the sandpit and who is wearing hair ribbons? I find this absolutely ridiculous. I do not know how the minister can come in here and defend her stupid actions, which are embarrassing to everyone. No-one could accuse her of being realistic—although in the guidelines she is asking people to show realism.

I am offended by these guidelines and I am offended by what this government is trying to do. This government takes away the rights of growers to look after their industries, the rights of small business to get on with the job and the rights of workers to have a job. Now it seeks to take away the rights of children to have a childhood free of socialist engineering. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to completely refute something that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) said in relation to Senator Newman. Senator Crowley is completely wrong in suggesting that Senator Newman supports the government's accreditation program. She is misleading the parliament.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman has made speeches in the parliament and put out press statements rejecting the government's accreditation system. In a debate on 27 October, which appears on page 2613 of the Hansard, Senator Newman said:

SPEECH.PARA: A gun was placed at the head of the whole industry and it was told, `We are going ahead to have accreditation; do you want to consult or don't you?'. People who were dead against the concept were involved to the extent of finding out what was going on. Since the new council has been established to implement the accreditation, there has been no parental involvement at all and I understand that the representatives of the non-government sector are effectively not representatives at all. That is the first thing about which the minister was misleading the Senate.

Senator Newman has been in touch with us. I think it is absolutely reprehensible that the minister should try to mislead the parliament in relation to Senator Newman's statement when she well knows that Senator Newman is ill in hospital at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cowardly.
—It is a very cowardly attitude to take.
—Callous.
—It is callous in the extreme that she should misquote and try to mislead the parliament.
—She watched it on TV and she has rung up and denied it.
—She has been in contact and absolutely denies the statement made by Senator Crowley.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has always said that we would support a voluntary system of accreditation which was worked out in a fair and representative way with the industry. This system is compulsory and is rejected by the majority of the industry. Not only is that the case, but my information is that petitions signed by 21,000 people and 12,000-odd letters are on the way to the minister at the moment. If that is not an example of feeling by the parents within the community, then nothing is.Senator Newman and the coalition have never supported the government's program. We made this clear at the last election, and Senator Newman has made it clear since. Senator Crowley is obviously in trouble when she resorts to misleading the parliament.

The strength of opinion against the government's accreditation of child-care centres is building around the country. I am confident that within the next day or so it will snowball, as people become aware of what the government is attempting with the guidelines. Talkback shows around the country this morning, as Senator Crowley well knows, were deluged with calls by parents concerned about what the government is proposing. This is not something that parents want, and it is not something that the majority of the child-care industry wants.

It is still not too late for the Green senators and the Australian Democrats to reject the accreditation guidelines put forward by the government. There is time to do something about it. I appeal to them to do so. It is to be hoped that the widespread community concerns about accreditation are reflected in the Senate tomorrow, when the coalition will be seeking to have the accreditation guidelines disallowed.

The coalition is committed to quality child care, voluntary accreditation and the central role of parental choice in determining quality of care for children. It is interesting that accreditation is not being introduced because of concern expressed by parents. There has been no ground swell in the community pleading with the government for accreditation. It has not occurred. To try to mislead us by saying that this has been an industry driven and parental driven action is quite misleading as well.

This accreditation program is being introduced so that the big stick of denial of child-care assistance can be used to force parents to make the decision governments believe should be made. Who is to decide the quality of care of our children—the bureaucrats, or politicians, or the government? Surely it is the parents. The parents have the right to determine the quality of child care. The weight of public opinion against compulsory accreditation is now so great that Senator Crowley must act to address these concerns. The best thing she could do would be to withdraw the guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that the opposition is confused about this question. It is confusing voluntary accreditation with accreditation. I know that Senator Herron is doing a very good job in getting his head around this issue to take over the debate from Senator Newman.

PARA.TAB: I will just say it again for the record. I will read the quote which is on the record and which shows that what I said she said is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —You misled the parliament in respect of Senator Newman.

—Senator Herron used selective quoting. We have had a lot of selective quoting. This is what Senator Newman said on 27 October 1993, as recorded in Hansard at page 2613—Senator Herron did not read this bit:

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition supports voluntary accreditation.
I said before that the opposition, as Senator Newman said, supports accreditation. She supports a voluntary accreditation—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not use the word `voluntary'.

—If Senator Herron checks the Hansard, he will find that I was correct. I know exactly what Senator Newman has said. She stands for accreditation. She does not stand for compulsion. She has made that clear. She supports a voluntary program but she supports accreditation. All of the points that have been raised by Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran—
—You are playing with semantics.
—No, it is not playing with semantics.
—You said `voluntary accreditation'. It is not the same as `compulsory accreditation'.

—I did not ever say it was. I said that Senator Newman supports accreditation. The points raised by Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran go to the accreditation process. They have confused the issues of accreditation with the broader issues. They oppose the compulsion element of it. There is no dispute, as I understand it, from the opposition about that. But it is divided and confused about accreditation. That is the point I was making; that is the point I will make again and again.

PARA.TAB: The child-care industry committee that established these guidelines was made up of private sector representatives, community based representatives, early education teaching representatives, union representatives and parent representatives. All of those people designed these guidelines. These are their words for what describes best practice in child care. They are not the government's words. We accepted their recommendations in this area.

It is very well and good to mock selectively bits of the guidelines. If those opposite had ever been to a child-care centre, they would know what constitutes good quality care. In large part, it is described in that book of guidelines.

Secondly, the opposition has just discovered at the last moment what this is all about. This afternoon an opposition senator asked that we table the documents. They will have been on the table in this place for 15 sittings days come tomorrow. That shows the level of understanding in the opposition about this matter.

I make it clear that these guidelines were tested in a pilot study during 1992 when the guidelines were being described. The parents and the staff and operators of child-care centres who participated in that program found the guidelines to be very successful, very enjoyable and very helpful. There has been absolutely no criticism about them since from all of the people who were involved in the pilot program.

A large section of the private child-care industry strongly supports the accreditation and the accreditation process of the government with its connection to fee relief. They certainly do. What is happening is that a small section of the private industry, the Confederation of Child Care Associations, based in Victoria and with representatives in New South Wales, at the last moment is now opposing its own guidelines. This body had representatives on the committee which formulated these guidelines. It is now moving away from its own guidelines.

The confederation does not have the support of the whole sector. Large chunks of the private sector in Victoria strongly support the government's accreditation. Private child-care centres in Canberra met and declared their support for this accreditation process. The private child-care centres in Queensland—Senator O'Chee should tell Senator Boswell this—have not opposed this. They are in support of the accreditation process. A number of private operators, individuals, have very strongly made their support clear to government.

I am concerned about quality of care. I am concerned that parents know that when they leave their children in child care those children will be in a quality care place. The frenzied attack from the opposition at the last moment is misleading people; is creating confusion and huge anxiety out there. Either those opposite are for quality or they are not, and I understood from Senator Newman that they were. The point of difference is the voluntary aspect and fee relief. I made that clear in the answer that I gave. What Senator McGauran and Senator Boswell are doing is attacking the principles of accreditation, which the opposition agreed to. The opposition is divided on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard five minutes of the screamingly irrelevant from the minister who wants to abolish Christmas. Principle 21 of the guidelines, which Senator Crowley has enforced, sets out what is considered to be satisfactory and unsatisfactory in creative development and aesthetic awareness.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley considers unsatisfactory the constant repetition of Christmas songs as background music at the end of the year. This is the minister who wants to do away with Christmas. Elsewhere in these guidelines we find that it is considered merely basic—not good child care but merely basic—to have songs which are not culturally relevant for many children sung for special occasions such as Christmas. They may not be culturally relevant for a small number of children, but I think most people, certainly most children, in this country would seem to think that Christmas is fairly relevant to them.

What we have from the other side of the chamber is just another attempt at the socialist social engineering process. Some of these guidelines are a nonsense. Senator Crowley has suggested that we on this side of the chamber are divided over this garbage. The only division we have on this side of the chamber is that we cannot work out whether to laugh or cry. Let us look at principle No. 3—this is wonderful stuff. The principle states that it is unsatisfactory for staff at a child-care centre not to encourage children to enter into activities that are traditionally regarded as more appropriate to the other sex; and that it is unsatisfactory for staff to provide stereotype toys such as trains, tip trucks and bulldozers for boys and dolls and tea sets for girls. Well, Senator Crowley, boys like playing with trains. Boys like playing with tip trucks and girls like dolls. Senator Crowley may wish she had the chance to play with tip trucks and bulldozers when she was a girl, but most boys do not like playing with dolls.

We have had one concession to reality from Senator Crowley. It is good quality child care, we are told, for staff to consistently provide equal opportunities for boys and girls to participate in all activities, play with all materials, play vigorously on outdoor equipment, express a range of emotion and contribute to discussion. Principle 3 goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff recognise that this need not extend to minor areas such as expecting boys to dress up in female clothes if this conflicts with family expectations.

In other words, if the parents do not say that a boy is not allowed to wear a tutu, he can be made to cross-dress. What is the message from this? The message from these guidelines is very simple: under this government, send your children to preschool so they can learn to dress in drag. That is what it is all about. This is the minister for having kiddies dress in drag. Some of this stuff is incredible.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley, who has her head in the sand pit—I assume, as Senator Boswell said, to make sure that the girls are not making too many mud pies—seems to think that there is widespread support for this garbage. Mr Deputy President, 12,500 letters have been written to the minister complaining about this gobbledegook and 21,500 names are on a petition which is going to be coming either to the minister or to this place, and that is just the start. When the parents out there start to hear about this sort of rubbish they will really be up in arms. They will be absolutely outraged. I do not know what Senator Crowley and her advisers have against Christmas, I do not know what they have about boys playing with trucks or girls playing with dolls, but let us get one thing clear: I am sorry, Rosemary, but the Australian population doesn't agree with you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator O'Chee—

—I am sorry—Senator Crowley. The Australian population does not agree with Senator Crowley. They want Christmas, they want their kids to be able to play in the playground, they do not want their children to have to cross-dress, and when it comes to Christmas, they do not want to be scrooged.

—We have heard a great deal today about cross-dressing, the abolition of Christmas, people dressing in drag, sandpits and, of course, Christmas carols. We have heard a great deal about what is right and what is wrong. I am afraid that what we have failed to hear today is what the Australian people understand to be what is right and what is wrong. What we saw in the last election is that the people were very clear about what was right and what was wrong. They were not prepared to put up with this sort of reactionary nonsense, the sort of attitude that stems straight out of 1955: the black and white view of the world; the attitude that everyone has to fit into nice, neat, little boxes; the attitude that only people who go to church on Sunday—the church that those opposite go to on Sunday—are the sort of people that those opposite want to see in this country. What we see is an understanding by this government that Australian society has changed. What we see is a government that understands that there is a whole range of expectations—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Carr made a reference to a particular church as though that church was contaminated with some sort of stereotype. I do not think that is parliamentary and it is certainly offensive to people who go to church. Will you ask Senator Carr to withdraw that remark.
—I did not detect what was said. But if what was said was in the terms you have set out, it is not contrary to standing orders.
—It was as stated.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
—I have ruled on the point of order.
—I would like to make it clear that what Senator Boswell said is a complete misrepresentation of what was said.

—It has to be understood that this government is committed to a couple of very basic things concerning child care. It is committed to the creation of 161,000 places over 10 years. That is the critical issue that the people of this country are concerned about. They are concerned about the quality and the cost of that service. They want to be assured that their kids are placed in care where professional service is provided. They want to understand that they are getting good treatment, good value for money and that their kids will be safe and well looked after. They are not interested in this sort of hysterical crap that we have heard here today.
—Order! That is thoroughly unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. We have to understand what is right and what is wrong. At the last election the people of this country demonstrated what was right and what was wrong. The Victorian Liberal government has its own gender equity proposals and programs. The document entitled Gender Equity—A Fair Go For Everyone: Guidelines for Staffing Children's Services was published by Mr Gude's department this year. It goes through a whole series of issues which senators opposite should be concerned about, but we do not hear them say a word about that.

PARA.TAB: Right across this country there is a clear understanding of the need to ensure that services of a high quality are provided and of the fact that real changes in our country are occurring as our society changes. The Victorian government says there is a need to develop gender equity policies to ensure that people have a fair go in this country. This is aimed at ensuring that children are provided with realistic opportunities and are able to develop as full human beings, rather than having to conform to some sort of stereotype that those opposite thought existed in 1955.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran asked his question today because he feels greatly for the freedom of families to bring up their children in the best way they see fit. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that future Australian society will not be inspired and helped by this new accreditation. It is right and proper that he should publicise the details of these guidelines so that parents and child-care centres across the country can find out what the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) proposes and what she has in mind for them.

PARA.TAB: This government appears to read only the front cover of the reports that are put in front of it. It is another Minister Kelly performance. Minister Crowley can talk as long as she likes, but in her heart of hearts she knows that she does not really support many of these guidelines.

The Senate will remember that Minister Kelly identified all farmers as people who degraded their land. According to Mrs Kelly, Australian farmers—who happen to be the best, probably the most efficient and the least subsidised farmers in the world—degraded their land. She was identified as a fool and now Senator Crowley is falling into the same category.

These accreditation guidelines are for real. But one could be mistaken for thinking they were a skit by Magda Szubanski from Fast Forward. I think Senator O'Chee made that very clear. This government is in the hands of the politically correct agenda setters. We cannot legislate to make people behave with propriety and decency. The government ought to wake up. People are ringing Senator Crowley's office because they are concerned, and so they should be. They are ringing because they object to the guidelines. The minister should scrap them.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue has captured a degree of public attention. When looking at the colleagues of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), who were sitting behind her as she blundered on through her answers, I felt that there is great concern not only on this side of the Parliament about what has happened. It would not surprise me that when this debate is finished she will go back to her office and find a message on her desk saying, `Senator Crowley, phone Mr Keating urgently'. Perhaps because of the poor advice she has received from some people, or perhaps because, to use the Ros Kelly defence, she did not read this material carefully enough, she has trampled on the values of most Australians.
—You trite fool.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! Senator Schacht, you know that is unparliamentary. I would be grateful if you would withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.
—This is not the first or last time that we will be seeing the Labor Party act in a totally authoritarian and manipulative manner regarding social customs in this country.

PARA.TAB: I guess I am pretty typical of many parents on Senator Crowley's side of the chamber. What does she think average Australians think when they read that it is unsatisfactory to provide toys such as trains, tip trucks and bulldozers for boys? Senator Crowley and the Australian Labor Party should get real. Most parents have actually given trains, tip trucks and bulldozers to their sons and have not suffered any embarrassment. Indeed, they have seen their children grow up, hopefully, in good health and with strong values as proud Australians. Equally, I confess—I say this on the public record—that I have given some dolls to my daughter in the past. I would not like any of Senator Crowley's Gestapo coming around, checking out my house and saying, `Senator Kemp is giving trucks to his son and dolls to his daughter'. This is what these silly guidelines say.

In the 550 guidelines that Senator Crowley has laid down there may well be some 500 which are perfectly satisfactory. I have not had time to read all of them carefully. There are a number there which are just plain damn stupid. They trample on ordinary Australian values. If only she could see the faces of her colleagues behind her when she attempted to explain her position in these matters. I have no query with the statement that staff should consistently provide equal opportunities for boys and girls to participate in all activities. But then the minister goes on to say that the staff recognise that this need not extend to minor areas, such as expecting boys to dress up in female clothes `if this conflicts with family expectations'.

Most Australian fathers are really happy to have their boys dressed as boys. It is no big deal. I suggest that to put something so profoundly silly and idiotic in the guidelines shows a total lack of balance and understanding of ordinary Australian families. On a number of occasions I have said that the Labor Party is so out of touch with ordinary Australians. This is not the Labor Party of old. This is the Keating Labor party of regency furniture, John Gould prints and trouble with the domestics at the palace. This is the new Labor Party and Senator Crowley has nothing in common with the Labor Party of old. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to contribute some rationality to this debate—
—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion that, notwithstanding anything contained in standing orders, Estimates Committee A reconvene as soon as possible to consider the dismissal of staff and the purchase of furnishings at the Prime Minister's Lodge, and that the committee report to the Senate on or before Monday, 6 December 1993.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to an inquiry by Estimates Committee A into the dismissal of staff and the purchase of furnishings at the Prime Minister's Lodge.

SPEECH.PARA: On 16 November of this year, three of my colleagues, Senator Kemp, Senator O'Chee and Senator Troeth, wrote to the Chairman of Senate Estimates Committee A, Senator Childs, asking that Estimates Committee A be reconvened to consider several matters. The first related to dismissal of domestic staff at the Lodge and the second related to the attempted acquisition of a new dining table for the Lodge. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this letter to Senator Childs.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator B Childs
Chairman
Estimates Committee A
16 November 1993
Dear Senator Childs,

We request that a meeting of Estimates Committee A be convened to examine possible inconsistencies between evidence given to the Committee at its supplementary meeting on 8 November by the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Evans, and evidence which has subsequently emerged in relation to two matters:
1.The dismissal of domestic staff at The Lodge;

We ask that the Committee examine the apparent inconsistencies between the statements made by the Minister during the supplementary hearing, and the statement subsequently issued by two of the staff through their lawyers; and
2.The attempted acquisition of a new dining table for The Lodge.
We ask that the Committee examine the apparent inconsistencies between evidence put to the Committee, and material now available as a result of an application under the Freedom of Information Act.

We also note that, while the Minister refused to table documents in the Committee hearing pending the processing of the FOI application, the FOI process is now complete and the documents should be tabled.
The Committee should also consider whether, pursuant to the relevant Sessional Order, it should table a supplementary report in the light of the further evidence .
Yours sincerely,
SENATOR R KEMP
SENATOR W O'CHEE
SENATOR J TROETH

TALK.START.PARA: —Arising out of the first hearing of the estimates committee, there were certainly suggestions that the committee had been misled. In relation to the staff at the Lodge, the allegation is that they were misled on two matters. Firstly, there was an implication that the two housekeepers had credit cards and that they had failed to account for use of those credit cards in a way that was required by the department. The second issue is that they had been warned by the department that they would have to change their ways in relation to certain difficulties that were occurring in staff matters. Both of those issues were put on the record by Ms Tinney of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in the Estimates Committee A hearing on 8 November 1993.

PARA.TAB: Subsequent to that, a statement was issued by solicitors for the two housekeepers which made clear that one of them did not even have a credit card to use on behalf of the department. Also, they both alleged that they received no warning of any dissatisfaction or any allegation of wrongdoing in relation to their work by the department. The situation is totally unsatisfactory in that the allegations made by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet are refuted by the housekeepers. Therefore, either the estimates committee was misled or the housekeepers are, in fact, incorrectly misleading the community at large. Obviously, that matter should be clarified and obviously the estimates committee should be reconvened in order that it be clarified. As I said, on the face of it at the moment, it would suggest that the parliament has been misled and it cannot be allowed to lie in that condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two or three staff members?

—Two housekeepers. The second matter concerned Mrs Betteridge who found that it was in her best interests to retire from the department after a telephone call from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Of course, the Prime Minister had gone public and said that it was Mrs Betteridge who had found the famous Thai teak table, when evidence put before the estimates committee—actually, it was not put before the estimates committee, it had to come out in subsequent papers that were tabled—was to the effect that she had been directed to the Prime Minister's friend, Mr Kenny, by the Prime Minister, and that was where the table was to be sourced. Again, there is contradictory evidence on the record of the estimates committee that needs to be clarified.

PARA.TAB: In normal circumstances, when this occurs the chairman recalls the estimates committee and the matter is settled. But in this instance, the chairman refused to do so, and it was necessary for members on our side to write to the chairman and request that he reconvene the committee. The astonishing thing is that the government has now used its numbers on that committee by a vote today to refuse to reconvene the hearing of that committee in order that this matter be settled.

The government is allowing the situation to remain where, on the record, it would appear that the parliament has been misled. That is totally unsatisfactory. The government has clearly got something to hide otherwise it would not be abusing the process in this way; it would be allowing the estimates committee to meet and complete its task and be able to report correctly to the parliament. Therefore, this chamber should override the decision of the Labor majority on that committee and require the committee to be reconvened and this matter settled.

This is another test for the Australian Democrats and the Greens to see whether they are prepared to make an effort to keep this government honest, whether they are prepared to say to Labor, `We are not going to allow you to abuse the committee process in this way; we are going to require this committee to be reconvened, that further evidence be taken and this matter settled'. I move the suspension of standing orders in order that I might move the substantive motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, may I say that we oppose this suspension of standing orders. This is just another political stunt by the opposition.
—And wasting time.

—Yes, it is a complete waste of time. The opposition does not want to debate the substantive issues of legislation. I believe those opposite probably do not want to debate the industrial relations legislation, nor do they want to debate Mabo. With all these fundamental issues before us, they do not have any idea other than to say no. They have no alternative idea so the idea is to keep moving the suspension of standing orders every day on some other political stunt. This is all about getting down into the gutter or the sewer to smear people's reputations and, in particular, that of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: We saw a stunt in here during question time and just after with the most beat-up interpretation one could imagine about child-care rules and regulations and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally misleading.
—Absolutely misleading. We had one ranking senator on the other side saying it is the end of Christmas. I suppose anyone with his intelligence cannot think as far ahead as Christmas.
—No wonder they are in opposition.
—Yes, it is no wonder they are in opposition; they are the classic opposition of all time. They are the heirs of Bill Hartley and the Labor Party on how to lose elections and keep losing.

PARA.TAB: We have talked about the case of the two staff at the Lodge. I presume that those opposite want to recall Estimates Committee A to call people together so that some members of the opposition can show the public how hairy chested they are in abusing public servants and others in the style that Bronwyn Bishop has made infamous in Australia—substituting rudeness and abuse for logic. That is what they want to do with Estimates Committee A.

Under the laws of Australia, under the conciliation and arbitration act, people have the right to appeal against unfair dismissal, including the staff of the Lodge. What utter hypocrisy it is for the opposition to say, `We want to have an Estimates Committee A hearing because these people have been unfairly dealt with', when we know that its industrial relations policy is to abolish the conciliation and arbitration act, to remove all the provisions for unfair dismissal and to go down the Kennett road and make workers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Slaves.

—Good point. The opposition would make workers slaves to the employer with no rights. Under the existing federal legislation, which we will support here, to maintain workers rights, if staff at the Lodge believe they have been unfairly dismissed, they can use all the provisions of the legislation to have a fair hearing, to put their case and to have it properly adjudicated.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, can you imagine Estimates Committee A being fair? It will be a kangaroo court, with maniacs from the opposition screaming and shouting at public servants on the basis of wanting to smear the reputation of public servants and the Prime Minister.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! Senator Schacht, I think you should withdraw your reference to `maniacs from the opposition'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. There is no doubt that the opposition has not the slightest concern for the interests of the staff members who were dismissed. Those opposite see them purely as a political totem which enables them to abuse public servants.

PARA.TAB: Over the last four or five years in this place, those opposite have shown us policies on industrial relations which would smash ordinary workers, remove their rights and destroy the whole system of conciliation and arbitration in this country. That is what John Howard is about; that is what Jeff Kennett is about; and that is what Mr Court is about in Western Australia—to remove workers' rights so that no worker in the future will have the right to an unfair dismissal claim. When any worker is sacked in Australia in the future, all those opposite will offer will be to call Estimates Committee A together and have three demented Liberal senators screaming and shouting at public servants. That is the treatment; that is the basis of the opposition's industrial relations policy.

It is utterly fraudulent for those opposite to move the suspension of standing orders in order to call back Estimates Committee A. They are not concerned at all about the rights of those workers. Those workers have the right, established by this government, to appeal against unfair dismissal under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, a principle this government has adopted over many years. Those opposite want to destroy all that and substitute for it a circus called Estimates Committee A. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Hill on the motion for the suspension of standing orders to allow the Senate to debate the motion to allow Senate Estimates Committee A to re-examine the issues of staffing at the Lodge and the purchasing of furniture at the Lodge. We have moved this motion simply because the evidence that was given to Estimates Committee A seriously conflicts on both these issues with other material which has emerged since the estimates committees convened.We do not need to be spoken to by Senator Schacht about fairness to ordinary workers. He is part of a government that has created a million unemployed and I would think that most Labor people would be hanging their heads in shame.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that emerges here is not how good to the workers the government is in theory or what the party platform is; but how does it actually treat them—how does it deal with these people—when it is put to the test? More importantly, how does the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) deal with these people?

Let us take the case of the housekeepers. Let me get this clear: the housekeepers themselves have asked for an independent inquiry into this matter; the housekeepers themselves would support a reconvening of the Senate estimates committee so that additional questions can be asked. As I have pointed out, there are serious conflicts which have emerged between the evidence given at the committee by public servants and ministers and the information that has been given out since.

Let me list three key areas of conflict which have occurred. Were the staff members given fair warning? The answer is they were not. Although assurances were given by Senator Gareth Evans both today and in the estimates committee, they were not given a fair warning. Secondly, the issue of the use of credit cards has emerged. The housekeepers themselves have denied on a number of occasions that there was any issue in relation to this matter, but Senator Evans chose again to make this particular allegation against these people. The third issue which has emerged is: what were the reasons for these two housekeepers, who had given loyal service to the Prime Minister, being dismissed? According to what was told to the housekeepers, it was staff restructuring; according to the evidence given at Senate Estimates Committee A, it was difficult interpersonal relations. Clear conflicts.

I put it to the Senate that these two individuals themselves want to have the chance to make sure that the record is put straight. We have had the reputations and names of these two workers traduced both in the Senate estimates committee and before this parliament today. In fairness to them, I believe it is important that the estimates committee be reconvened. I certainly put it to Senator Harradine, the Australian Democrats and the Greens that this is a motion which deserves their strongest possible support.

In relation to the other matter, I can understand the sensitivity of the Labor Party. I would be sensitive if a Liberal Prime Minister was concerned about Regency furniture in the Lodge and the need to import a Thai teak table. I would be concerned if a Liberal Prime Minister decided to spend $100,000 on Gould prints for the cabinet room. I put it to the Senate that in the evidence that was given to the committee on this particular matter there was an attempt to convey the impression that it was the decision of the Public Service to purchase this Thai teak table. The evidence which has come out since shows that, indeed, the Prime Minister was the driving force behind it.

There are substantial reasons for this Senate estimates committee to be recalled to examine the misleading and inconsistent evidence which was clearly given to the earlier hearings of the committee on November 8. This is a motion which I believe is grounded in principle that should be strongly supported. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —More than two political generations ago in the United States Senate, a junior Republican senator from Wisconsin by the name of Joseph R. McCarthy had to make the key political decision of his career: whether he was going to make the St Lawrence seaway the issue on which he made his name, or the Communist Party in the United States of America. He chose the latter course. He used and abused the American congressional system over the ensuing half-decade or more. He used and abused that system in a way in which some opposite are suggesting this chamber ought to go—to have people hauled before it, to throw overboard conventions and precedents, and to toss aside the alternative legal framework that the country has built up during the past century.

PARA.TAB: There is no question of fairness involved in this. There is no doubt that Estimates Committee A is an inappropriate body to deal with these matters. Estimates Committee A is not a tribunal of fact; it is not an industrial tribunal. It has no powers of arbitration; it has no powers of intervention; it has no powers of redress. It cannot order that the housekeepers be reinstated, for example; it cannot make an appropriate award in terms of recompense; and, what is more, it sets an appalling precedent for other industrial circumstances within the Commonwealth's jurisdiction for the future.

For those reasons alone, this proposition of Senator Hill's ought to be rejected outright. We are again seeing a simple exercise in political frustration. Some elements of the coalition are determined, by any means available to them, to denigrate the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Mr Acting Deputy President, no-one suggests that the Prime Minister or his family had anything to do with the determination in respect of the housekeepers. But some members of the opposition believe it is a way in which the Prime Minister might be damaged in passage. There is such a malignant approach evident in some members of the coalition that virtually any issue which touches upon the Prime Minister is pursued with a zeal that does the people involved no credit at all.

I simply ask in the Senate this afternoon: when we have issues as important as Mabo—which, frankly, will be of great significance to the future of Australia—and industrial relations, where is the sense of priorities, where is the sense of obligation to the country, and where is the sense of responsibility?

I heard Senator Hill say something in an aside to Senator Evans earlier in the week when I asked a question on APEC and Senator Evans rose to answer it. Senator Hill said—and it did him no credit, in my view—`Now we will bring you back to the real world'. He was not referring to APEC; he was referring to the type of political sludge that we have seen in the chamber over previous weeks. I thought it was appalling. I trusted that Senator Hill was better than that; I believe he is. I hope that it was simply an aberration.

There were very good and cogent reasons why Estimates Committee A chose not to proceed with these matters. It would not have been the second time we had looked at these issues; it would have been the third. I have no doubt that it would not have been the final time if we had agreed. Some elements in the coalition would have wanted Estimates Committee A to continue meeting right through Christmas if they thought some tangential damage could be done to the Prime Minister or his family.

In respect of the matter before us, the unfortunate reality is—and I say to Senator Kemp that I do not mean this in any provocative way—that a great part of the coalition has no concept of industrial relations, of industrial relations practices, as Senator Murphy understands and as Senator Harradine understands. The simple fact of the matter is that within the ACT framework or within the federal framework there are appropriate industrial tribunals open to the two former housekeepers to take their case. They have legal representation. We know that for a fact. Letters have been written. There are appropriate industrial tribunals available to the two former housekeepers that do have powers of intervention and redress. Estimates Committee A does not.

This is not a matter of the public revenue. It is a simple matter of political malice on the part of some in the coalition. It would be absolutely and utterly appalling if Estimates Committee A were obliged to resume yet again. Unfortunately, part of the coalition does not appreciate the realities of industrial relations.The proposition from Senator Hill would take us precisely nowhere. The tribunal is not a tribunal of fact.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I call Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was up first.
—Order! Senator Burns, I have called Senator Short.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. We have recently had two speakers from that side running because Senator Reynolds did not jump quickly enough. I was first to my feet on this occasion. There is no reason that the call should be given to the other side.
—I will continue to call from alternate sides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I support Senator Hill's call for the reconvening of Estimates Committee A to consider what I think most people on both sides of the chamber would now accept was inconsistent evidence at the estimates hearings about the dismissal of the two staff from the Lodge and the clear conflict of evidence that has been presented. With due respect to Senator Loosley opposite, I doubt that I have heard five minutes of more misleading, pious sophistry in my whole life than he put forward in defence of the government's approach to this matter. I do not know what the government is going to do. The bunch of Pontius Pilates opposite are all attempting to wash their hands of what has quite clearly been a miscarriage of the proper process of employer-staff relations. Indeed, in doing what they are doing, they are in conflict with the bill that they have just circulated in the Senate today—their Industrial Relations Reform Bill.
—Not so. Tell us how you were going to deal with it.
—Let me tell those opposite what is in their bill.
—You people opposed compulsory arbitration.
—I know those opposite have not got an argument but what about listening to one. Section 170DB of the bill that the government is presenting today says:

SPEECH.PARA: An employer must not terminate an employee's employment unless

PARA.TAB: (a) the employee has been given either the period of notice required by subsection (2), or compensation instead of notice; or
(b) the employee is guilty of serious misconduct, that is, misconduct of a kind such that it would be unreasonable to require the employer to continue the employment during the notice period.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection 2 goes on to give the required period of notice under the government's bill, its policy and its industrial relations approach, which is worked out on the basis of the employee's period of continuous service with the employer. The period of notice, depending on that, ranges between at least one week and at least four weeks.

PARA.TAB: We know from the evidence given in Estimates Committee A that not only were those periods of notice prescribed in the present bill not given, but no notice was given at all. I quote from Estimates Committee A Hansard of 8 November, page 277, where the representative of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mrs Tinney, said:

SPEECH.PARA: They were not warned that they would be sacked.

Quite clearly, the fundamental point of an essential part of the Labor Party's own policy has been brutally breached. In the process of doing that, we have had the greatest filibustering and shibboleths mounted in this parliament in recent days, the worst of which was from Senator Evans today where there was a massive impugning of the reputation of those two employees. That performance by Senator Evans today was an absolute disgrace. Now the government is going to compound the felony by preventing a properly constituted committee of this Senate investigating the circumstances and the conflicting evidence that have already been given.

PARA.TAB: There is a classic case here of hypocrisy and double standards on the part of this government. But, more importantly, if we in this Senate are going to allow conflicting, misleading evidence to be given to the Senate through estimates committees or in whatever form, then we are doing a great disservice to the Senate generally and, in this particular case, we are doing a great disservice to two employees, who one would have thought deserved better from the person who purports to be the leader of this nation, but whose actions over a long time now and increasingly over recent weeks and months should deny any thought that he is truly the leader of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposition that this matter should not go to Estimates Committee A. I do so on the basis not of going to the heart or the moral of the issue but because I am quite convinced as a result of chairing estimates committee meetings over time that this will only give an opportunity for senators on the opposite side to go in for point scoring. The last thing in their minds will be the interests of or justice for the two employees concerned. For approximately 32 of the last 44 years we have had Liberal-National Party governments in this place. I first began my career or my role in industrial relations in 1957. It continued for some 30 years, until 1987.
—Did you work at all then?

—On many occasions I worked as a boilermaker and as a part-time official of a union, as well. Continuously during that time we were told by the government of the day, that is, the Liberal-National party government, that the arbitration commission was the place to go to settle disputes. The government continually said, `Go to the umpire. Accept the umpire's decision'. There were times when we did that. The organisation I belonged to did that and so did many other unions. On some occasions we were able to get what we thought was a favourable result; we would have called it justice. On other occasions we did not. But one thing was certain—we did understand that the people in the commission had some expertise in making a decision or making recommendations to the parties about, for instance, unfair dismissals. Because of that experience they were able to make fairly objective decisions in many cases. It is true that the trade union movement has not always abided by this idea of going to the umpire; it always tries to kick a couple of goals before it calls the umpire on to the field.

PARA.TAB: But the facts here are clear: two people have been dismissed and there is an argument about the correctness of it. I know a situation like this is different from, for example, someone being dismissed in a fairly large organisation because of the closeness of the interrelationship between people who are employed in a household. However, it is not beyond the capacity of the Industrial Relations Commission to consider it and, I believe, come down with a reasonable proposition.

For 32 years the trade unions have been subdued with fines. Now the opposition says, `Don't go to the commission and abide by the umpire'. Those opposite should stop being hypocrites. I suggest that people go through the arbitration system. If they are not members of the relevant union, they can become members of it, be represented and their case can be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full employment. You guys never delivered.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! Senator Kemp!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not mind; he might run out of breath a bit. They should go to the arbitration system and have their case considered in the way that those opposite have suggested for 32 years.

—As a member of Senate Estimates Committee A, I support Senator Hill's motion for the reconvening of the committee. We are not trying to act in the position of arbitrator; we are simply trying to establish the truth from the conflicting statements that we have been presented with.

PARA.TAB: We wish to recall Estimates Committee A for the simple reason that, during the entire time that these questions have been asked, more information has come out which is tending to muddy the pool altogether so that the true position has not been made clear. First, we wish to establish which particular person instigated the purchase of the table that was to be installed at the Lodge. Secondly, we wish to establish whether the two employees who were dismissed from the Lodge were given fair warning of their dismissal.
I asked that question of Senator Gareth Evans today, but he did not answer. He prevaricated and gave an extremely convoluted answer as to whether they had been given a fair warning.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I apologise for having taking up the time of the Senate. In case the motion for the suspension of standing orders is not accepted and we do not have time to debate the issue itself, I would like to say this: I am concerned lest the estimates committees' procedures become fatigued by imposing upon them functions which are not inherently theirs and for which remedies are available to aggrieved persons in other jurisdictions.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission which was established in January this year. Commissioner Michael Dodson took up his appointment on 26 April, and this report covers the period from January to 30 June. It is a very significant and important report because the commission itself is also significant and important.

PARA.TAB: The report is comprehensive. It is very detailed and, given that it effectively covers an operational period of about three months, I am quite surprised by the extent of the issues canvassed and the detail. Obviously, Commissioner Dodson and others have a background of very detailed and comprehensive work in this arena over a long period. No doubt, this enabled them, in the first three months, to address such a quick build up of issues.

I note that chapter 1 of the report is addressed `Native Title'; chapter 2, `Self Determination'; chapter 3, `Education: Awareness'; chapter 4, `International Issues'; and, chapter 5, `Powers, Functions, Responsibilities, Resources'. As native title legislation is currently before the House of Representatives and will come before the Senate, it would be inopportune at this stage to comment on the section of the report relating to native title, other than to say that Commissioner Dodson obviously takes a very different viewpoint from that of the government. The agenda which he addresses in this report would, in effect, take many of the principles of native title much further than the government has done. I certainly draw the attention of honourable senators and other people to that very important aspect in respect of compensation or other issues.

The areas that are addressed with regard to self-determination, education and international issues require a considerable amount of very early attention. We would want to ensure that the proposals being put forward by Commissioner Dodson do not, in effect, try to lead the Labor Party or the federal government into any new agenda that relates to international and very special issues.

From my cursory reading of this report—it has been tabled only today—I draw attention to those parts of the report that almost imply that many Australian systems and institutions ought to be bypassed and that we should go directly to international agreements and arrangements of the United Nations in respect of areas that relate to Aborigines and indigenous people. I draw attention to the quite significant section of the report that relates to those issues. They certainly need to be canvassed and it is important that they be debated. I would hope that, at some future stage, there will be opportunities in the Senate for us to address these very important issues, particularly on behalf of Aboriginal people.

The whole issue of self-determination, particularly—as Senator Boswell has said in this place—relating to the Torres Strait Islands, needs very special attention. There are areas in the report that pick up the principles of self-government for Aborigines. Again, these are new concepts that I think tend to march the agenda much further than native title.

The new structure of the commission is set out towards the end of the report. I note that the commission will comprise some 24 staff personnel. That will obviously be a very expensive and very well resourced area of structural arrangement for government, and it will be important to look at a number of the issues that were addressed last year.
