Commissioner Dodson's own appointment has not been without controversy. As honourable senators will see from the rear of the report, his background is one of a Public Service career; he has not worked in the private sector. Commissioner Dodson has been closely associated with Aboriginal interests. In recent years, he has been the Director of the Northern Land Council and he has been integrally involved with the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account in the Northern Territory. The administration over the last few years of these two organisations is under very severe criticism and will be the subject of an important Auditor-General's report to this parliament in several weeks time. Commissioner Dodson's performance needs to be judged in light of that report which will be tabled here shortly. Then, in the future, we must assess the work that he does in respect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In this, the International Year of Indigenous People, it is more than appropriate that the first Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission report be tabled in the Senate today. The issues raised in the report and the legal and historical context in which they are developed reflect both the major issues of profound concern to indigenous communities and also challenges which other Australians have faced in the past and will have to face in the future.

PARA.TAB: The importance of the report might not be immediately apparent to many readers, but the issues raised in terms of rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples will no doubt become important agenda items in this place and in other forums concerned with the rights of indigenous people. We have seen in the press in recent times new arguments and actions being taken by Australia's indigenous people. This report gives some of the intellectual and legal analyses on which these actions are being taken. On this I congratulate the commission.

The capacity of the commissioner to fully understand his task is clearly shown in a number of areas. Senator Tambling referred to the way in which the report is set out. Attention is given to issues which are listed under various headings. Commissioner Dodson quotes what was said by Michael Duffy, the then Attorney-General, when speaking on the creation of the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. Mr Duffy said:

SPEECH.PARA: But there continues to exist a need for us as a nation to regularly focus on the extent to which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are able to exercise the basic human rights that the rest of the nation take for granted.

He then said that the creation of this office would provide this focus. One could have considered that it would have been appropriate to fill that position with someone of the Caucasian race with background knowledge and understanding and sympathy towards the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cause. The government did not do that. It appointed an Aboriginal, Michael Dodson. The commissioner states in the report:
Criticism of the Commonwealth by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner may be seen as `biting the hand that feeds you'. . .

That is not the way it was set up. The government was quite prepared to give a person that responsibility within a certain framework and expect him to undertake the task in an objective and proper manner. He goes on to say:
There must necessarily exist a certain structural tension between the performance of my functions and the Commonwealth Government.

That is an acceptable situation as far as I am concerned. People do have certain biases and they may have a certain emphasis on issues that others do not. They may have been affected by matters personally and thus have a deep feeling about a particular issue. He further states:
It is my strong belief that the criterion for selection should be amended to require any future Commissioner to be an indigenous person.

I accept that that is a reasonable proposition. However, I would prefer to see a situation where that was not so but where people took that into consideration and were wise enough to appoint somebody of that race and from that particular background.

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner then goes on to recognise that there might be people who have an attitude towards him. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to be identified as an `Aboriginal leader' and appointed by the Commonwealth to a position of influence may be viewed by some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as being co-opted by government.

For instance, this could refer to selling out. I think this report dispels any thought that anyone might have in that direction. He certainly did not do that and he states that he is not of that view. He then goes on to say in the report:

It is of critical importance, if I am to genuinely fulfil my Commission, that I accurately reflect the experience and aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples throughout Australia. To this end, I will not only consult, as I am obliged to, with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission but will also consult with community organisations and individual communities as much as possible.

Again that shows his appreciation that his view is not the only one and that he is there to look after the interests of a wide group of people and races in the community and he says he is prepared to do so. He must be commended for that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission report. I have not had time to fully read this document, but I was particularly interested to turn to the chapter entitled `International issues'. I suggest that honourable senators would be interested to read that chapter. It outlines in a very comprehensive way the international obligations that Australia has acquired through the signing of a wide variety of UN treaties, covenants and so on. There is an explanation of the particular articles which are relevant to the commission and it goes through in some detail the impact that these particular covenants will have on Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have not had time to closely read the material. It does raise some interesting issues for the nation. The obligations are acquired through the treaty arrangement, not because the treaties have passed through the Australian parliament but because they have been signed by the executive government. Often many of the rights which are specified are rights that most Australians in principle would subscribe to. We have to understand that, where obligations are acquired by the nation in a domestic sense, the way democracies do that is through parliament. I have a qualification there.

The report draws our attention to the importance of a recent government decision to allow domestic cases to be ultimately appealed to United Nations committees. I do not think that is disputed at all in the community. In doing this, the government has taken a very significant and important decision. It is a decision which overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act, and honourable senators will remember that that act severed links with the Privy Council. Five years later Mr Keating, Mr Hawke and Senator Evans, with their love affair with the UN, decided to ratify the first optional protocol which allowed Australian domestic disputes relating to human rights to ultimately be appealed to the United Nations.

I do not think most Australians knew the importance of this decision. The government made a brief press release on this matter, but it has not puffed its chest out about it—no wonder. In a period of growing Australian nationalism, I think most Australians would be a little surprised that we have decided to involve UN committees in the Australian legal system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good one!

—There is a third aspect of this report which Senator Reynolds, who is shaking her head, might care to look at. If we accept that we should overturn the philosophy of the Australia Act and we decide that it is appropriate that the UN does have a role in a range of domestic disputes, then we have to ask what the quality of these committees is like. Are these committees appropriately structured to deal with Australian cases which go to them? I have pointed out in this chamber on a number of occasions that these committees do not meet Australian standards of independence, judicial process and the normal standards of conduct of a court which we would expect of our own courts and bodies dealing with important cases such as these.

PARA.TAB: Some members on these committees are nominated by governments which frankly are a disgrace on the human rights front. To think that these people would be making rules on human rights issues in Australia is offensive to Australians. I would see this as a growing issue. I certainly recognise that if one does not believe in the Australia Act and one overturns the philosophy and one believes that UN committees should become involved in Australian cases, then at least those people have a role to ensure that those committees are appropriately structured.

I think the report illustrates what I have been saying. These are important decisions and we should not hide from them. The report states that it expects many of the cases to go to these UN committees and quotes another report which mentions that a significant proportion of all Australian cases are anticipated to come from indigenous peoples.
I think that is a very significant statement. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to congratulate Commissioner Dodson on his first report. Senator Burns has indicated that it is a very important and significant occasion for the commissioner to report in this International Year of Indigenous People. I am disappointed that Senator Tambling and Senator Kemp seem a little more preoccupied with other agendas, instead of focusing on the significance of the social justice report.

PARA.TAB: I think that Commissioner Dodson has been very honest in his assessment of the necessary tension in his role. I would like to read from his speech delivered at the launch of the report. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So delivering this first report is both a satisfying and a disturbing task. Satisfying in that it marks a commitment from the Commonwealth to confronting the issues honestly; disturbing because of the truth of those issues.
In fact, as the first Commissioner, I find myself in a role fraught with tensions.

Nevertheless, I believe that in establishing my commission the government has acknowledged that constructive criticism is necessary for a vital democracy. It is my earnest hope that any tension between my commission and the commonwealth government will be creative and constructive.

That brings me to some of the references that have been made in this place and others about social justice issues. The whole question of the native title legislation creates tension certainly in the parliament and in the community. Australians have moved to a new place in history where we do have to view indigenous people from a totally different perspective than we have historically done so.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that Commissioner Dodson has been quite critical of the welfare based model of government policies in a number of areas. As someone who has worked to ensure that governments around Australia do focus on the needs of Aboriginal and Islander people, I was a little concerned when I first read of that criticism. But I read further and saw that Commissioner Dodson was saying that governments have to look beyond the welfare based dependency that we have in some ways created for indigenous people. We have to be brave enough to ensure that, while those fundamental service provisions have to be there, we look beyond those services to self-determination and genuine self-government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `self-government'?

—I mean many things by self-government. That brings me to how Australia lines up in comparison with other countries. That seems a point on which the opposition is particularly sensitive. Two speakers this afternoon have expressed some reservations about international obligations.
—Apprehension.

—Apprehension is even worse. It is disturbing that the coalition has this very parochial and narrow view of Australia. When talking about human rights and social justice we need to look at our responsibilities in an international community. We cannot live in the past and simply provide services; we have to look beyond that and work on an equal basis. We have to learn, as the Prime Minister has already learnt, to sit down and negotiate with Aboriginal and Islander people.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the report. I think it is a very historical document. I hope that many Australians will read it and start to understand the real aspirations of Aboriginal and Islander people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted;debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1992-93 annual report of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act relating to consultants engaged under section 4 of the act once again makes very interesting reading. Section 4 of the act details the reasons for the possible engagement of a consultant by a minister. The report lists the details of 57 consultants who were employed by ministers of this government during the financial year 1992-93. There are in fact more than 57 engagements because a continuous period of engagement by the same minister is counted as one engagement even though in technical sense it could well be regarded as more.

PARA.TAB: One of the deficiencies of the report that is tabled here annually is that, whilst it gives details of the names of the consultants, the period for which they are engaged, the minister by whom they are engaged and the duties of their consultancy position, it does not give the costs. We have to get around that by asking questions of the departments at estimates committee hearings and by other sources. The results for 1992-93 show that the cost of ministerial consultants has continued to rise, seemingly without a ceiling, despite the lower inflation figures and government claims that it cannot make expenditure cuts.

In 1992-93 the cost of salaries and travelling entitlements for consultants employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act ballooned by nine per cent to $3.14 million. That is a staggering figure. It compares with about $300,000 spent in 1983, the first year of this Labor government. In other words, over the 10-year period we have had something like a 10-fold increase in the annual cost of ministerial consultants.

The cumulative cost of ministerial consultants for the past nine years, from 1984-85 to 1992-93, has been $18.1 million. As I say, that cost has continued to escalate from year to year with seemingly no regard at all for the economic circumstances and requirements and the hardships being imposed on each and every other Australian as a result of the policies of the Hawke and now Keating governments.

I believe that that is a disgraceful situation because it is an amount over and above the already extremely large costs to service the extremely large numbers of staff that all the ministers have anyway. It is the icing on the cake so far as ministers are concerned. It is being used, and I believe abused, in the most improper fashion to simply provide another resource to the ministerial office without really making use of consultants in the way that was envisaged in the act.

These consultants are not consultants in the sense of being employed to complete a specific project and then go on and do other things or, more importantly, to end the consultancy; most of these people are employed on a continuing full-time basis. Virtually all of the 57 consultancies are ongoing positions. The salaries for these positions range widely—from about $68,000 or $70,000—to the top consultancy, which is paid by the Prime Minister to his chief scientist, of $120,000 a year.

I believe that this matter would be of concern to all Australian taxpayers, who are increasingly seeing this government being unable to distinguish between the national interest, the interests of government, the interests of the people and the interests of a narrow political party for the use of taxpayers' money. This is another part of an ongoing saga in this regard. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the annual report of Austrade entitled The Australian Trade Commission 1992-93—Really making a difference. And that is what we really need—an Austrade and an export culture that will really make a difference in getting our products offshore.

PARA.TAB: The report says that Austrade helps to win business overseas and bring investment to Australia. Having just been through Europe and central Europe in July, I believe that Austrade is doing a fantastic job in bringing trade to the fore. It is a difficult job because at the moment trade is having to suffer the imposts involved in getting our products offshore. These include increased costs of transport, brought about by increased fuel taxes in the budget, and the costs associated with the slow reform of the waterfront.

I will allude to a few of the areas that are mentioned in the report. One is Austrade's responsibility to serve Australia's export community, including thousands of small and medium sized enterprises that currently export or may do so. Some of the areas are innovative, some are new and some are old.

Export centres, for example, which Austrade is now operating with the chambers of commerce, are helping people to understand more about what can be offered. The market analysis unit organises detailed research of overseas markets on behalf of exporters and makes sure that people in Australia know a little bit about them. I think that in the past Austrade has not done quite as well in that area—although maybe it will in the future—as it has in the overseas postings. The people over there do a fantastic job.

The market opportunities unit distributes opportunities spotted overseas amongst the Australian exporters via the export intelligence unit. The network support unit arranges visits to Australia by foreign business people so they can learn what we have to offer them. Then there is the national export hotline. If people dial 132878 during business hours anywhere in Australia, they are connected to the hotline and told what services are provided by Austrade. About 30 or 40 calls a day go to those areas.

Austrade has helped a great deal in the central European countries—especially in the Czech Republic and Poland, for example, to get more wool into those areas. Joint ventures and similar activities can be pursued. Certainly one should make special mention of the Austrade officers in those places.

The fact that we now export so much wine and are pushing our product into places such as Germany, one of the biggest wine markets in the world, and the fact that we have five per cent of the UK wine market, is, in many cases, the result of the help and support given by Austrade. Austrade is not perfect but it is the front line of our trade in foreign countries. If it can improve a little bit more in helping those prospective companies in Australia, I believe that it will give an even better report next year of the job that it is doing for Australia's export industries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—On behalf of the President, and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No.13 1993-94: Efficiency audit: The purchase and use of a supercomputer, ANSTO.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This very interesting report has only become available in the last hour. I think it indicates yet again the enormous inefficiency and the incompetence of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation—ANSTO—which, as one sees if one goes back to the formation of the old Australian Atomic Energy Commission, is simply a continuation of the expensive, irrelevant and misguided direction that those two organisations have taken over many years.

PARA.TAB: In this report it is stated that ANSTO does not agree with the Australian National Audit Office's findings, which of course is not surprising, but the report is extremely damning. It says that the ANSTO went ahead with making arrangements with respect to this supercomputing facility without properly addressing all the issues, without competent assessment of the needs of ANSTO for supercomputing facilities, and indeed also without looking at the alternatives which were available to ANSTO. This all adds up to what I think the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) has already discovered—namely, that the ANSTO board is not particularly satisfactory. I understand that the minister has taken steps to get rid of the ANSTO board, and in my view it is about time.

Moving on from this report, one needs to recognise that something more needs to be done than simply changing the ANSTO board. What we have put to the minister, and what I would like to put into the record here in the Senate chamber, is that the Australian Democrats believe that ANSTO as a separate organisation really needs to be broken up and the various parts of ANSTO need to be dispersed, never to see the light of day again.

We have here a body which has consistently taken a very strong pro-nuclear line in a very political way. It has engaged in much of the public debate on nuclear issues and has taken a very partisan line—not a disinterested line, as it might have done. I believe that, given its pressure for a new nuclear reactor, and seeing that desire in the light of the Auditor-General's report in relation to supercomputing, one would say that ANSTO is not to be trusted with the notion of buying another nuclear reactor. What we would very much like to see happen is that ANSTO would be split up and that a decision would be made quickly that we are not going to buy a new nuclear reactor. Certainly that decision should not be left with ANSTO.

We should quite deliberately go down the road of using cyclotron technology for the preparation of medical isotopes. That is one aspect of ANSTO's work which could be quite rightly and correctly split away and put into some sort of a medical setting. It might, for instance, come under the portfolio of the Minister for Health. The cyclotrons might be sited not within ANSTO but in association with one of the hospitals.

We believe that, in relation to ANSTO's participation in the regulatory functions and in the international obligations functions that Australia carries out with respect to things such as the International Atomic Energy Agency, ANSTO should be split away from those functions and quite correctly be put independently in, say, Senator Gareth Evans's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. That would leave quite a small part of nuclear research, which probably could be put with CSIRO. I understand that if that were done, CSIRO would not be particularly unhappy with that arrangement. It certainly does not want to have a very aging and ineffective nuclear unit—the unit at Lucas Heights—put within its control, with the enormous costs and inefficiencies associated with that.

I am drawing on this report—a report which indicates the incompetence and the lack of clear direction of ANSTO, the making of yet another major decision which was wrong, and the wasting of money—to urge the minister to go further with his actions on ANSTO, to split up ANSTO, and to put the various sections with other bodies so that ANSTO simply ceases to exist. I think the Auditor-General's report underlines the fact that that split is now urgently required and that he should not simply stop with dispensing with the old ANSTO board but should go a great deal further.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the tabling of the Auditor-General's report No.13, relating to the efficiency audit of the purchase and use of a supercomputer at ANSTO, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, for which as Minister for Science and Small Business I am responsible.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment on the remarks made by Senator Coulter, who has a long interest in nuclear matters. I am interested in his remarks in view of the controversial debate that has taken place on and off over the past two or three months, since I first raised the issue of the restructuring of ANSTO and its possible merger with CSIRO. We were also dealing with the McKinnon review into whether we needed a new research reactor, so a whole range of nuclear issues came to a head.

I will deal with the audit report first, and then I will respond to Senator Coulter's comments which dealt with the wider nuclear issues as well. The problems identified in this report will be dealt with by the new board. I announced two weeks ago that, on the decision of cabinet, the present ANSTO board would be asked to resign and a new board would be constituted, with some members of the CSIRO board serving on the ANSTO board, to get better integration of the science arrangements and the science research programs where there is a natural synergy between many of the programs of ANSTO and CSIRO. In fact, CSIRO has facilities at Lucas Heights already. It should be noted that the present chairman of the ANSTO board, Professor Collins, who did the review for the government back in the mid-1980s to establish ANSTO out of the old atomic energy agency, said quite clearly—he repeated it in ANSTO's 1991 annual report—that there was no scientific reason why ANSTO should not be merged with CSIRO. There are other reasons to keep a separate nuclear agency: public presentation dealing with the sensitive issues of nuclear matters, overseas representation, maintaining nuclear science expertise and, above all, dealing with the public and its concerns about nuclear matters.

I do not think it is controversial to say that in some of these areas, particularly relationships with the local community, there have been some problems with ANSTO. Professor Collins and others have conceded that they have had some problems.

Remember this: ANSTO is, above all, a scientific research agency with a research reactor. If, scientifically, there are good reasons to put it with CSIRO—for efficiency reasons or a better outcome for science—then I do not think they can be dismissed. If the non-scientific areas can be addressed, all the better. So cabinet agreed that we would constitute a new board. I have been told that all the members of the existing board have agreed to resign and that letters of resignation have been lodged with the government to take effect in the next few weeks so that a new board can be established.

One of the first jobs the new board will take on will be to respond to the recommendations and criticisms in this report about the supercomputer. I believe it is a matter of some urgency that the new ANSTO board prepare a response to this audit report for the government to be put back to parliament as is required.

The existing ANSTO management in this present report has responded to and rejected most of the criticisms that have been made. However, I think one has to accept that there is considerable strength in the criticisms raised. I have had to raise those matters myself with the ANSTO board and management, since I have been minister. The concern I have, in particular, is that, on the financial side, the supercomputer is losing taxpayers' money. It was a substantial purchase and its operating costs have been high and its commercial viability has not been successful. I think the criticism—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nowhere near what ANSTO set out.

—Yes, and the criticism in the report is that there was a lack of real planning in the commercial sense as to who outside of ANSTO's own area would use the supercomputer. So I look forward to the new board of ANSTO dealing with this report.

PARA.TAB: I will make a couple of comments about the remarks made by Senator Coulter. I was, in general, pleased to hear Senator Coulter's remarks about the fact that there is a case for restructuring in nuclear science. I may not agree with some of his outcomes or suggestions, but I think he does make a good comment about where we are going with nuclear science and whether ANSTO as a stand-alone organisation should continue.

The reason for the government's decision to proceed to an administrative arrangement rather than with legislation—and I will be quite frank about this; it is in my statement of two weeks ago—was that cabinet was concerned that, with its present make-up, trying to negotiate a majority through the Senate on nuclear matters would not be easy. The main reason for that is that there is every indication that the opposition would just say, `No', full stop, and trying to put together a combination of the government, the Democrats, the Greens and the Independent to get a majority would not be easy and in the end we may fail. So the cabinet's view was: can we achieve most of these objectives by having an integrated board with CSIRO and working with a plan to get efficiencies in that area? I think we can get most of what we are about in improvement and a future for nuclear science at a level that is appropriate for Australia's needs.

The cabinet's decision said that, after two years, cabinet would review the progress made by these present arrangements and if those arrangements were not successful we would then have another look at the structural arrangements. The new board will have a two-and-a-half-year life. I hope to be able to make an announcement in the next few days about the membership of that board. I think people will see that, if everything goes as I expect, we will have a board of vigour, enthusiasm, skill and competence to deal with the issues.

Senator Coulter also raised wider issues about nuclear matters; in particular, whether or not we should have a new research reactor in Australia. The cabinet decision of over two weeks ago also dealt with the McKinnon review on this issue. The cabinet accepted the major recommendation that there is no need to make a decision as to whether we need a new reactor for at least five years. The existing reactor has about another 10 years of life and it would take five years to build a new one if we wanted to, so we have to make that decision in about five years time.

I also point out to Senator Coulter that that decision will not be made by ANSTO; it will be made by the government as part of public policy process. The main reason is that, if nothing else, it is a big, expensive item. There is a dispute about this, but some people estimate that the cost may well be $300 million to build a new research reactor in Australia. If it was not built at Lucas Heights it would be even more expensive because the existing infrastructure at Lucas Heights would have to be shifted somewhere else and that would be an additional expense.

One of McKinnon's recommendations also pointed out that developments in nuclear technology, cyclotrons and so on, may mean that in five years time we will have a better grip on whether the production of isotopes can be achieved by non-nuclear reactor means, and that major justification for a new reactor may no longer be there. So all of those issues will have to be weighed up. It will be a controversial debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —What support are you giving to cyclotrons solving the remaining problems?

—That is certainly a technical interjection. We are not ignoring cyclotron development. The operation of the cyclotron for medical purposes at St Alfred's Hospital shows that its applications to medical health are very useful.

PARA.TAB: The science section of my department, separate from ANSTO, will be asked to monitor the developments and keep a brief of what those developments are so that when the decision has to be made in five years time, the government has available to it a range of scientific evidence to be debated and assessed at that time. I imagine there will be plenty of people who will be raising these issues off their own bat.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could become a leader in this.

—I do not know whether we will be a leader; I am not game to predict that, but we could. All I know is that I as a lay person will be very cautious before I chance my arm on predicting nuclear technology developments.

PARA.TAB: Professor McKinnon raised the issue of the new reactor, saying that it cannot be justified purely on scientific or commercial grounds. It has to be considered in the broader sense of `what is the national interest'. Again, the national interest and Australia's having some capacity in and access to nuclear science is part of a wider debate. We should remember that the national interest will have a price tag on it. If we want to build a new nuclear reactor, there will be a price tag of $300 million plus, spent over five years. We are not talking about a small amount of money.

The tabling of this audit report is timely, in view of the recent discussions and debate about nuclear matters. It shows at the very least that there are issues that the government and the new ANSTO board will have to address about management of the super computer. They cannot be ignored. I will wait for the report from the new board about the matters it raises.

As minister responsible for a number of statutory authorities, even though they operate under acts of parliament, with their own independent boards and their own duties to perform as statutory authorities, in the end I accept the responsibility to report to parliament on the expenditures of public moneys, because it is taxpayers' money that is being expended by these statutory authorities. In the end, for good or for bad, a minister has to stand up in this place or in an estimates committee and answer the questions that quite legitimately can be raised, such as: are we getting value for the public's money which is being spent in any of these statutory authorities? That is a fundamental issue of parliamentary democracy and I accept it, even though it means at times having to accept criticisms that are not necessarily of my own making, but I have to be responsible for them. I look forward to hearing the response from the new board.

In conclusion, I think that the new arrangements that we are introducing for most of the staff at ANSTO—the scientific and research staff—will give them a better environment in the long-term future for the work which they conscientiously carry out in nuclear research and engineering. I look forward to a new era beginning at ANSTO.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for the year ended 30 June 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak briefly on the report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. I wish to reiterate one of the matters raised in the report which concerns the proposed creation of a Department of Parliamentary Library and Reporting Services. I understand that there is a bill before the other place on this matter and it will be presented soon to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in the report because I believe this is a matter which I and a number of other senators have some concern about. I know that Senator Reid was a member of the committee which looked at this issue. I have taken the opportunity to read her remarks and look at various transcripts of debates which have been had on this in the past. I am concerned about this proposal.

The argument which I find persuasive and which concerns me relates to the possible threat to independence of the library as a result of amalgamations. I would like to associate myself with the remarks of Senator Reid on this issue. It is of concern that a major step is being taken. I am singularly unconvinced that there will be substantial savings as a result of this.

I notice that one of the senators who signed the dissenting report was former Senator Sowada. I hope that the Democrats will take note of the views of their colleague on that committee and perhaps share the views of Senator Reid and me.
