SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) in her second reading speech of the Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 said that the bill realises a key election promise to families of Australia and that this is another promise made and kept. I can understand why the government would want to pat itself on the back for actually keeping a promise; it is a pretty rare event. There is certainly no mention made of the promises broken by this government since the election.

PARA.TAB: The thing about this promise and this bill is that it is a promise that should never have been made in the first place. This a promise to use taxpayers' money, just like Ros's rorts, to buy off a certain group of voters at the expense of other voters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. There is a clear ruling in this place that senators and members in this chamber and the other should be referred to by their titles.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I would ask Senator Minchin to abide by the practices of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mrs Kelly's reports, I presume is what we are talking about. This bill and the policy behind it reek of being driven by left wing feminists to enable middle and upper income women to have taxpayers pay for their child care. It is not just us saying that and it is not just the National Party, as Senator Evans says. A very prominent Labor person and identity has the same view. A former Labor minister, Senator Peter Walsh, said in the Australian Financial Review recently:

SPEECH.PARA: For the past decade Labor has allowed its child-care policy to be determined by a self-serving symbiotic coalition of feminist networkers, non-market service providers and early childhood services educators. Consequently, it has been flawed by internal inconsistency, cost-ineffectiveness and a benefit distribution somewhere between random and regressive.
It is not just the coalition that has this view about the government's mishmash of child-care policies.

PARA.TAB: The first point I want to make is about the cost of this policy, something that never seems to be mentioned by this government—the cost of what it is doing to this country. The government estimate is that this will be $151.8 million in 1994-95 and another $14.1 million in administration costs. So we are talking about nearly $170 million to start with. The administration costs in 1993-94, before the scheme even comes into effect, amount to nearly $6 million. I bet that when we see the final figure it will be a lot more than that. I understand that the parliamentary library estimate, an independent estimate, of this whole proposal is that the full year cost could be nearly $238 million. Like most government programs, the cost is bound to exceed that which the government estimates.

The budget forecast for total expenditure on child care is that it is going to double over the next four years. In 1992-93 we spent $546.2 million. By 1996-97 that is going to be $1,023.6 million. So we are going to spend over $1,000 million on child care, when this government says to one and all that its overriding policy objective is to reduce the budget deficit. Yet here we plan to spend over a thousand million dollars on this particular scheme and, in this case, to benefit middle and higher income earners—from the party of the workers.

What appals me particularly, coming from South Australia, is that the government's proposal to attack the wine industry was only going to raise less than half the amount of money that it is going to spend on the child-care rebate. So the government is going to risk the future of the wine industry to raise less than half the money it was going to take to buy off this particular group of people.

There are several very significant problems that I see in this child-care rebate proposition. The fundamental problem is that it continues the government's bias against families in which the mother sacrifices her income to care for her own children at home. The policy is biased against them and towards those mothers who put their children into child care and go into the work force. There is a complete lack of equity, a lack of fairness, in the treatment of mothers with young children. The government seems to have no regard whatsoever for the role of mothers who choose to look after their children full-time at home.

All we are seeking is that the government be fair in its treatment of mothers, that it treats them in a neutral way and that it does not bias policy one way or the other. The government's approach to assisting families with children is completely wrong. It has ignored the principles of fairness and choice. The policy in this area should be all about maximising the choice for mothers with young children, the choice between caring for their children themselves at home or the choice of entering the paid work force and putting their children into child care.

We are not saying that the government should have a moral position one way or the other; we are saying that the government should be neutral in its treatment of mothers with young children, and it most avowedly is not. In my view—I have put this view before and I will keep putting the view—this whole extravagant mess should be replaced with a universal child tax credit or benefit so that we are putting the purchasing power in the hands of mothers who have young children and leaving them with the choice of whether they use that purchasing power to enable them, or make it more realistic for them, to choose to look after their children themselves or whether they choose to spend that money on child care. But give them the choice, put the choice in the hands of the consumers, instead of these producer-driven schemes which this government continues to thrust upon us.

This child-care rebate provides very dubious incentives. The government is clearly using its taxpayers' funds to provide an incentive to women to put young children in child care and to enter the paid work force. We are not saying that women should not be free to choose to do that, but we do object to the government using taxpayers' money to put carrots in front of women to make that choice. The government is using taxpayers' money to embark on the most extraordinary experiment of the late 20th century. The government is providing incentives that will result, in its earnest hope, in the placing of a whole generation of young children in institutional child care. It has no idea what the consequences of that move will be.

There is increasing evidence in the United States, where this whole policy agenda has been much more advanced, that prolonged day care may well be very harmful to young children and lead to significant behavioural problems. But this government is disregarding all of that and using the money that it takes from taxpayers to embark upon this extraordinary experiment.

The government is completely ignoring the considerable evidence that a majority of mothers of young children who are in the paid work force would rather be at home looking after their children. It disregards what popular opinion is all about. It is disregarding the public in relation to Mabo and so many other issues. It is disregarding the attitudes of mothers with young children who have been forced into the work force by economic circumstance due to the government's destruction of the economy. It is not giving them the realistic choice of staying at home and looking after their children, as so many of them clearly want to do.

Why on earth should the government be actively using taxpayers' money to encourage mothers of young children to enter the work force? What is the rationale of that when there is 11 per cent unemployment—one million people cannot get a job as a result of this government's policies?
Peter Walsh who, as I said before, is stridently opposed to this proposal, said in the same article in the Australian Financial Review:

SPEECH.PARA: But surely a time when unemployment is around 11%—the highest in 60 years—is not the time to provide further incentives—skewed in favour of those with high incomes—for married women with young kids to join the workforce.
All we are seeking is neutrality, but this government is providing taxpayers' money to give these people an incentive to go into the work force at a time of record unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary library, an independent source on such issues, stated in its Bills Digest on this bill:

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme also seeks to promote greater labour market access at a time when there is clearly an oversupply of labour.

At a time when government policy should be focused on reducing unemployment, the government is about to spend over $170 million a year on a scheme which could increase unemployment. It is a most extraordinary proposition.

PARA.TAB: The government seeks to justify this rebate on the grounds that `the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income'. This might sound very attractive, rational and logical, but where would that kind of principle really end? There is an endless list of what might be regarded as legitimate expenses which, if made rebatable, would totally destroy this government's budget. If that logic were adopted, all travel to and from work, work clothing, meals associated with work, home cleaning, gardening and every domestic service that could possibly be thought of should be rebatable or tax deductible expenses. It is an absolute nonsense.

People have children by choice. It is not forced on them in relation to their employment. This legislation represents one of the worst kinds of window-dressing for a radical proposal and it is quite wrong. The government is very wrong to introduce it.

In terms of legitimising this proposition in relation to rebatable expenses, the government has ignored the fact that it should well know that the best tax system has as few rebates and tax deductions as possible. The reason the tax systems get so complicated, difficult and expensive to administer is that there is a system of deductions and rebates. A philosophy of keeping rebates and deductions to a minimum enables tax rates to be kept to the minimum level possible. Introducing rebates and tax deduction, by definition, increases the rate of tax.

Even if we accept the government's argument, we really must wonder why there is a periodic cash rebate used in this case. Why do we not have a tax rebate at the end of the year? Why introduce this extraordinary complexity, the use of Medicare offices and all the other problems that are associated with the incredible expense of over $14 million in administering this scheme, to provide a cash rebate? It has never been done before and it is completely unjustified.

Finally, I am extremely concerned about where this scheme will lead. It is not beyond any stretch of the imagination to postulate that the next step will be that this rebate will only become payable in respect of accredited child-care centres. The government's push on the accreditation of child-care centres and the compulsory nature of that in relation to fee relief strike terror into my heart in relation to the whole child-care rebate scheme. I lay a bet that, later down the track, we will see the government's advisers saying that the only way to ensure proper accreditation, et cetera, is to pay this rebate only in respect of accredited centres.

In conclusion, this rebate scheme is completely wrong. It was dreamt up in the heat of a campaign by a government desperate to grab as many votes as it could. It is absolutely the parallel of the sports rorts of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). It is unfair and inequitable; it is grossly unfair to women who sacrifice an income to stay at home with their young children in order to bring them up in the manner they so choose.

This scheme will be an inappropriate use of taxpayers' funds in the context of what the government says is this nation's overriding problem—a massive $16 billion government deficit. The government should completely rethink its policy in relation to assistance to families with children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been outlined by the previous speakers, the Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 introduces a cash rebate for work related child-care expenses. I will not spend time going over the details—particularly the financial details—of the scheme. The bill is aimed at providing direct financial assistance for child-care costs to those families that are presently not receiving in any way targeted child-care assistance.

PARA.TAB: To qualify for the rebate, each parent has to be working, or the single parent has to be working. That means that they have to have recognised work-related commitments. This includes undertaking recognised study or training. It is defined as covering unemployed people who are registered with the CES and those who are receiving a carer's pension or a domiciliary nursing care benefit, as both of these last two commitments are seen as involving full-time work.

We have some problems with that definition. I will be speaking further on this when Senator Harradine moves some amendments. Families receiving maximum child-care assistance, or what is known as fee relief, will not be eligible for the rebate.

Child-care providers will be registered with the Health Insurance Commission. The rebate can only be claimed if the expenses are paid to a registered child-care provider. Families will also register with the commission and lodge their claims through local Medicare offices. Contrary to earlier speculation, applicants will not have to provide their tax file numbers to the HIC, although providers will have to satisfy the commission that they have a tax file number before they can be registered.

I am very pleased that this is the way in which it is being done. At one stage it certainly looked as though this scheme would be another extension of the tax file number. We recall the bombshell dropped in here by Senator Crowley in the autumn sittings when she said that the government was looking at requiring carers to provide their tax file numbers to a Medicare office. As I said at the time, that was completely unacceptable to the Australian Democrats. Looking back now, it seems as though the idea was run up the flagpole to see how far it would go. As it turns out, it did not go very far at all.

We made it very clear at that time—I know that Senator Newman also expressed concerns—that we would not support a situation where people were forced to give their tax file numbers in order to claim the rebate. The Democrats are pleased to see that another method has been found and that that idea was put in the rubbish bin where it belongs.

Let me now deal with the scheme itself. The Democrats will be supporting this legislation, although we have some misgivings. For example, we wonder whether the money going into the scheme—which, as has already been said, is around $150 million a year—would not have been much better spent in improving access to child-care services.

Cost is only one part of the problem for many parents who are looking for child care. There are major problems with access to more flexible types of care, such as emergency or relief care, out of school hours care, child-care options in rural areas, child care for children with special needs and so on. The $150 million would have bought quite a bit of additional care in these areas.

There is narrowness in the scheme. The rebate will only be available for people who are in employment or who have recognised work-related commitments. As we have said many times before, the Democrats have problems with that. We really need to look at the value of unpaid work and formally recognise unpaid work, most of which is done by women.

Recognition of the value of unpaid work necessarily involves an acknowledgment of the importance of non-work related child care. From that perspective, this rebate scheme fails to address two critical matters. First, if we do not provide access to child care for carers at home, we are not only refusing to acknowledge their significant economic contribution, we are also denying them an opportunity to fully participate in society.

Second, the Democrats think that it is time we looked at the idea of payment to carers who are choosing to stay at home and care for young children, whether those carers are men or women. That payment needs to go much further than the home child-care allowance which the government also promised at the last election. It really does need to provide choice; it needs to provide a sufficient level of funding so that there really is an option for those who do wish to stay at home. We have to find mechanisms that really give women the right to choose.
There is certainly a growing recognition of the tension between employment and family responsibilities. The 1991 OECD paper called Shaping Structural Change: the role of women pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: Most women are now forced to juggle household and family demands with involvement in paid work structures designed to fit male employment patterns. Men miss out on the emotional rewards of the care and development of children because they are similarly constrained by the gender-based division of household and employment responsibilities.

In short, we basically need to make sure that both men and women really can make choices which suit their families, their employment situations, their caring needs, their careers, and, indeed, their personal desires—without incurring serious penalties.

PARA.TAB: The challenge before us is to recognise the value of that unpaid work. We have to support those who do choose to spend a period of time at home caring for young children. I really do not see why we cannot meet that challenge. The Democrats urge the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to look beyond this child-care rebate scheme and beyond his proposed home child-care allowance and to begin to fully explore the issues.

I turn to the issue of means testing the rebate. This was not an easy decision for us. We spent a long time looking very hard at what exactly this government was doing, particularly considering the economic constraints that we are facing as a nation at the moment. There certainly are two sides to this debate. We looked very carefully at a wide range of concerns expressed to us about the regressive nature of the rebate scheme. But, in the end, we decided to come down on the side of moving child-care out of the welfare basket and into the community responsibility area.

We had to come down on the side of seeing child-care as a legitimate work related expense and we had to come down on the side of those 230,000 families and 358,000 children who will benefit from this rebate. The premise underpinning this scheme is one of equating child-care with other expenses—genuine expenses—incurred in earning an income. In other words, it is shifting the emphasis of the debate from being one about a women's issue or a welfare issue to one of it being a community issue or an industrial issue. I think that shift in emphasis is very important; it is long overdue.

It is a shift which says that child-care is no longer the privilege of a few and that it has to be accessible, affordable, of a very high quality, and that it is a basic or essential service and not a welfare service. It is putting child-care on the same basic list of human rights as education and health. In my view, collective acceptance of those basic rights and entitlements is a measure of the maturity and the economic and social good sense of a society.

The Democrats are strong in their belief that these services should be publicly funded through taxation to ensure that all Australians have access to an adequate standard of education, health and child-care. I found it very interesting to listen to coalition speakers who now want to means test this payment, and to look back at their policy of introducing tax deductibility with absolutely no cap, no limit whatsoever. Surely they have to acknowledge that the scheme we are looking at today is far less regressive than the tax deductibility they are actually planning. Their continuing push for non-means tested, non-capped tax deductibility really undermines their total argument and all their credibility in this debate.

As I have already indicated, the Democrats will support this legislation. But, because we do have some concerns about the operation of this scheme, I have asked the minister whether she will consider an evaluation of the scheme after the first two years of operation. Such an evaluation will provide us with an analysis of claims made under this scheme and will give us a chance to look at exactly who is able to access the system and who is missing out. Senator Crowley has provided me with a written undertaking to review the scheme at the end of 1995. I thank her for taking our concerns on board and I seek leave to table the letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has completely missed the point, particularly the last coalition speaker. The point is that the child-care cash rebate is not intended to be a welfare payment. It is intended to be a payment which reduces the fundamental inequity which exists between workers with children and workers without children.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I think most of the points that needed to be made have been made very well in this debate by my colleague Senator Chris Evans and, most recently, by Senator Lees in her contribution. I have to say that Senator Minchin's contribution is, at best, confused and, at worst, betrays a clear understanding that he does not know what his own party policy is—not only what it is, but what it has been.

PARA.TAB: I will make some points in response to the contributions of those opposite. I note that one of the opposition senators—I think it was Senator Minchin—said that this is a promise made and a promise kept. Senator Patterson suggested that we do not keep any promises that we have made. I would have thought that the opposition might at least find enough grace in its system to acknowledge that we have made a promise and kept it—and it is a very important one.

It is particularly interesting and important to note the opposition's contribution about whether or not to means test this rebate. Those who listened to Senator Minchin would have to say that he sounds very confused on this matter. As Senator Lees spelt out very well, means testing the rebate is completely contrary to previous policy of the opposition. Not only was it not going to provide a rebate but, before that, it was going to provide a non-means tested tax deduction, which is particularly regressive. I would suggest that Senator Minchin might repair to his own party policy over the past few years and look at that.

When women are finally provided with a rebate that recognises the cost of child care as a legitimate expense in earning an income, what does the opposition want to do? It wants to means test it. I have never heard those opposite come in here and propose to means test lawyers' libraries. I have never heard them come in here and propose to means test doctors' refrigerators. I have never heard them talk about means testing any of these rebates or tax deductions.

Women have been fighting for this recognition for many years and—as the opposition policy intermittently has recognised—the first time this is provided to women the opposition want to means test it. The opposition is taking an extraordinary stand which is particularly anti-women, especially when those opposite say that they are in sympathy with women. This clearly shows that they are not. It is entirely consistent with the opposition's view on all other tax matters.

If we look at the amount of tax dollars that are forgone through tax deductions—around about $5 billion against all of those expenses legitimately claimed under the present tax laws by all sorts of people in the earning of their income—there is not a word of objection from the opposition about that. But the minute women get access to a vital tax rebate in an area that has been absolutely critical for them—one for which the opposition has argued—the opposition wants to means test it. The opposition is sending women voters a very contradictory message.

I also want to reinforce the view of the government that by recognising child care through this rebate it moves it from being seen as a welfare payment to a recognition as a major economic issue and part of labour market considerations. It is the first time that we have been able to recognise child care as a legitimate cost of earning income. I do not understand at all the inconsistency and illogicality of the opposition's policy on this.

I will make a few comments about the privacy matter. Opposition senators seem to suggest that I and this government have no concerns about privacy. That is completely contrary to the facts. I am particularly concerned about privacy. I am not going to run in this place all the arguments that I have used in other places, particularly in discussions about this legislation. I have very serious concerns about privacy and I have had them since the earliest stage.

I think it is important and interesting to note that those concerns are well met by the Democrats who have always been consistent on this matter and by the opposition which washes a bit hot and cold. We have a system that balances privacy and accountability considerations. As honourable senators have said, this is a large amount of money and it would be quite improper for me or the government to disregard the requirement for fair and proper accountability. At the same time, the government is particularly concerned that the privacy considerations also be taken into consideration. I believe the outcome that the government has provided is the best balance between those two considerations.

A person's tax file number will not in any way be provided to the Health Insurance Commission. The Health Insurance Commission will not be able to record it, note it or in any way take account of it. The only thing the Health Insurance Commission will do is pass the names and dates of birth of the people who have registered as providers of child care to the tax office so that the tax office can confirm that those people do have tax file numbers as they claim on their reports.

I think the matter of privacy ought to be laid to rest. It is a matter of major concern. The government has taken that into account and I have been very concerned to take it into account. I believe the government has struck a very good balance in terms of the outcome.

The opposition trawled in the red herring of accreditation. Senator Minchin got quite carried away in his speech and suggested that in the end the government would be providing the cash rebate only to accredited centres. Senator Minchin is particularly mischievous to say that. This legislation spells out quite clearly that the cash rebate will apply to formal and informal child care. That is what the legislation says and that is the government's intention.

We recognise that while we have a large supply of child-care places it is still well short of the demand. Many people are using informal care because they are unable to find a place in a formal child-care centre. There are also many people who chose informal child care. In recognition of the reasons that people choose informal care, the government has made it quite clear that this legislation covers the informal care area. Senator Minchin is wrong and mischievous in proposing that this will change that or that we are not serious about it.

Accreditation and quality are matters of considerable concern to this government. Despite the absolutely ridiculous campaign being waged against accreditation, the government's commitment to quality is absolutely clear. I am very concerned to make sure that parents using child care are assured that their children will have care provided in quality child-care centres. I am also aware that when people apply to have their children enter a child-care centre they are not completely able to assess the quality of care provided and they do not necessarily meet all the child-care providers. They cannot be fully aware of all the things that will happen in a child-care centre. Even if they do make a very large effort to find out about the child-care centre—and I think many parents do—honourable senators should realise that they may not be able to satisfy themselves on all counts. In the informal area when parents make arrangements for their own children, they are very well placed to ensure that they are satisfied with the quality of care they are arranging.

For the record, I note that Senator Patterson suggested that 60 per cent of child-care centres are private and all of those oppose accreditation. Those figures—like everything else the opposition is saying about accreditation—are quite incorrect. About 60 per cent of child-care places are private and a very large section of that private child-care area strongly supports the accreditation process. Those figures are way off as usual.

Senator Chris Evans spelt out very well the way the cash rebate will be given on top of the fee relief for child-care assistance. This means that there has been considerable progress in this area. Our assistance to make child care affordable is very much targeted to people on low incomes. The cash rebate will be available to some parents receiving full fee relief if their fees are above the cut-off level. In other words, if there is an amount that the parents have to pay they may receive a cash rebate. A modest amount of cash rebate would be available to those parents. Some parents on full fee relief may be able to have a small amount of the cash rebate to contribute towards those fees that are above the capped level.

If one examines the figures—and I think Senator Evans has done it, so I will not do it again—it is quite clear that the maximum payment for one child using child care with no fee relief is $28.20. The sliding scale of perhaps less than a full cash rebate or even full cash rebate plus the assistance of fee relief means that there is considerable progress in the way we are assisting families with the question of affordability.

The opposition seems very confused in what it thinks about informal care. On the one hand, in the accreditation debate, the opposition was arguing that we are forcing people into informal care. In this debate it is arguing the importance of informal care. I think members of the opposition are not clear whether it is good or bad or which way they want to use it. I think that is another example of their confusion in this whole area.

Senator Minchin got a bit carried away and trawled across the old red herring of children reared in institutional care being ruined and how harmful it is. Yet he is a member of a party that has exactly the same policy apart from the means test. I do not quite understand what Senator Minchin is really trying to argue. However, I think this is a very good example of a confused opposition mind. Is Senator Minchin for or against child care? It is not at all clear to any of us listening what he actually stands for.

I am very aware of what the women of Australia are saying. The government actually spent a very long time extensively consulting the women of Australia. They have put three points very high on their political agenda. The things they want the government to consider are child care, violence against women and women's health. The government has delivered in all of those areas. I can assure the opposition that in the child-care area it is in response to the concern in the community, particularly of women, that our child-care policies have been designed. The government's policies very much recognise the importance of choice for women. It is not fair to say, as Senator Minchin said, that the government has no regard at all for families at home.

Another promise made and kept and also forgotten by Senator Patterson and honourable senators opposite is the home child-care allowance. It will be introduced towards the end of September next year. While I can accept Senator Lees's point that one would like it to be larger, one has to recognise the important breakthrough in getting the dependent spouse rebate cashed out to the spouse at home. It recognises the importance of looking after children at home and it also provides a continuing income to the spouse who is providing that care. Certainly, one could argue about the amount, but I think the important point being made in that home child-care allowance is the recognition of the importance of women in the home.

One also needs to recognise the payment of family allowance. There is also considerable funding under the child-care vote for occasional care. That is particularly designed to assist women at home who are not in the work force or defined as seeking work. We have also dramatically increased the money to play groups. In all of those ways we recognise the importance of women at home and the care that they provide.

We also recognise that the old war between women at home and women in the workplace is tired and destructive. It fails to recognise what women are telling government, telling me, that most adult women, particularly those who have children, expect to spend some time of their adult lives in and out of the work force. Our policies recognise that. They recognise and support women in making that choice.

Senator Minchin also said that we should be castigated for introducing a policy that assists millionaires. He then spent a lot of time saying how ridiculous it was to design a system that allowed people to collect the rebate every two weeks. I suggest that Senator Minchin has really got a muddled brain. One of the reasons why we do not allow the rebate to be collected only at the end of the year is that only people on higher incomes can afford that. Cashing out the rebate this way clearly recognises the needs of families, particularly women on lower incomes. They are not able to wait for the whole year to draw a rebate. They appreciate that this policy gives them the ability to collect that money every two weeks. It is particularly obvious. I can not understand why Senator Minchin failed to appreciate that.

Senator Lees was particularly concerned on behalf of the Democrats that there be an evaluation of the scheme after two years. As Senator Lees has noted in her comments, I think that is a very acceptable proposition. The government, of course, would be evaluating the program from the day it started. It is a proper and usual procedure in government that there be close evaluation and monitoring.

I also appreciate the point made by Senator Lees that a stepping back, if you like, from the ongoing process of monitoring to an evaluation after two years will allow us to take a look at the aggregated figures to see patterns emerging of who has had access, who has had use and maybe who has been missing out. I am very happy to support that request from Senator Lees. I think it is thoughtful and considered. I believe that it will add to the value and the impact of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the observation that in respect of amendments Nos 1 to 7 proposed to be moved by Senator Harradine, there is a view that they are in fact requests because they add to a cost to revenue. If you are of similar mind, Senator Harradine, I will refer to amendments Nos 3 to 6 as amendments to omit clauses and to amendments Nos 1 and 2 as requests that the House of Representatives make the appropriate amendments to the bill.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine—I thank the Chair for advice on that matter. The thought had crossed my mind during the day. I will be guided by your advice on that matter.
Clause 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.
Senator Patterson—To facilitate the committee stage of the bill, I would like to move amendments Nos 1, 2, 3 and 4 standing in my name, if that is in order.
Senator Crowley—Mr Chairman, I would also like to ask for your clarification on how we intend to deal with this. I think it would help us all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, with the leave of the chamber, we could take those clauses together and then take the balance of the bill as a whole. There are no other amendments that would clash, as I understand it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley—I am having some difficulty with this, too. I was wondering whether we should move that the bill be taken as a whole because the amendments actually cover a whole number of clauses. They are almost consequential on the principal amendment. The amendments proposed to be moved come as a package. I wonder whether it will be of assistance to the committee if we take the bill as a whole and then senators can move their amendments taking those as consequential effects.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was what I was seeking to indicate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine—Frankly, I would prefer for the usual procedure to take place, that we go through clause by clause. I believe that this will enable the minister perhaps to explain some things and it may not be necessary to move certain amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a perfectly reasonable request. You are quite reasonably declining leave to take the bill as a whole. So we will go through it clause by clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 4, page 2, after the definition of "claim" insert the following definition:

" `combined family income', in relation to a family, means the sum of the taxable income in a relevant year of a person forming part of a family for the purposes of subsection 5(1), and the income of the partner (if any) of the person, as defined in subsection 5(1) or (2);".
(2)Clause 4, page 3, after the definition of "registered family" insert the following definition:
" `relevant year', in relation to the combined family income of a family, means the financial year immediately preceding the year in which a claim is lodged;".

I wish to speak to these two amendments to clause 4, but to facilitate the time of the chamber I will speak to my other amendments and when we get to them I will just move them. If Senator Harradine is prepared to accommodate us in that sense, that is what I will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is perfectly reasonable.

—No. I made my position perfectly clear. It is not a question, as suggested by Senator Patterson, that I am not trying to facilitate matters. I think the minister has a responsibility to answer questions in respect of particular clauses. If one takes the bill as a whole, one does not have the opportunity specifically in respect of individual clauses to question the minister; otherwise, we will have a rambling debate. I want to facilitate debate on this particular matter by focusing particular questions to the minister in respect of particular clauses. I am quite happy for Senator Patterson to move her amendments however she wishes to move them and debate however she wishes to debate. There is no problem with that.

—The opposition has two other amendments, which relate to clauses 33 and 36. The effect of the amendments that the opposition has put forward is to target child-care cash rebates to families with a taxable income of less than $60,000 a year. I gave the reasons for this in my speech in the second reading debate. A maximum rebate will be payable for taxable family income of up to $50,000 per year. The rebate is then tapered down as income increases. For taxable family income exceeding $60,000, no rebate is payable.

PARA.TAB: These amendments reflect the coalition's policy of providing assistance for child care in an economically prudent way in recognition of difficult economic times. In an ideal world there would not be any targeting of the rebate, but the reality of the economic imperatives facing us means that the application of an income test is appropriate. It reflects the coalition's position as stated in our 1993 child-care policy statement. Such an income test is not unprecedented. For instance, the dependent spouse rebate—or, as it will be known from next December, the home child-care allowance—is subject to an income test.

It should be pointed out that senior ministers within the government were pushing for the application of an income test for the child-care rebate. As I said in my speech on the second reading, back in June the Treasurer was reported as telling cabinet ministers that he could not understand why families on high incomes should be able to claim the child-care rebate. Given the present economic conditions, for once the coalition agrees with the Treasurer and calls on honourable senators to support these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it clear in my speech that we will not be accepting these amendments. I do not believe it will assist the Senate to trawl over the arguments again. I think they were well spelt out in the second reading speech.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also be opposing these amendments. I went through the arguments in my speech on the second reading. I stress again that we believe that child care should be taken out of the welfare basket and put into one that has community responsibility very clearly on the side of it. What this payment will do is reduce the fundamental inequity that exists between workers who have children and workers who do not have children. Therefore, we will not be supporting these amendments, which effectively target it quite tightly.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the question of definitions, or the lack of definitions, in clause 4. In clause 5(1) there is a definition of `family' which provides for certain conditions. Clause 5(2) says:

PARA.TAB: For the purpose of paragraph (1)(b), a person is the partner of another person if:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the person is legally married to the other person and is not, in the Managing Director's opinion . . . living separately and apart . . .
(b) all of the following conditions are met:
(i) the person is living with the other person;
(ii) the person is not legally married to the other person;
(iii) the relationship between the person and the other person is, in the Managing Director's opinion (formed as mentioned in subsection (3)), a marriage-like relationship . . .
There is no definition of the term `marriage-like'. I ask the minister: what is the meaning of the term `marriage-like'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The definitions that Senator Harradine has just taken us through make it clear that the reach is to recognise what are commonly called de facto relationships and to include other arrangements where people may be in a relationship. In this case, it would allow the inclusion of people of the same sex who have the responsibility and care of children. I am advised, though, that it is largely to go to heterosexual couples who are not married but who are in a de facto relationship. (Quorum formed)

—The reason that I called the quorum is that I do not think I heard the minister correctly. The minister seemed to indicate that the definition of a family, for the purposes of the child-care rebate, is to include a marriage-like relationship, and that included in that marriage-like relationship are same-sex couples. That means that for the first time we have a minister of a government saying that the definition of a family is to include same-sex couples—homosexuals.

PARA.TAB: I may have misunderstood the minister. I would be really interested to hear what she has to say about that. If she is saying that, now, a marriage-like relationship is to be defined as a homosexual relationship or a lesbian relationship for the purposes of this legislation, so far as I can see, that is the first time that a government minister has indicated that those relationships will be regarded as part of a definition of a family. Am I to understand that that is the case or not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is what I said and that is what this legislation means. What we realise and what we want to recognise in this legislation is that the care of children is being provided for in a variety of families and that the person who has responsibility for the care of children may be in a variety of those different groupings. This legislation does not want to say that children who are living in a household where two adults of the same sex are essentially responsible for running that household should be excluded from having access to the cash rebate.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes, following a marriage breakdown, people move to that sort of relationship and they have care and custody of a child, if not full time then part time. The legislation allows those parents to have a claim against the cash rebate. We felt it was very important not to define a category of children who would then be ineligible for the cash rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come back to the question of the definition of the family. We are not talking about the payment of an amount of money for a person who is the parent of the particular child. If that person is working, that person clearly would be entitled to a rebate. We are not talking about that at all. We are talking about a situation where, I believe for the first time, the minister has chosen to define a family so as to include lesbians and homosexuals. I think that is a very serious matter. If that is the case, I will be proposing an amendment, which I will seek time to draft, which will refer to marriage-like relationships, including de facto relationships, that are normally included and generally the case in respect of all of these matters, such as social security and so on. The provisions of the social security legislation do not extend these benefits to lesbian or homosexual couples.
—It is the children we are talking about.
—We are talking about the children. If we are talking about the welfare of the children, then I think we ought to have a think about that as well. I move:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of clause 4 be postponed till after consideration of the remainder of the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to accept that. It is a little surprising that I find these questions being raised by Senator Harradine for the first time here. It may have assisted us all if, having had these concerns, he had asked those questions earlier. We would have been very pleased to assist him then.

PARA.TAB: What distinguishes this piece of legislation from social security legislation—and I think it is an important matter—is that we are not talking about payments to families where the definition of a marriage-like relationship is non-inclusive of single sex relationships. Here we are talking about family defined in a way that will not create a group of children whose carers, on their behalf, will not have access to the cash rebate.

This is a payment on behalf of care for the child. It is distinct from those payments in social security. That is why this definition is wider. We did not want to find ourselves creating discrimination against some children who are living in those kinds of families. It seems to us much more important to be inclusive of opportunity for children rather than defining a group who would be ineligible for that kind of assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond by indicating that the minister is not prepared to allow me the time to draft an amendment which I think may assist the committee to ensure the protection of the rebate for the children but not to have included and on the record, and maintained on the record, the definition of a family to be a homosexual couple. That is what we are doing here if we allow the situation, as has been proposed, to be maintained.

PARA.TAB: The minister has in fact agreed that a definition of a family can include a homosexual couple. All I will be asking in my amendment is that we ensure that the children are not adversely affected, but that this parliament makes it perfectly clear that, for the purposes of the definition of a family, we are not prepared to accept an interpretation by the minister at the table that that definition will include a homosexual couple.

All I am asking at this stage is for time to ensure that a properly drafted amendment is drawn up so as to achieve those two objectives. That is surely not an unreasonable request because this is a very important matter. For the first time, as I say, that I have ever heard of, a minister has got up in this chamber and said that a definition of a family can be a homosexual couple or a lesbian couple. I do not accept that and I do not think that most members—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about time you did. It is a fact.
—Senator Zakharov said that it is about time we did accept that homosexual couples and lesbian couples are families. Well, I do not accept that and that has never been the definition.
—It is a family.

—That has never been the definition of family in any legislation. We do not want it to creep through the back door as the government is trying to do on this occasion. If we are going to have that debate, let us have it out in the open. Let us go to this question of what is a family. Here is the Minister for Family Services trying to bring it through the back door. She says that if I had asked the questions before or consulted people before, they may have assisted me, that they may have given me that answer. They may not have done so.

PARA.TAB: The matter was drawn to my attention and I then drew it to the attention of the minister in the hope—as it has turned out, the vain hope—that she would give the definition as per the usual definition that is adopted for this particular purpose.

This is a crucial issue. This parliament should not allow this crucial issue to be determined as it is being determined right here and now. Let us have a full debate about it. All I am asking for on this occasion—and the minister is denying it to me, unless she changes her mind—is the opportunity to craft an amendment which will protect any benefit that may accrue in respect of a child and also protect the principle and the definition of the family that have been accepted heretofore.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have liked this issue to have been canvassed when the bill was tabled on 26 October; it may have made life easier. We would have had better vision with hindsight if Senator Harradine had raised this issue with Senator Newman—who had responsibility and carriage of this bill until she had to go into hospital—and the minister. We could then have debated this in our party room.

PARA.TAB: I feel somewhat reluctant not to concede to the request that Senator Harradine has made to examine this issue and consider putting up alternative wording. Members of my party would expect me to take that back to them because it is an issue of great moment and consequence. I think we should have the opportunity to debate that. Again, it would have been better had it come in the due process. It has been through the party room. Obviously, we have not picked that up. It is partly our fault that we did not pick it up and take that opportunity to debate it in the party room and also to question the minister beforehand. Now that the issue has been raised, I indicate that I will be supporting Senator Harradine to defer the consideration of this clause until he has had time to draft an amendment and I have had time to consult with my party on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support Senator Harradine's motion for deferral of debate because it is of fundamental importance. We cannot just gloss it over. We certainly missed it in this context. I was not aware of it until I heard Senator Crowley's response. I do not want to get into the debate on the issue itself, at this stage all I want to do is support Senator Harradine's request that it be considered at a future date.

PARA.TAB: We concentrate on couples in this issue—whether they be celibate, homosexual or whatever—but we forget the child. The child's life is more important in that respect because adults can determine their own circumstances. The child is the person of the future and it is the child that needs to be considered. It is of paramount importance that this issue be debated. I know that the vast majority of Australian people support the concept of the importance of the standard family unit. We have seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures today in the papers which show that 90 per cent of the Australian population—and this was a huge survey—support the concept of a male-female standard relationship in relation to the upbringing of a child. I completely support the motion that Senator Harradine is proposing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with something that Senator Herron says, that what is important here is the child. I believe that this is a very important issue. I understand that we will finish this debate at about 7.28 p.m., so there are only three or four minutes to go. I think that this issue will naturally draw itself to no conclusion tonight and that we will come back to this place, perhaps tomorrow, perhaps not, depending on the scheduling of government business, to look at this again.

PARA.TAB: I stress that what concerns the Democrats is the welfare of the children. After all, this measure is designed to assist with child care and support for children. Therefore, I want to put on the record that the Democrats do not have any problem with the definition in this bill. We believe this is about care for children and the opportunity for all children to access child care. We do not believe that the sex or the sexual preference of the adults caring for them—their parents—has any relevance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is probably the first time I have spoken on a matter like this. I am very happy that Senator Harradine picked up this issue, otherwise we would have seen a recognition of a homosexual relationship in legal matters via the back door. We have just heard Senator Lees and the minister say that they are both concerned about the welfare of the child. I reckon that is of prime importance, but let us not use that issue to get marriage-like situations into the legislation. It will be a black day if we do that today or any other day.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister and Senator Lees to look at clause 4 which mentions persons who are not within a prohibited relationship, and gives the definition of a prohibited relationship. If a child is involved, what do we do then? That sort of family can exist. I have seen quite a few of them. For example, a married woman with a child and no husband is left to her own devices so her single brother sets up with her in a household and provides everything. There is no relationship because they are just standard brother and sister. What do we do with the child then? Will the government legalise anything in that case as well, or will it leave that child hanging out?
I return to my main point. I am utterly disgusted—I am almost sick in the stomach—

SPEECH.PARA: that maybe, for another legitimate reason, we legalise homosexual relationships through the back door. I would like an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that. Senator Panizza will get an answer tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Western Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What, if any, grants or payments have been made to the Commissioner of the Western Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (Mr Neil Phillips) on his own behalf or on the behalf of others and for what purposes have these grants or payments been made.
(2) Have these payments been properly acquitted where appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Mr Phillips has received payments in his own right only in the form of remunerations, as in accordance with his entitlements as a Commissioner and Regional Councillor for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

Mr Phillips is also a member and office-bearer of a number of incorporated Aboriginal organisations in Western Australia which have received grants from ATSIC. The following grants and other payments have been made over the past three years to organisations of which Mr Phillips is known to be an office-bearer.
1990/91—a grant of $30,170 was made to the Aboriginal Sport and Recreation Organisation to provide input to an inter-agency study of Aboriginal youth offenders programs.
1991/92—a grant of $5,000 was made to the Binyardi Aboriginal Corporation for the development of a community plan.

—an allocation of $2,500 was provided to each of three organisations in which Mr Phillips was an office-holder for the purpose of conducting community consultations on the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. These organisations were the Binyardi Aboriginal Corporation, the Homeless Aged Persons Care Agency and Royals Sport and Recreation Aboriginal Corporation.
1992/93—a grant of $25,000 was provided to the Binyardi Aboriginal Corporation (BAC) for the purchase of a motor vehicle.

(2) In relation to the acquittal of the $30,170 Aboriginal Sport and Recreation Association grant, the Australian Government Solicitor's (AGS) office undertook an examination of the acquittal and decided that further action was not warranted.

The $5,000 made to BAC, of which Mr Phillips was Chairperson, has also been acquitted. The $2,500 allocations made for the purpose of community consultations on the Recommendations from the Royal Commission did not require acquittal.

However, the $25,000 allocation made to BAC has not yet been acquitted. ATSIC's WA State Office has sought advice from its Commercial Law Section on this matter, and the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations is separately conducting an investigation into the affairs of BAC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 August 1993

PARA.TAB: (1) Where are the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) printing plants located.

(2) (a) Who is running the `pause gymnastics' courses outlined in the Department of Administrative Services 1991-1992 annual report; (b) is this a national program; (c) how long has the program been in existence at AGPS; (d) how is the value or success of `pause gymnastics' measured; (e) what is the cost of this program; and (f) do participants pay a fee for this employer-provided service.
(3) How many work days have been lost as a result of Occupational Overuse Syndrome.
(4) How many people in AGPS suffer from Occupational Overuse Syndrome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that my previous response to part (3) of the honourable senator's question of 6 August, published in the Weekly Hansard of 6 September at page 1003, only referred to lost days for new cases diagnosed during the year rather than the total lost days for all cases during the year. The amended answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) AGPS has printing plants at Kingston in the ACT and Brunswick in Victoria, and Instant Print and Copy Centres in Brisbane, Melbourne, Canberra, Adelaide, Perth and Hobart.

(2) (a) The Occupational Health and Safety Nurse conducted the program; (b) it was conducted only in the Canberra area; (c) the program commenced in March 1992; (d) lower incidence of Occupational Overuse Syndrome; (e) negligible, as the program became a fifteen minute part of the working day; (f) no.
(3) Comcare reports that during the 1991-92 year a total of 2560 working days were lost.
(4) There were 12 reported cases in 1991-92.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are the Australian Postgraduate Research Awards administered by the department tax free stipends to full-time PhD and Masters degree students.

(2) Have some research students been made to sign intellectual property arrangements which have been interpreted by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) as being a `service providing' agreement for which tax can be levied.

(3) As a result of this interpretation, is the ATO treating these awards as taxable income; if so, will the amount of the awards be raised to a level that will offset any tax liability and thus protect the value of the awards to the students.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under Section 23 (z) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, scholarship income received by a full-time student at a university is exempt from taxation. Australian Postgraduate Research Awards are covered by this general provision. There are a number of exceptions to the provision, one of which is the situation where the scholarship income is received by the student on condition that services are rendered to the scholarship provider.

(2) The Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) has not been informed by students or by institutions of any cases where Australian Postgraduate Research Award holders have been deemed by the ATO to be rendering services and consequently liable to pay tax. The department is aware that some postgraduate students supported by other agencies have been required by the ATO to pay tax on their stipends.
(3) If the honourable senator provides advice of any instances where Australian Postgraduate Research Award holders' stipends have been assessed as taxable income, the issue could be examined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Taxation Office: Purchase of Books

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 October, 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the purpose of the `customised effective business writing work books' purchased at a cost of $20,813.40 from Champagne Consultants, Mona Vale, New South Wales, by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).
(2) How many books were purchased.
(3) Are these books currently being used by employees of the ATO; if so has there been any notable improvement in the output of these employees.

QUESTION.PARA: (4) How many employees have used these books.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The workbook is an integral part of the ATO Effective Business Writing course. It provides the ATO with a consistent approach to:
(a) the service ethic; and
(b) business writing principles.

It reflects ATO operations and standards, and invites further consultation and reference by participants on return to the workplace. It provides course participants with a standard reference source and written exercises which will help them:
decide when it is appropriate to write to clients;
orientate writing to the needs and concerns of the reader;
use appropriate tone and language register;
write clearly, concisely and concretely so that information is accurately recorded and easily understood;
set out correspondence in the currently accepted ATO layouts;
structure writing in a logical sequence; and
develop confidence in their ability to write.
(2) 500 copies.
(3) Yes.

ATO Effective Business Writing course commenced in late August/early September this year at 7 Branch offices. Given that only part of the course has been completed at this stage, it is too early to demonstrate that these course participants have shown any `notable improvement in output'.
(4) On the current course, 140 employees are using the workbook.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the purpose of the apparent budget of $2 million for advertising the new $10 note.
(2) What is the breakdown of the $2 million budget.
(3) Why is it considered necessary to advertise this new banknote to such an extent.
(4) Who approved the $2 million amount for the advertising campaign.
(5) Was the advertising campaign put to tender; if so, what was the outline of the tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Reserve Bank is spending approximately $1.6 million on a public education program related to the new $10 note. This program is intended to explain why the new note is being issued, and to provide details of the design and security features of the note.
(2) The breakdown of the budget is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Production of television commercial and airtime—$0.714m

PARA.TAB: (including ethnic and regional television)
Press advertising—$0.388m
(including ethnic and regional press)

ANSWER.PARA: Other educational material—$0.269m

PARA.TAB: (leaflets, posters, video)

ANSWER.PARA: Consultants, administration and related expenses—$0.224m

PARA.TAB: Total—$1.595m
(3) The expenditure of $1.6 million was considered a reasonable provision for a public education program of this kind.
(4) The program was approved by the Governor of the Reserve Bank.

(5) The program was put to tender and three tenders were submitted. The major objectives of the program as specified in the tender document were to alert the public to the issue of the new $10 note and to explain its design features and anti-counterfeiting properties.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service invite comments on a management plan from Ausfern Pty Ltd to export antarctica dicksonia (sic).
(2) Was 5 June 1993 the closing date for receiving comment.
(3) How many submissions were received.
(4) How many submissions: (a) supported; (b) opposed, or had criticisms of, the proposal.
(5) Has the management plan been approved; if not, what is the status of Ausfern's proposal.
(6) Is there international concern-about the status of Ausfern's licence to trade overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency (formerly the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service) invited comments on a document entitled Tree Fern Management Plan for APPM Forests, Burnie, which applies to the species Dicksonia antarctica, and which was submitted by Ausfern Pty Ltd on 5 May 1993. The document was circulated to those persons and organisations on the register maintained under section 9B of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.
(2) Yes.
(3) Four.

(4) (a) None. (b) All of the submissions received had criticisms of Ausfern's management plan. Three of them were primarily critical of the management of native forests in Tasmania and the tree fern industry in general.

(5) No. Ausfern's proposal is still under consideration while the Australian Nature Conservation Agency endeavours to find a resolution to the lack of a State-wide management strategy for tree ferns in Tasmania.
(6) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency has not received any international expressions of concern regarding Ausfern's approval to trade overseas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Government Publishing Service : Occupational Overuse Syndrome

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) employees have been diagnosed as having Occupational Overuse Syndrome (OOS) during the 1990-91, 1989-90, 1988-89 and 1987-88 financial years.
(2) How many work days were lost by the AGPS during the 1990-91 financial year as a result of OOS.
(3) What was the cost of lost working days due to OOS in the AGPS during the 1990-91 and 1991-92 financial years.
(4) How is OOS diagnosed.
(5) Has the introduction of pause gymnastics reduced the incidence of OOS; if so, by how many cases and lost working days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) From information supplied by Comcare, the number of AGPS employees diagnosed as having OOS was 5 in the 1990-91 financial year, 9 in the 1989-90 financial year, 7 in the 1988-89 financial year and 3 in the 1987-88 financial year.
(2) From information supplied by Comcare, 1705 work days were lost by the AGPS during the 1990-91 financial year as a result of OOS.
(3) From information supplied by Comcare, the cost of lost working days due to OOS in the AGPS was $170,506.79 during the 1990-91 financial year and $220,887.46 during the 1991-92 financial year.
(4) OOS is diagnosed by the patient's general practitioner from reported symptoms and by medical examination. Subsequent opinion may be sought by referral to a specialist medical practitioner.

(5) The incidence of OOS has been reduced in the area where pause gymnastics was introduced. In 1991-92 there were three new cases in that area compared to one new case in 1992-93. Given that there are a number of factors which contribute to the incidence of OOS, including work practices, work load, workplace design and machine usage, it is not possible to establish a direct causal link between the introduction of pause gymnastics and the incidence of OOS.
